searchDocs.title: Welcome
searchDocs.content: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin. Here are a few tips you might find useful. Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory. Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml. The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as: 2019-05-30-welcome.md2019-05-30-welcome/index.md A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images: The blog supports tags as well! And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.

searchDocs.title: Definition​
searchDocs.content: An experimental component or pattern represents something that is being explored by a team on VA.gov, but has not yet been validated sufficiently by our Veterans and caregivers to become a best practice design system component or pattern.  These are marked as "Use with caution" on the maturity scale.

searchDocs.title: Purpose​
searchDocs.content: The experimental showcase serves several functions:  Purpose	BenefitVisibility	Creates transparency across different contractor teams and companies building on VA.gov Collaboration	Prevents duplicate efforts by making teams aware of similar work happening elsewhere Lightweight contribution	Enables teams to contribute emerging work back to the design system without a heavy approval process

searchDocs.title: Usage guidelines​
searchDocs.content: Teams may use experimental components and patterns in their applications, but should:  Recognize they haven't received full validationProceed cautiously and test within their specific contextDocument any research findings on the component or pattern's documentation page for community benefit

searchDocs.title: Contributing experimental work​

searchDocs.title: Graduating to production​
searchDocs.content: Experimental components can advance through the maturity scale as they:  Gain research validationSee adoption across multiple teamsDemonstrate stability in production

searchDocs.title: Core concepts​
searchDocs.content: Web Components consist of three parts:  Part	DescriptionCustom HTML element	Registers your own HTML tag Shadow DOM	Separate DOM tree with scoped CSS styles Templates and slots	HTML templates providing additional context

searchDocs.title: VA Design System web components​
searchDocs.content: All VA components use a va- prefix (for example, va-alert).

searchDocs.title: Benefits​
searchDocs.content: Framework compatibilityConsistent syntax across projectsActive maintenance and updatesPerformance advantages

searchDocs.title: Vanilla JavaScript​
searchDocs.content: Use web components directly without imports when no functions, objects, arrays, or custom events are needed:  <va-alert status="info" visible> <h2 slot="headline">Alert headline</h2> <p>Alert content goes here.</p> </va-alert>

searchDocs.title: React applications​
searchDocs.content: Two options are available:  Option 1: Direct vanilla component  <va-alert status="info" visible> <h2 slot="headline">Alert headline</h2> <p>Alert content goes here.</p> </va-alert>   Option 2: React binding (for functions/events)  import { VaAlert } from "@department-of-veterans-affairs/component-library/dist/react-bindings"; <VaAlert status="info" visible onCloseEvent={handleClose}> <h2 slot="headline">Alert headline</h2> <p>Alert content goes here.</p> </VaAlert>

searchDocs.title: Custom events in React​
searchDocs.content: Prefix with on and use camelCase. For example, vaChange becomes onVaChange:  <VaTextInput onVaChange={handleChange} />

searchDocs.title: Custom events in vanilla JavaScript​
searchDocs.content: const input = document.querySelector('va-text-input'); input.addEventListener('vaChange', handleChange);

searchDocs.title: Native events in React​
searchDocs.content: Use on prefix with camelCase:  <va-button onClick={(event) => console.log(event.detail)}> Click me </va-button>

searchDocs.title: Native events in vanilla JavaScript​
searchDocs.content: Inline or event listener approach both supported:  const button = document.querySelector('va-button'); button.addEventListener('click', handleClick);

searchDocs.title: Using Foundation​
searchDocs.content: Start with foundation elements to ensure consistency:  Colors - Use only approved color tokensTypography - Apply standard font sizes and weightsSpacing - Use the 8px spacing gridLayout - Use the 12-column flexbox grid

searchDocs.title: Using Components​
searchDocs.content: Check existing components first - Don't recreate what already existsUse components as designed - Don't modify core component stylesFollow usage guidelines - Each component has specific guidanceConsider accessibility - Components are built to WCAG standards

searchDocs.title: Creating New Designs​
searchDocs.content: When existing components don't meet your needs:  Document the gap - Explain what's missingPropose a solution - Design with reusability in mindFollow the contribution process - Get approval before developmentConsider accessibility - All new designs must meet WCAG 2.1 AA

searchDocs.title: Design Review Checklist​
searchDocs.content: Before handing off designs:   Uses approved colors, typography, and spacing Components match design system specifications Responsive behavior is documented Accessibility requirements are noted Content follows style guide States are designed (default, hover, focus, error, disabled)

searchDocs.title: Before You Begin​
searchDocs.content: Teams should use existing design system patterns and components when possible. New components or patterns require approval through the Experimental Design process.

searchDocs.title: When to Contribute​
searchDocs.content: Consider contributing when:  Your component or pattern could benefit multiple VA.gov productsExisting components don't solve your user problem sufficientlyYou've identified a significant gap in the design system

searchDocs.title: Contribution Criteria​
searchDocs.content: A component or pattern is a good candidate if it meets these standards:  Multi-product utility - The component will be useful in multiple products on VA.gov, with documented use cases beyond a single product Significant differentiation - The component differs substantially from existing designs—not merely in color or format variations Unmet user needs - Existing components and patterns won't solve the user problems sufficiently

searchDocs.title: Phase 1: Collaboration Cycle​
searchDocs.content: Identify the need - Document why existing components/patterns don't workResearch - Gather evidence for the user needInitial proposal - Create a brief proposal for reviewDesign System Team review - Get initial feedback

searchDocs.title: Phase 2: Submission & Review​
searchDocs.content: Submit your request - Use the contribution request formProvide documentation - Include research, designs, and use casesReview process - The governance team evaluates the proposalIterate - Address feedback and refine the design

searchDocs.title: Phase 3: Implementation​
searchDocs.content: Develop - Build the approved component/patternTest - Ensure accessibility and cross-browser compatibilityDocument - Write usage guidelines and examplesDeploy - Release to the design system

searchDocs.content: Propose and research components/patternsProvide use cases and documentationImplement approved designsParticipate in review process

searchDocs.content: Review proposals and provide feedbackSupport teams through the contribution processMaintain quality standardsManage releases

searchDocs.title: Governance Team​
searchDocs.content: Make final approval decisionsEnsure alignment with design system strategyBalance consistency with innovation

searchDocs.title: Documentation Contributions​
searchDocs.content: Teams can contribute directly to design system documentation through GitHub.

searchDocs.title: How to Contribute Docs​
searchDocs.content: Fork the repository - Create your own copyMake changes - Edit or add documentationSubmit a pull request - Request review of your changesAddress feedback - Make requested revisionsMerge - Changes are published after approval

searchDocs.title: Documentation Standards​
searchDocs.content: Use clear, plain languageInclude code examples where appropriateProvide accessibility guidanceFollow the existing structure and format

searchDocs.title: Start Early​
searchDocs.content: Begin the contribution process during the design phase, before development begins. Early engagement helps avoid rework.

searchDocs.title: Provide Evidence​
searchDocs.content: Support your proposal with:  User research findingsAnalytics dataUse cases from multiple productsCompetitive analysis

searchDocs.title: Be Collaborative​
searchDocs.content: Work with the Design System Team throughout the process. They can help refine your proposal and increase its chances of approval.

searchDocs.title: Think Beyond Your Product​
searchDocs.content: Design for reusability. Consider how other teams might use your component in different contexts.

searchDocs.title: Page Structure​
searchDocs.content: Every component page follows this structure:  1. Title & Description (frontmatter) 2. Component Header (maturity badge, platform tags, resource links) 3. Related Components 4. Examples 5. Usage (when to use, when not to use, behavior, placement) 6. Code Usage (per platform) 7. Content Considerations 8. Accessibility Considerations 9. Related Components (footer)

searchDocs.title: Required Imports​
searchDocs.content: At the top of each component MDX file, include these imports:  // For components with both platforms (tabs) import Tabs from '@theme/Tabs'; import TabItem from '@theme/TabItem'; // Core components import ComponentHeader from '@site/src/components/ComponentHeader'; import StoryEmbed from '@site/src/components/StoryEmbed'; import AutoPropsTable from '@site/src/components/AutoPropsTable'; import DosDonts, { Do, Dont } from '@site/src/components/DosDonts';   For single-platform components, you can skip the Tabs imports.

searchDocs.title: Component Header​
searchDocs.content: The ComponentHeader component displays the maturity status and platform availability:  <ComponentHeader maturity="deployed" platforms={['web', 'mobile']} github="https://github.com/..." figma="https://figma.com/..." />

searchDocs.title: Props​
searchDocs.content: Prop	Type	Descriptionmaturity	'deployed' | 'use-with-caution' | 'dont-use' | 'best-practice'	Component maturity level platforms	('web' | 'mobile')[]	Which platforms support this component github	string	Link to GitHub issues/source figma	string	Link to Figma designs research	string	Link to research documentation

searchDocs.title: Platform Combinations​
searchDocs.content: // Web only platforms={['web']} // Mobile only platforms={['mobile']} // Both platforms platforms={['web', 'mobile']}

searchDocs.title: Platform Tags​
searchDocs.content: Use PlatformTag to label platform-specific sections within the page. This keeps all content visible while clearly indicating which platform it applies to.

searchDocs.title: When to Use Platform Tags​
searchDocs.content: Code examples that differ between web and mobileProps/API tables that are platform-specificExamples that only exist on one platformBehavior notes that differ by platform

searchDocs.title: How to Use​
searchDocs.content: Add the tag inline with headings:  ### Web component <PlatformTag platform="web" size="small" /> ### React Native component <PlatformTag platform="mobile" size="small" /> ### Destructive variant <PlatformTag platform="mobile" size="small" />

searchDocs.title: Tag Sizes​
searchDocs.content: size="small" - Use inline with headingssize="medium" - Default, use standalone

searchDocs.title: Auto-Generated Props Tables​
searchDocs.content: Use AutoPropsTable to automatically fetch and display component properties from VA's published component documentation. This keeps props in sync with the actual component libraries.

searchDocs.title: How It Works​
searchDocs.content: Props are fetched at runtime from:  Web components: @department-of-veterans-affairs/web-components package (component-docs.json)Mobile components: VA Design System documentation repository (mobile-app-component-docs-source.json)

searchDocs.title: Usage​
searchDocs.content: // Web component props (default) <AutoPropsTable componentTag="va-button" /> // Mobile component props <AutoPropsTable componentTag="va-button" platform="mobile" /> // Hide events table <AutoPropsTable componentTag="va-button" showEvents={false} />

searchDocs.title: Props​
searchDocs.content: Prop	Type	Default	DescriptioncomponentTag	string	—	The component tag name (e.g., "va-button") platform	'web' | 'mobile'	'web'	Which platform's props to display showEvents	boolean	true	Whether to show the events table

searchDocs.title: Benefits​
searchDocs.content: Always up-to-date: Props automatically sync with the published component librariesNo manual maintenance: Changes to component APIs are reflected automaticallyConsistent formatting: All props tables look the same across the site

searchDocs.title: Platform Tabs​
searchDocs.content: For components available on both platforms, use tabs to organize platform-specific content. This keeps the page clean while allowing users to switch between Web and Mobile documentation.

searchDocs.title: When to Use Tabs​
searchDocs.content: Component supports both Web and Mobile platformsExamples, code, or props differ between platforms

searchDocs.title: When NOT to Use Tabs​
searchDocs.content: Component only supports one platform (just show the content directly)Content is the same for both platforms (no need to duplicate)

searchDocs.title: Implementation​
searchDocs.content: Import the Docusaurus Tabs components:  import Tabs from '@theme/Tabs'; import TabItem from '@theme/TabItem';   Use groupId="platform" and queryString to sync tabs across sections:  <Tabs groupId="platform" queryString> <TabItem value="web" label="Web" default> Web content here... </TabItem> <TabItem value="mobile" label="Mobile"> Mobile content here... </TabItem> </Tabs>

searchDocs.title: Key Features​
searchDocs.content: Synced tabs: All tab groups with groupId="platform" stay in syncURL persistence: queryString saves the selection in the URL (e.g., ?platform=mobile)Default tab: Use default on the TabItem to set the initial selection

searchDocs.title: Code Usage Section​
searchDocs.content: For components available on both platforms, structure the Code Usage section with tabs:  ## Code usage <Tabs groupId="platform" queryString> <TabItem value="web" label="Web" default> \`\`\`html <va-button text="Continue"></va-button> \`\`\` ### Properties <AutoPropsTable componentTag="va-button" /> </TabItem> <TabItem value="mobile" label="Mobile"> \`\`\`jsx import { Button } from '@department-of-veterans-affairs/mobile-component-library'; <Button label="Continue" onPress={() => {}} /> \`\`\` ### Props <AutoPropsTable componentTag="va-button" platform="mobile" /> </TabItem> </Tabs>   For single-platform components, skip the tabs entirely:  ## Code usage \`\`\`html <va-alert status="info">...</va-alert> \`\`\` ### Properties <AutoPropsTable componentTag="va-alert" />

searchDocs.title: Manual Props Tables​
searchDocs.content: For components not in the VA component libraries, or when you need to override the auto-generated props, use PropsTable:  import PropsTable from '@site/src/components/PropsTable'; <PropsTable properties={[ { name: 'text', type: 'string', default: 'undefined', required: true, description: 'Button display text' }, ]} events={[ { name: 'click', description: 'Fires when clicked', detail: 'MouseEvent' }, ]} />

searchDocs.title: Storybook Embeds​
searchDocs.content: Use StoryEmbed to show interactive examples from VA's Storybook:  <StoryEmbed storyId="uswds-va-button--primary" height={80} title="Primary button example" />

searchDocs.title: Finding Story IDs​
searchDocs.content: Go to design.va.gov/storybookNavigate to the componentThe story ID is in the URL: ?path=/story/{story-id}

searchDocs.title: Dos and Donts​

searchDocs.title: Creating a Checklist Page​
searchDocs.content: Create a data file in src/data/component-checklist/[component-name].json:  { "componentName": "Button", "webCompleted": "August 15, 2025", "mobileCompleted": "August 20, 2025", "maturity": [ { "name": "Guidance", "webScore": true, "mobileScore": true }, { "name": "Research", "webScore": true, "mobileScore": true }, { "name": "Stability", "webScore": true, "mobileScore": true }, { "name": "Adoption", "webScore": true, "mobileScore": true } ], "codeAssets": [ { "name": "Variations", "webScore": true, "mobileScore": true }, { "name": "Responsive", "webScore": true, "mobileScore": true }, { "name": "Interactive states", "webScore": true, "mobileScore": true }, { "name": "Tokens", "webScore": "n/a", "mobileScore": "n/a" }, { "name": "Internationalization", "webScore": "n/a", "mobileScore": "n/a" } ], "visualAssets": [ { "name": "Variations", "webScore": true, "mobileScore": true }, { "name": "Responsive", "webScore": true, "mobileScore": true }, { "name": "Interactive states", "webScore": true, "mobileScore": true }, { "name": "Tokens", "webScore": "n/a", "mobileScore": "n/a" } ], "accessibility": { "web": { "platform": "web", "lastAuditDate": "August 2025", "codeReview": "pass", "readability": "pass", "automatedScans": "pass", "useOfColor": "pass", "textResizing": "pass", "screenReaders": "pass", "inputMethods": "pass" } } }   Register the data in src/data/component-checklist/index.ts Create the checklist page using the template at static/templates/component-checklist-template.mdx:  --- title: Button - Component checklist description: Maturity and asset checklist for the Button component sidebar_label: Checklist --- import ComponentChecklist from '@site/src/components/ComponentChecklist'; import { checklistData } from '@site/src/data/component-checklist'; import ChecklistDefinitions from '@site/docs/_partials/checklist-definitions.mdx'; import Link from '@docusaurus/Link'; # Button checklist <Link to="/components/button">← Back to Button</Link> This checklist tracks the maturity, code assets, visual assets, and accessibility audit status for the Button component. <ComponentChecklist data={checklistData.button} platform="both" /> <ChecklistDefinitions />

searchDocs.title: Purpose​
searchDocs.content: These standards center on end-user experience for Veterans, families, caregivers, and the public. Teams can self-check their work against these criteria throughout development to verify alignment with user needs.

searchDocs.title: 1. Comprehension​
searchDocs.content: User easily understands the product. Launch-blocking issues occur when users struggle to understand task completion.  Standards:  Element perception (users can perceive meaningful elements)Content best practices adherenceSufficient task information availabilityClear button/link destination expectations

searchDocs.title: 2. Consistency​
searchDocs.content: User has a predictable and unchanging experience across all VA.gov and VA Mobile App services.  Standards:  Accurate, consistent contentBest-practice components and patternsClear, consistent design componentsContent alignment with other VA.gov contentCurrent design component versionsAlignment with VA.gov design principles

searchDocs.title: 3. Credibility​
searchDocs.content: User perceives VA.gov and VA Mobile App as a credible source.  Standards:  Voice and tone alignment with content principlesInformation review/edit capability before submissionAppropriate status notifications

searchDocs.title: 4. Efficiency​
searchDocs.content: User accomplishes goals quickly with minimal cognitive load.  Standards:  Primary task focus without distractionsNo unnecessary repetitionUser notification before flow interruptions

searchDocs.title: 5. Findability​
searchDocs.content: User identifies location within VA.gov and navigation next steps.  Standards:  Clear next steps identificationSite location awarenessAccessible content pathways

searchDocs.title: 6. Health and safety​
searchDocs.content: User safely accesses tools without health risks.

searchDocs.title: 7. Usability​
searchDocs.content: User easily knows how to use the interface.  Standards:  Flow completion capabilityElement identification and state recognitionPredictable component interactions

searchDocs.title: Three major categories​
searchDocs.content: Category	Status levels	GuidanceUse	Deployed, Best practice	Ready for production use Use with caution	Candidate, Available	May have limited validation Don't use	Proposed, Deprecated	Not ready or no longer recommended

searchDocs.title: 1. Proposed​
searchDocs.content: Request filed but not yet reviewed by Design System Team or Council.

searchDocs.title: 2. Candidate​
searchDocs.content: Evaluated by leadership. Documentation in progress. Possibly limited production use.

searchDocs.title: 3. Available​
searchDocs.content: Complete and ready for use. May or may not be in production. Has some research support.

searchDocs.title: 4. Deployed​
searchDocs.content: In production 3+ months. Adopted by multiple projects. Research-backed variations exist.

searchDocs.title: 5. Best practice​
searchDocs.content: Production use 1+ year. No significant issues. Multi-project adoption. Research-supported.

searchDocs.title: 6. Deprecated​
searchDocs.content: No longer recommended. May have significant issues or been superseded by alternatives.

searchDocs.title: Structure​
searchDocs.content: The naming format follows: [global namespace]-[class prefix]-[BEM syntax]  Example: .vads-c-component-name

searchDocs.title: 1. Global namespace​
searchDocs.content: The namespace is vads (Veterans Affairs Design System). This identifier distinguishes Design System classes from application-specific ones.

searchDocs.title: 2. Class prefix​
searchDocs.content: Prefixes indicate function:  Prefix	Purposec	Component u	Utility l	Layout

searchDocs.title: 3. BEM syntax​
searchDocs.content: BEM stands for Block, Element, Modifier.  Block (base component):  .alert {}   Element (child components, using __ separator):  .alert__header {} .alert__body {}   Modifier (variations, using -- separator):  .alert--success {} .alert--error {}

searchDocs.title: Complete example​
searchDocs.content: <div class="alert alert--success"> <h2 class="alert__header">This is the alert heading</h2> <div class="alert__body"> <p>This is some alert text</p> </div> </div>

searchDocs.title: Why Accessibility Matters​
searchDocs.content: Veterans and their families include people with a wide range of abilities. Accessibility ensures that:  Users with visual impairments can navigate with screen readersUsers with motor impairments can use keyboard navigationUsers with cognitive disabilities can understand contentUsers with hearing impairments can access audio content

searchDocs.title: Standards​
searchDocs.content: VA.gov follows WCAG 2.1 Level AA standards, which is required by:  Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act21st Century IDEA (Integrated Digital Experience Act)

searchDocs.title: Common Requirements​
searchDocs.content: Color contrast: 4.5:1 for normal text, 3:1 for large textFocus visible: All interactive elements must have visible focusLabels: All form inputs must have associated labelsAlt text: All meaningful images must have alt textHeadings: Use proper heading hierarchy (H1 → H2 → H3)Links: Link text must be descriptive and unique

searchDocs.title: The challenge​
searchDocs.content: Teams often struggle knowing which content needs screen reader announcement, leading to over-verbosity and increased cognitive load for users relying on screen readers.

searchDocs.title: How screen readers function​
searchDocs.content: Screen readers convert digital text to synthesized speech, reading content sequentially. Users navigate via:  HeadingsParagraphsHTML elements (inputs, tables, links, buttons)Landmarks (header, main, footer)Skip navigation links

searchDocs.title: Key behaviors​
searchDocs.content: Announce page titles on loadRead image alt textIdentify heading levelsRespect user verbosity settings

searchDocs.title: 1. Errors​
searchDocs.content: Any time a blocking error occurs preventing forward progress requires announcement. Users need immediate feedback when something goes wrong.

searchDocs.title: 2. Dynamic page changes​
searchDocs.content: When user actions trigger updates elsewhere on the page via JavaScript, announcements prevent confusion. Users need to know content has changed without having to search for it.

searchDocs.title: 3. State changes​
searchDocs.content: Component states (like accordion expansion) using aria-expanded attributes need communication. Users should understand when interactive elements change state.

searchDocs.title: 4. Focus shifts​
searchDocs.content: Dynamic focus changes, such as modals appearing, require announcement of new locations. Users need context about where focus has moved and why.

searchDocs.title: 5. Images and icons​
searchDocs.content: Visual elements communicating important information must be described or marked decorative. Meaningful images need alt text; decorative images should be hidden from screen readers.

searchDocs.title: 6. Contextual information​
searchDocs.content: Supporting content during processes needs announcement for complete understanding. Help text, hints, and supplementary information should be accessible.

searchDocs.title: 7. Language changes​
searchDocs.content: The HTML lang attribute enables proper pronunciation of content in different languages. Screen readers adjust pronunciation based on language attributes.

searchDocs.title: Prioritize native HTML​
searchDocs.content: Use semantic HTML elements before reaching for ARIA attributes. Native elements have built-in accessibility support.

searchDocs.title: Keep announcements concise​
searchDocs.content: Reduce cognitive burden while maintaining clarity. Long announcements can overwhelm users and cause them to miss important information.

searchDocs.title: Avoid over-announcement​
searchDocs.content: Not everything needs to be announced. Focus on critical information that users need to complete tasks successfully.

searchDocs.title: Visual indicator​
searchDocs.content: VA.gov uses a thick gold outline to indicate focus on interactive elements.

searchDocs.title: Key guidelines​
searchDocs.content: Never eliminate focus indicators from interactive componentsAvoid custom focus styling; leverage system-wide defaultsEnsure complete visibility of the outline around grouped elements

searchDocs.title: Principle​
searchDocs.content: Focus order should match the visual reading order of the page, progressing left-to-right and top-to-bottom for English content.

searchDocs.title: Requirements​
searchDocs.content: Include only interactive elements (buttons, links, inputs) in tab sequencesMaintain predictability and logical progression

searchDocs.title: Benefits​
searchDocs.content: Provides screen reader context when elements receive focusDirects users toward relevant next actions

searchDocs.title: Risks​
searchDocs.content: Can disorient users if triggered unexpectedlyMay interfere with aria-live announcements

searchDocs.title: Page load​
searchDocs.content: For single-page applications, set focus to the first unique heading when a new page loads.

searchDocs.title: Content changes​
searchDocs.content: Move focus to newly added contentRestore focus logically when content is removed

searchDocs.title: Error states​
searchDocs.content: Direct focus to the first problematic input requiring correction.

searchDocs.title: Modals​
searchDocs.content: On open:  Move focus to the modal's first interactive elementAvoid focusing on destructive actions (like "Delete") first  On close:  Restore focus to the triggering button

searchDocs.title: Developer notes​
searchDocs.content: Moving focus into Shadow DOM elements produces unpredictable outcomes across browsersConsider prioritizing focus announcements over aria-live when both apply

searchDocs.title: Testing requirements​
searchDocs.content: Teams must independently test their products for accessibility and comply with VA.gov Experience Standards. Complete foundational accessibility testing before staging reviews and pursue advanced testing as well.

searchDocs.title: Component evaluation in context​
searchDocs.content: Design system components are tested in isolation. While we try to ensure that no accessibility barriers exist in any given component, barriers can still be introduced when components are used in an unanticipated combination or context.  Teams should evaluate:  Headings - Proper hierarchy and logical content groupingButton/Link text - Meaningful language that conveys purposeLabels - Clear, concise, and understandable textPlain language - Error messages describing issues with resolution pathsColor contrast - Against backgrounds and adjacent elements

searchDocs.title: Defect reporting​
searchDocs.content: Teams identifying accessibility defects should submit issues to the GitHub repository.

searchDocs.title: POUR framework​
searchDocs.content: Components are tested against four accessibility principles:  Principle	DescriptionPerceivable	Information presentable in perceivable ways Operable	Components and navigation are operable Understandable	Information and operation are understandable Robust	Content interpretable by various user agents and assistive technologies

searchDocs.title: Standards compliance​
searchDocs.content: Testing adheres to WCAG 2.2 Level AA, incorporating Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act requirements.

searchDocs.title: Assistive technology coverage​
searchDocs.content: Testing includes screen readers, voice commands, magnification, browser settings, contrast themes, and various input methods.

searchDocs.title: Code review​
searchDocs.content: Reviewers examine:  Proper semantic HTML usageValid ARIA implementationAppropriate element labeling

searchDocs.title: Automated scanning​
searchDocs.content: aXe DevTools scans via Cypress for default variationsBrowser extension scans for additional variations

searchDocs.title: Readability evaluation​
searchDocs.content: Assessment of heading hierarchy, button/link text clarity, label quality, and plain language compliance.

searchDocs.title: Color testing​
searchDocs.content: WCAG Level AA contrast ratio complianceNon-color-dependent information communicationWindows contrast theme compatibility

searchDocs.title: Text and display adjustments​
searchDocs.content: Testing covers:  Browser font size adjustmentsZoom levels at 200%, 300%, and 400%macOS Zoom and Windows Magnifier compatibility

searchDocs.content: Screen reader	Browser	PlatformJAWS	Chrome	Windows NVDA	Firefox	Windows Narrator	Edge	Windows VoiceOver	Safari	macOS TalkBack	Chrome	Android VoiceOver	Safari	iOS  Testing verifies:  Content announcement orderUnique accessible namesProper element type announcementsStandard navigation patterns

searchDocs.title: Input method testing​
searchDocs.content: Touch and mouse:  Target sizes meet WCAG AA requirementsNo multipoint or path-based gestures requiredNo specific timing requirements  Keyboard:  All interactive elements focusableVisible focus indicators with proper contrastArrow key functionality for form elementsKeyboard activation capabilityNo focus trapping  Voice commands:  Accessible names match visible labelsStraightforward pronunciation for clear interaction

searchDocs.title: Checklist result categories​
searchDocs.content: Result	DescriptionPass	Meets all requirements Conditional pass	Passes with specific conditions Pass with exceptions	Minor issues noted Fail	Does not meet requirements Not completed	Testing not yet performed  Notes clarify results, such as false positives in automated scans.

searchDocs.title: Components, templates, and patterns​
searchDocs.content: Names should align with VA content principles—clear, concise, and user-focused. The ideal length is 1-2 words, though exceptions exist (for example, "On This Page").  Generic web tools should share standard names (for example, accordions).

searchDocs.title: Pattern naming format​
searchDocs.content: Patterns follow a structured format:  "Ask Users for [Topic]" (for example, Files, Addresses)"Help Users to [Action]" (for example, Sign In, Check Answers)

searchDocs.title: Naming structure​
searchDocs.content: Element	Convention	ExampleFolders and files	kebab-case	action-bar, form-controls Component names	va- prefix + kebab-case	<va-alert>, <va-modal> Attributes	kebab-case	close-handler, is-visible Boolean attributes	is-, has-, should- prefixes	is-visible, has-error

searchDocs.title: Shadow DOM and slots​
searchDocs.content: Named slots use kebab-case: <slot name="header-content">  Internal classes follow Block Element Modifier (BEM) notation:  Block: .va-component-nameElement: .va-component-name__elementModifier: .va-component-name--modifier

searchDocs.title: Front matter​
searchDocs.content: Specify actual web component names with va- prefix in kebab-case.

searchDocs.title: Page titles​
searchDocs.content: Convert kebab-case to Title Case with spaces (for example, va-alert-expandable → "Alert - Expandable").

searchDocs.title: URL structure​
searchDocs.content: Use kebab-case without the va- prefix. Employ hierarchical paths for variations:  Base: /components/alertVariations: /components/link/actionSpecific variants: Use anchor links (for example, #primary-entry)

searchDocs.title: Variant naming strategy​
searchDocs.content: Type	ApproachSimple variations	Document on main component page with anchor links Complex variations	Create separate pages maintaining hierarchical titles State variations	Document on relevant component/variation page with clear state indicators

searchDocs.title: Implementation checklist​
searchDocs.content: When adding new documentation:  Include web component name with va- prefix in front matterTransform kebab-case to Title Case for human readabilityUse " - " separators for hierarchical elementsAvoid words like "component" or "pattern" in link textMaintain URL consistency with similar components

searchDocs.title: Purpose and audience​
searchDocs.content: Target users:  Designers and developersPlatform Governance teamEnd users with disabilities using assistive technologies  Key benefits:Annotations push designers to incorporate accessibility as part of the design work rather than an afterthought. They reduce developer guesswork by providing clear semantic HTML and UI interaction guidance.

searchDocs.title: When to add annotations​
searchDocs.content: Designers should add annotations before design/developer handoff. The Collaboration Cycle recommends completion before midpoint review. This allows the Governance team's accessibility specialist to evaluate decisions early and suggest changes before engineering begins.

searchDocs.title: Annotation library​
searchDocs.content: The VA.gov Platform uses an open-source accessibility annotation kit from CVS, located in the Figma VADS Annotation Kit within the VA Design System folder.

searchDocs.title: Pin stamps​
searchDocs.content: Point to specific design elements, with adjustable orientation (above, below, left, right, or center).

searchDocs.title: Lasso stamps​
searchDocs.content: Highlight design areas for landmarks or components like linked cards, with customizable label positioning.

searchDocs.title: Details cards​
searchDocs.content: Numbered reference notes corresponding to pin/lasso stamps, containing:  Interface behaviorURLsError messagesSemantic HTML codeARIA attributes

searchDocs.title: Available annotation categories​
searchDocs.content: ButtonsDesign System (DS) componentsFeedback messagesFocus orderHeadingsImagesInputsLandmarksLinksListsNotesReading orderUtilities

searchDocs.title: What to annotate​
searchDocs.content: Prioritize annotating elements where an engineer needs to make decisions about something that's not baked into a component or forms library code.

searchDocs.title: Essential items​
searchDocs.content: Heading levels and hierarchy - Use pin stamps to identify semantic levels (H1-H6), especially when visual styling differs from hierarchyARIA labels and accessible names - Annotate unique names for multiple similar elementsFieldset and legend placement - Use lasso stamps to show grouping of related form inputsError messages - Document custom or unique error messaging for content review and testingFocus management - Indicate primary focus destination on page load and between pagesCustom code implementations - Any non-standard interactionsSpecific VADS component usage notes - Component-specific requirementsForm elements - Elements between breadcrumb and help component

searchDocs.title: Best practices​
searchDocs.content: Over-annotation is preferable to under-annotation because it:  Encourages designer-engineer communicationForces deeper experience considerationEliminates developer guesswork  Tailor annotation verbosity to team expertise levels. As teams mature, annotation approaches may evolve.

searchDocs.title: Collaborative approach​
searchDocs.content: Use annotations as communication tools. Teams utilize the kit differently based on their needs and should establish shared understanding with engineering partners.

searchDocs.title: Collaboration cycle integration​
searchDocs.content: Submit annotated prototypes at midpoint review for Governance team evaluation. This timing allows accessibility specialists to assess design decisions and surface open questions before engineering handoff.

searchDocs.title: Required usage​
searchDocs.content: All teams building on VA.gov must use v3 components exclusively. Using a v1 component will be considered a launch-blocking issue.

searchDocs.title: No imposter components​
searchDocs.content: Teams must not create custom-coded elements that mimic design system components. This is a design system violation. Exceptions include:  Basic HTML <button> elements styled as the default button variationBasic HTML <a> tags styled as default links

searchDocs.content: The following components are deprecated and should not be used in new development:  Banner - Promo - Use standard Banner insteadInput message - Use Alert (slim variant) insteadNotification - Use Alert instead

searchDocs.title: Content​
searchDocs.content: Page has one H1 that describes the page content Headings are hierarchical (H1 → H2 → H3, no skipping levels) Link text is descriptive (avoid "click here" or "learn more" alone) Images have alt text describing the content (or empty alt="" for decorative images) Content is readable at 200% zoom without horizontal scrolling Language is plain and easy to understand

searchDocs.title: Color & Contrast​
searchDocs.content: Text has sufficient contrast (4.5:1 for normal text, 3:1 for large text) UI components have sufficient contrast (3:1 minimum) Color is not the only indicator of meaning (use icons, text, patterns too) Focus indicators are visible on all interactive elements Links are distinguishable from surrounding text (not just by color)

searchDocs.title: Keyboard​
searchDocs.content: All functionality is keyboard accessible (no mouse required) Focus order is logical (follows visual reading order) Focus is visible on all interactive elements No keyboard traps (user can navigate away from all elements) Skip links work (skip to main content link at page start)

searchDocs.title: Forms​
searchDocs.content: All inputs have visible labels (not just placeholder text) Labels are associated with inputs (using for/id or wrapping) Required fields are indicated (not just with asterisk) Error messages are clear and specific about what's wrong Error messages are associated with fields (using aria-describedby) Form can be submitted with keyboard (Enter key works) Focus moves to first error after failed submission

searchDocs.title: Images & Media​
searchDocs.content: Informative images have descriptive alt text Decorative images have empty alt="" Complex images have extended descriptions (diagrams, charts) Videos have captions Audio has transcripts No auto-playing media (or easily paused/stopped)

searchDocs.title: Interactive Components​
searchDocs.content: Buttons use <button> element (not styled divs/spans) Links use <a> element with valid href Custom components have ARIA roles where needed State changes are announced to screen readers Modals trap focus while open Modals return focus when closed

searchDocs.title: Mobile & Responsive​
searchDocs.content: Touch targets are at least 44x44 pixels Content is usable at all screen sizes No horizontal scrolling at 320px width Orientation is not locked (works in portrait and landscape)

searchDocs.title: Screen Reader​
searchDocs.content: Page has descriptive title (<title> element) Main content is in <main> element Navigation is in <nav> element Regions have accessible names (aria-label on landmarks) Live regions announce updates (aria-live for dynamic content) Tables have headers (<th> elements with scope)

searchDocs.title: Testing​
searchDocs.content: Automated testing passes (axe, WAVE, Lighthouse) Keyboard testing completed (Tab, Enter, Space, Escape) Screen reader testing completed (VoiceOver or NVDA) Zoom testing completed (up to 200%) Mobile testing completed (real device or emulator)

searchDocs.title: When to Use​
searchDocs.content: Before code reviewBefore launching new featuresWhen updating existing pagesDuring accessibility audits

searchDocs.title: How to Test​
searchDocs.content: Automated first - Run axe or WAVE to catch obvious issuesKeyboard navigation - Tab through the entire pageScreen reader - Navigate with VoiceOver or NVDAVisual inspection - Check contrast, focus states, zoom

searchDocs.title: Accordion
searchDocs.content: Accordion Best practiceWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch...Storybook Accordions are expandable content sections using progressive disclosure principles. They display as a list of headers that users can click to reveal or hide additional content. By default, accordions are multi-selectable and borderless, however, props can be added to make them bordered and single-select. searchDocs.title: Button
searchDocs.content: Button Use: DeployedWebMobile GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch...Storybook Variations Button groupArranges multiple buttons with gapsButton - SegmentedRelated options in a compact containerButton - IconTertiary button with icon and label Related components Link - For navigation between pagesAction link - For prominent call-to-action links Examples WebMobile app Primary The primary button is for the most important action on a page. Use to advance users to the next step. Interactive ExamplePrimary View in Storybook Secondary For non-primary or current-page actions that should be visually downplayed. Interactive ExampleSecondary View in Storybook Big For the only action on a page. Uses primary button styling at a larger size. Interactive ExampleBig View in Storybook Continue Specialized variation with forward arrow icon for form navigation. Interactive ExampleContinue View in Storybook Back Specialized variation with back arrow icon for form navigation. Interactive ExampleBack View in Storybook Usage When to use Actions: Use buttons for clickable actions such as "Add", "Close", "Cancel", or "Save"Triggers: Use buttons to trigger functionality via JavaScript, like closing a modalForm progression: Primary buttons advance users to the next step in a processSecondary actions: Use secondary buttons for non-primary actions that need to be downplayed When to consider something else Navigation: For links between pages, use Link components insteadCall-to-action prominence: Consider using Action links for visually prominent CTAs linking to other pagesGeneral decoration: Avoid using buttons purely for visual effect Behavior Limit primary buttons per page or section to maintain their impactArrow icons are reserved exclusively for "Back" and "Continue" buttons in formsUse icons in buttons only when necessary for clarity—never for decorationAvoid disabling buttons as a design solutionPrimary buttons typically appear first or to the left of secondary buttons Diagrams Button Decision Flow Use this flowchart to determine which button type to use Code usage WebMobile app Usage ```html <!-- Primary button --> <va-button text="Continue"></va-button> <!-- Secondary button --> <va-button text="Cancel" secondary></va-button> <!-- Big button --> <va-button text="Submit application" big></va-button> <!-- Continue with arrow --> <va-button continue></va-button> <!-- Back with arrow --> <va-button back></va-button> ``` Properties Loading component documentation... Buttons vs. links​ It's important to use the correct element for the intended action: Use a button when: Submitting a formTriggering an action (save, delete, cancel)Opening a modal or dialogToggling a statePerforming a JavaScript action Use a link when: Navigating to another pageNavigating to an anchor on the same pageOpening a resource in a new tab Decision flowchart​ Is the action navigating to a new page or anchor? ├── Yes → Use a link (<a>) └── No → Does the action submit a form? ├── Yes → Use a submit button (<button type="submit">) └── No → Use a button (<button type="button">) Why this matters​ Screen readers announce buttons and links differently, setting user expectationsKeyboard users expect different behaviors (Enter for links, Enter/Space for buttons)Search engines follow links but ignore buttonsBrowser behavior differs (links can be opened in new tabs, bookmarked, etc.) Do not disable buttons​ Avoid disabling buttons when possible. Disabled buttons present several usability and accessibility problems: Problems with disabled buttons: Screen readers may not announce disabled buttons or their labelsUsers can't understand why a button is disabledLow contrast makes disabled buttons hard to seeKeyboard users can't focus on disabled buttons to learn their purpose Better alternatives: Keep the button enabled and show an error message when clicked with invalid inputHide the button entirely until the user completes required fieldsShow a clear message explaining what the user needs to do before proceeding If you must disable a button: Provide visible text explaining why it's disabledUse aria-describedby to associate the explanation with the buttonEnsure the disabled state has sufficient contrast (3:1 minimum) <!-- If disabling is necessary --> <button disabled aria-describedby="button-help">Submit</button> <p id="button-help">Complete all required fields to submit.</p> View component checklist Provide feedback Share your feedback, report issues, or suggest improvements for the Button component. searchDocs.title: Replace with Alert​
searchDocs.content: Use the Alert component with the appropriate status:  <!-- Informational notification --> <va-alert status="info" visible> <h2 slot="headline">Information</h2> <p>Your notification message here.</p> </va-alert> <!-- Success notification --> <va-alert status="success" visible closeable> <h2 slot="headline">Success</h2> <p>Your action was completed successfully.</p> </va-alert> <!-- Warning notification --> <va-alert status="warning" visible> <h2 slot="headline">Warning</h2> <p>Please review this information carefully.</p> </va-alert> <!-- Error notification --> <va-alert status="error" visible> <h2 slot="headline">Error</h2> <p>Something went wrong. Please try again.</p> </va-alert>

searchDocs.title: For dismissible notifications​
searchDocs.content: Use the closeable attribute to allow users to dismiss the alert:  <va-alert status="success" visible closeable> <h2 slot="headline">Changes saved</h2> <p>Your profile has been updated.</p> </va-alert>

searchDocs.title: Why was this deprecated?​
searchDocs.content: Redundancy: The Alert component provides all notification functionalityAccessibility: Alert includes robust ARIA support and screen reader announcementsFeature parity: Alert supports all status types, dismissibility, and styling options

searchDocs.title: Replacement​
searchDocs.content: View Alert Component →

searchDocs.title: Filter chip
searchDocs.content: Filter chip Use with cautionWebMobile Usage When to use Filtering lists or search results: Use filter chips when users need to narrow down content based on multiple criteriaTag-based filtering: When content is categorized with tags that users can select to filterMulti-select filters: When users should be able to apply multiple filters simultaneously When to consider something else Single selection: If only one option can be selected at a time, consider radio buttons or a select dropdownPrimary actions: Don't use filter chips for primary actions; use buttons insteadNavigation: Use tabs or links for navigation between different views Behavior Filter chips toggle between selected and unselected states when clickedSelected chips should have a distinct visual treatment (e.g., filled background, checkmark icon)Chips should be dismissible when in the selected stateChanges should be reflected immediately in the filtered content Code usage Usage <va-filter-chip label="Category name" selected ></va-filter-chip> Properties Loading component documentation... Content considerations Keep chip labels short and descriptive (1-3 words)Use sentence case for labelsBe specific about what the filter doesAvoid jargon or technical terms users won't understand Accessibility considerations Chips should announce their label and current state (selected/not selected)State changes should be announced when toggledUse aria-pressed to indicate the selected stateEnsure sufficient color contrast for both states View component checklist Provide feedback Share your feedback, report issues, or suggest improvements for the Filter chip component. searchDocs.content: Progress bar - Activity Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... searchDocs.title: List selection​
searchDocs.content: Use numbered lists for steps requiring a specific sequenceUse bulleted lists for items without required order

searchDocs.title: List introduction​
searchDocs.content: Introduce lists with complete sentencesAvoid phrases like "the following"; use "these" insteadDon't combine introduction with list item starting words

searchDocs.title: List structure​
searchDocs.content: Never create single-item listsMinimize sub-bullets; create separate lists if neededKeep items to 1-2 sentences maximumLimit lists to 7 items; use subheads for longer listsMaintain parallel construction throughout

searchDocs.title: Conjunctions​
searchDocs.content: When using "and" or "or," bold and place at end of each itemNever use "and/or"; instead list all options separately

searchDocs.title: Punctuation rules​
searchDocs.content: We determine punctuation by list, not by page:  Fragments only: No ending periodsMixed or multiple sentences: End periods for all items

searchDocs.title: Bulleted list (fragments)​
searchDocs.content: What documents and information do I need to apply?  Your Social Security numberYour bank account direct deposit informationYour education and military historyBasic information about the school

searchDocs.title: List with conjunctions​
searchDocs.content: Both of these descriptions must be true:  You have a current illness or injury affecting your mind or body, andYou served on active duty, active duty for training, or inactive duty training

searchDocs.title: Multi-sentence items​
searchDocs.content: Here's what you'll need to apply:  A Social Security number for you, your spouse, and qualified dependents.Your military discharge information. If you sign in, we may fill this in automatically.

searchDocs.title: Links in lists​
searchDocs.content: List items can be links in specific contextsNot all items require linkingIf all items link, keep under 7 items totalEntire list item must be a link, not individual words

searchDocs.title: Purpose​
searchDocs.content: Alt text ensures all users receive equivalent information regardless of how they access content. Key beneficiaries include:  Individuals using screen readers who are blind or have low visionUsers with low bandwidth who disable image loadingSearch engine optimization benefits

searchDocs.title: When alt text is required​
searchDocs.content: Provide alt text unless an image serves purely decorative purposes. Images require alt text when they:  Convey important contextual informationFunction as clickable links directing to additional resources

searchDocs.title: Five core guidelines for quality alt text​
1. Describe meaningfully​
searchDocs.content: Convey what viewers need to know from the visual, considering surrounding page context.

searchDocs.title: 2. Stay concise​
searchDocs.content: Aim for no more than 150 characters to maintain focus on essential details.

searchDocs.title: 3. Avoid redundancy​
searchDocs.content: Don't repeat information already present in nearby text.

searchDocs.title: 4. Skip technical descriptors​
searchDocs.content: Omit phrases like "image of" or "photo of" since screen readers already identify graphics.

searchDocs.title: 5. Exclude file names​
searchDocs.content: File names provide no useful information and create confusion.

searchDocs.title: Privacy considerations​
searchDocs.content: Critical restriction Don't include Personally Identifiable Information (PII) or Protected Health Information (PHI) in alt text for interactive images.  Rationale: Interactive image interactions are logged in analytics systems, risking exposure of sensitive information.  Example scenario: X-ray images labeled with specific body parts and injuries expose PHI through alt text and analytics tracking.

searchDocs.title: Purpose​
searchDocs.content: This guide establishes house style standards for VA.gov, enabling the organization to speak with one voice and create a consistent, helpful experience for all users.

searchDocs.title: Key guidance resources​
searchDocs.content: The style guide is built on two foundational elements:  Content principles - These establish the voice and tone used across VA.gov, grounded in how the organization communicates for and with Veterans in mind Plain language and web best practices - The guide emphasizes these standards, with specific callouts for areas where VA.gov diverges from conventional practices

searchDocs.title: What's covered​
searchDocs.content: The guide addresses common writing issues specific to VA.gov, but explicitly excludes basic grammar and mechanics. For topics not covered, the guide directs users to:  AP StyleMerriam-Webster DictionaryVA Office of Public and Intergovernmental Affairs style guide

searchDocs.title: Organization​
searchDocs.content: The guide is organized into searchable topic sections covering areas like abbreviations, error messages, form labels, health content, and plain language standards.

searchDocs.title: Contact​
searchDocs.content: Questions can be directed to vawebdesign@va.gov with "Content style guide" in the subject line.

searchDocs.title: Formatting rules​
searchDocs.content: Case: Use sentence case (except for Button - Icon)Length: Keep labels under 35 characters; prioritize brevityAction-oriented: Employ recognizable action verbs that clearly communicate outcomesStructure: Make every label action-focused

searchDocs.title: Writing guidelines​
searchDocs.content: Do this "Create an account""File a complaint"  Not this "Get started""Complaint filing"

searchDocs.title: Privacy considerations​
searchDocs.content: Button text must avoid Personally Identifiable Information (PII) or Protected Health Information (PHI) when possible.  Important limitation When PII/PHI appears in button text, click event tracking becomes unavailable. This protection prevents sensitive information from appearing in analytics or logs.  Teams should either:  Redesign button language to exclude sensitive data, orImplement alternative data collection methods

searchDocs.title: When to use bold​
searchDocs.content: Appropriate uses include:  Setup lines before lists: Text like "Both of these must be true" preceding bullet pointsConjunctions in lists: The "and" or "or" at the end of bulleted itemsSentence openers: First parts of sentences requiring emphasis for scannability, especially when describing different eligibility categoriesKey numerals: Dollar figures and numbers Veterans specifically seekAccount types: References to "Login.gov, My HealtheVet, DS Logon, and ID.me"Note/Example labels: When introducing notes or examplesUI instructions: Design elements or buttons users should select (e.g., "Select File menu")Label-value pairs: Labels in contact information sections, separated by line breaks

searchDocs.title: When NOT to use bold​
searchDocs.content: Avoid bolding in these situations:  Text within hyperlinks (blue color and underlining provide sufficient distinction)Words emphasizing points (like "only if")Subheadings (use H3 or H4 tags instead for proper screen reader navigation)

searchDocs.title: Punctuation rules​
searchDocs.content: Introductory bold: Bold the colon or period following it (e.g., "Note:")Full sentences: Bold all punctuation within and at the sentence endPartial sentences: Don't bold trailing punctuation outside the bolded phrase

searchDocs.title: Italic text​
searchDocs.content: warning Avoid using italics entirely. Screen display quality and readability make italics problematic for web content.

searchDocs.title: Abbreviations​
searchDocs.content: Abbreviations are avoided on VA.gov except in specific contexts:  Common time references (a.m./p.m.)Titles before names (Mr., Mrs., Dr.)Degree credentials (Ph.D., M.D.)Space-limited formats like callout boxes or alerts may use abbreviated days and months  When uncertain, consult the AP Stylebook.

searchDocs.title: Standard practice​
searchDocs.content: First mention in body copy should present the full term followed by the acronym in parentheses. Subsequent references use only the acronym.  Examples:  Initial: "Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance Traumatic Injury Protection (TSGLI)"Later: "TSGLI"

searchDocs.title: Page titles and meta tags exception​
searchDocs.content: When character limits or scannability concerns arise in H1 headers or meta title tags, acronyms alone are acceptable. The spelled-out term should appear in the first body mention.  tip Veterans' familiarity matters—prioritize the term users recognize best and search for most frequently, especially in headers.

searchDocs.title: Internal acronyms​
searchDocs.content: Never use internal VA office acronyms on external-facing pages. Always spell out full office names to prevent confusion, as multiple offices sometimes share identical acronyms.  Example: OCC could refer to:  Office of Community CareOffice of Corporate CommunicationsOffice of Connected Care  Per AP Stylebook: "Names not commonly before the public should not be reduced to acronyms solely to save a few words."

searchDocs.title: Where to apply sentence case​
searchDocs.content: Page titlesHeadings and subheadingsButton labelsText linksMobile app interface buttons  Example: "Apply now for GI Bill benefits"  Avoid capitalizing common words merely for emphasis or visual importance.

searchDocs.title: Exceptions: Title capitalization​
searchDocs.content: Capitalize the following:  Proper nouns: branded terms like "VA.gov," official program names, state names, federal agency names, days of the week, monthsThe word "Veterans" (always capitalized)Global navigation labels: VA Benefits and Health Care; About VA; Find a VA LocationMobile app native actions: Use title case for iOS; use all caps for Android

searchDocs.title: Exceptions: Initial capitalization​
searchDocs.content: SEO title tags employ initial capitalization (example: "VA Prescription Refill And Tracking | Veterans Affairs")

searchDocs.title: Reference resources​
searchDocs.content: For uncertain cases, consult:  The VA.gov content style guide word listAP Style guidelines  When in doubt, default to sentence case capitalization.

searchDocs.title: Better content, not better bureaucracy​
searchDocs.content: The primary goal is enabling consistent, clear, and customer-centered content without adding unnecessary bureaucratic layers.

searchDocs.title: Four defining characteristics of better content​
1. Consistent​
searchDocs.content: Use words uniformly to build trust and confidence with customers.

searchDocs.title: 2. Conversational​
searchDocs.content: Employ everyday language and plain speech rather than government jargon.

searchDocs.title: 3. Clear and helpful​
searchDocs.content: Break complex information into digestible pieces, delivered progressively at appropriate moments to prevent overwhelming users.

searchDocs.title: 4. Empathetic​
searchDocs.content: Communicate person-to-person with customers, prioritizing the individual over their circumstances.

searchDocs.title: Practical examples​
searchDocs.content: Do this "If you limit consent, it may take us longer to get your records. Your doctor will follow the limits you specify."  Not this "The attending physician will abide by the limitation the Veteran specifies. If the Veteran opts to limit consent, please note it may take longer for VA to receive the Veteran's records."  Do this "Accept the terms of use to sign in."  Not this "Unless you accept the terms of use, you will not be able to sign in."

searchDocs.title: Foundation in user research​
searchDocs.content: These principles derive directly from Veteran feedback. Research participants expressed preferences for:  Manageable information deliveryConsistent intuitive labelingGenuine empathy over formalityCustomer service standards matching commercial online experiences

searchDocs.title: General rules​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses
searchDocs.content: Spell out dates in body copy, using the full construction: March 31, 1989Write date ranges using complete sentence structure: "December 1, 2025, to December 31, 2025"Add commas after years in full date construction, except at sentence endSpell out days of the week and months in body copy

searchDocs.title: Abbreviated formats​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses
searchDocs.content: Space-constrained areas allow abbreviations:  Days: Mon., Tue., Wed., Thu., Fri., Sat., Sun.Months: Jan., Feb., Aug., Sept., Oct., Nov., Dec. (March, April, May, June, July remain full)Form fields use mm/dd/yyyy formatUse hyphens without spaces for limited-space date ranges

searchDocs.content: Use "9/11" only in program names like Post-9/11 GI BillDecades use no apostrophe: "the early 2000s" not "2000's"
