searchDocs.title: Formatting standards​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses
searchDocs.content: Write out times, using a.m. and p.m. with periods: 9:00 a.m.Spell out noon and midnight. Don't use 12:00 p.m. or 12:00 a.m.Include minutes even for hour markersOffice hours always reference ET timezone

searchDocs.title: International and local usage​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses
searchDocs.content: International zones use country names or UTC offsetsUser-facing timestamps show local time zonesBody copy uses sentence construction: "9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. ET"Limited space uses hyphens without surrounding spaces

searchDocs.title: Incorrect examples​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses
searchDocs.content: ❌ 8 a.m. (missing minutes)❌ from 8:00 a.m. to noon ET (redundant construction)

searchDocs.title: Phone numbers​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses

searchDocs.title: Formatting requirements​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses
searchDocs.content: Use hyphens between number groups: 212-123-1234Include "+1" only for international contextsExtensions format: "202-123-1234, ext. 9"TTY format: "866-440-1238 (TTY: 711)"Always include operation hours with phone numbers

searchDocs.title: Linking and accessibility​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses
searchDocs.content: Hyperlink entire phone numbers and TTY informationDon't link preceding verbs like "call" or "text"Avoid vanity numbers in body copy for accessibilityException: marketing/promotional components may use "877-222-VETS (8387)"

searchDocs.title: Correct example​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses
searchDocs.content: "Call us toll free at 800-827-1000 (TTY: 711). We're here Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. ET."

searchDocs.title: Fax numbers​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses
searchDocs.content: Never hyperlink or add aria labelsClarify in surrounding text that it's a fax number  Example: "If you're in the U.S., fax your application to 1-844-531-7818."

searchDocs.title: Addresses​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses

searchDocs.title: Street names​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses
searchDocs.content: Write out street names (street, road, avenue, boulevard, highway, etc.)Don't abbreviateFollow local conventions for compass points (N, S, E, W)

searchDocs.title: Correct format​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses
searchDocs.content: 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW Washington, DC 20500 123 E. 45th Street New York, NY 67890

searchDocs.title: Zip codes​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Dates, times, phone numbers, and addresses
searchDocs.content: Require only 5-digit codes from Veterans in formsWhen providing addresses, include extended codes with hyphens: 12345-6789Don't use periods in "PO Box"

searchDocs.title: Content standards​
searchDocs.content: Adhere to VA's plain language style guide principlesUse "you" when addressing recipients and "we" when referring to VAApply existing content patterns where applicableReference the top 10 plain language standardsLeverage VA Notify templates for form submission status emails

searchDocs.title: Privacy protection​
searchDocs.content: Obtain privacy officer approval for all new or updated notificationsDo not include Veterans' personally identifiable information (PII) or protected health information (PHI) in notificationsException: PII/PHI may be included only with explicit Veteran opt-in and documented privacy officer approval

searchDocs.title: Subject lines​
searchDocs.content: Length: Maximum 9 words and 60 charactersAction-oriented emails: Begin with action verbs Example: "Review your dependent information for VA benefits" Reminders/confirmations: Use brief phrases Example: "VA appointment reminder" Post-submission failures: Prefix with "Action needed" Example: "Action needed: We couldn't process your VA form"

searchDocs.title: Salutation and closing​
searchDocs.content: Personalize with first name only: "Dear ((first_name)),"Omit closing signatureDo not include "Thank you for your service"

searchDocs.title: Heading structure​
searchDocs.content: H1: Match subject line exactly or provide slightly expanded versionH2-H4: Support content chunking and accessibility

searchDocs.title: Primary action links​
searchDocs.content: Begin with action verbs; include purpose and destinationInclude "on VA.gov" when linking to VA websiteExample: "Submit your disability claim on VA.gov"Limit to one primary Action Link per emailAvoid "Click here" phrasingAvoid generic terms like "Learn more" without context

searchDocs.title: Secondary links​
searchDocs.content: Reserve for additional resources, FAQs, contact informationMaximum 3 links per email bodyApply general VA link guidance

searchDocs.title: Formatting elements​
searchDocs.content: Bulleted lists:  Break up paragraph contentFollow VA design system styling  Bolded text:  Emphasize important information onlyDo not use for hierarchy (use headings instead)  Dividers:  Create visual separation between topic changesUse to separate footer from main contentAvoid between closely-positioned items  Blockquote component:  Display confirmation numbers, appointment dates, key detailsLimit to one per emailAlign data field labels with confirmation screensSupport Action Links within blockquotes

searchDocs.title: Contact section​
searchDocs.content: Default heading: "Have questions?"Default content: "Visit va.gov or call 800-827-1000 (TTY: 711). We're here Monday-Friday, 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. ET"Customizable as neededOmit if already referenced in body content

searchDocs.title: Footer​
searchDocs.content: Explain delivery reason and instruct against repliesExample: "You're receiving this email because you submitted a form on VA.gov. Don't reply to this email."

searchDocs.title: Site-wide scheduled maintenance​
searchDocs.content: Component: Alert box (Warning state)  Example Site maintenance We're working on VA.gov right now. We expect to finish our work by [DATE] at [TIME] ET.

searchDocs.title: Unexpected site unavailability​
searchDocs.content: Example VA.gov isn't working right now We're sorry. Something went wrong on our end. Please check back soon.

searchDocs.title: Application or tool maintenance​
searchDocs.content: Example [APPLICATION NAME] is down for maintenance We're making updates to [APPLICATION NAME]. We're sorry it's not working right now. Please check back later.

searchDocs.title: Partial page or application access​
searchDocs.content: Component: Alert box (Warning state)  Example Some parts of this page may not be working We're sorry. Something went wrong on our end. Some parts of this page may not be working right now. Please try again later.

searchDocs.title: Component-level issues​
searchDocs.content: Provide component-specific messaging with refresh or retry options.

searchDocs.title: Automated task failures​
searchDocs.content: Example We couldn't save your form We're sorry. We couldn't save your form. Please try again.

searchDocs.title: Page or application loading failures​
searchDocs.content: Example We can't load this page right now Please check your internet connection and try again.

searchDocs.title: Form save failures during connection loss​
searchDocs.content: Example We couldn't save your form Please check your internet connection. Then try saving your form again.

searchDocs.title: User-initiated task failures​
searchDocs.content: Recommend retry actions and provide appropriate alert components.

searchDocs.title: Records not found​
searchDocs.content: Example We couldn't find any records for you We searched all available records and couldn't find any matching your information. If you think this is an error, call us at 800-698-2411 (TTY: 711). We're here Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET.

searchDocs.title: User ineligibility for benefits​
searchDocs.content: Example You're not eligible for this benefit Our records show that you're not currently eligible for [BENEFIT NAME]. If you think this is an error, call us at 800-698-2411 (TTY: 711).

searchDocs.title: Non-enrollment in specific benefits​
searchDocs.content: Example You're not enrolled in [BENEFIT NAME] To use this tool, you'll need to enroll in [BENEFIT NAME] first. [Learn how to enroll]

searchDocs.title: Non-VA-patient status access restrictions​
searchDocs.content: Example You're not currently registered as a VA patient To use this tool, you'll need to be registered as a VA patient. Call us at 800-698-2411 (TTY: 711) to learn more.

searchDocs.title: Empty state​
searchDocs.content: When no data exists for a particular type:  Example We don't have any [DATA TYPE] for you in our system If you think this is an error, call us at 800-698-2411 (TTY: 711).

searchDocs.title: Design standards​
searchDocs.content: Components: Use Alert boxes (warning or error states) or plain text as appropriatePlacement: Position below title, above page title, or replace affected componentsTone: Be apologetic, clear, and action-oriented with CTAs when appropriate

searchDocs.title: Advance notification​
searchDocs.content: Use "Upcoming site maintenance" messaging that specifies the duration and affected capabilities.  Example Upcoming site maintenance We'll be doing some work on VA.gov on [DATE] between [TIME] and [TIME] ET. During this time, you won't be able to [AFFECTED ACTIONS].

searchDocs.title: 24-hour advance notice​
searchDocs.content: Include specific start and end dates and times.  Example Upcoming site maintenance We'll be doing some work on VA.gov starting on [DATE] at [TIME] ET. We expect the maintenance to last until [DATE] at [TIME] ET. During this time, you won't be able to [AFFECTED ACTIONS].

searchDocs.title: During maintenance​
searchDocs.content: Shift to "Site maintenance" messaging with reassurance.  Example Site maintenance We're working on VA.gov right now. If you have trouble using this site, check back later. We expect to finish our work by [DATE] at [TIME] ET.

searchDocs.title: Site-wide issues​
searchDocs.content: Example VA.gov isn't working right now We're sorry. Something went wrong on our end. Please check back soon.

searchDocs.title: In-app problems​
searchDocs.content: Example [APPLICATION NAME] is down for maintenance We're making some updates to [APPLICATION NAME]. We're sorry it's not working right now. Please check back soon.

searchDocs.title: Partial page or application access​
searchDocs.content: Use a warning alert when some parts of a page aren't working.  Example Some parts of this page may not be working We're sorry. Something went wrong on our end. Some parts of this page may not be working. Please try again later, or check back soon.

searchDocs.title: Claim status updates​
searchDocs.content: Alert users when their claim status has changed.

searchDocs.title: Evidence requests​
searchDocs.content: Notify users when VA needs additional documentation to process their claim.

searchDocs.title: Prefill notifications​
searchDocs.content: For authenticated users, let them know their information has been pre-populated.  Example We've prefilled some of your information We've prefilled some of your information from your account. If you need to make changes, you can edit the information.

searchDocs.title: Work-in-progress save reminders​
searchDocs.content: For unauthenticated users, remind them to sign in to save their progress.  Example Sign in now to save time and save your work in progress If you're signed in to your VA.gov account, we can prefill some of your information. This can save you time. You'll also be able to save your work in progress for up to 60 days.

searchDocs.title: Components and placement​
searchDocs.content: Use Alert components, Maintenance Banners, and Modals with appropriate states (Informational, Warning)Place messages above affected components, within alerts on form introduction pages, or in site-wide banners as appropriate

searchDocs.title: Standardized label categories​
searchDocs.content: The design system provides guidance for form labels organized under the "Ask users for..." pattern section:  Addresses - Guidelines for collecting address informationDates - Standards for date input fieldsEmail address - Rules for email field labelsNames - Conventions for name collection fieldsPhone numbers - Standards for telephone inputSocial Security or VA file number - Guidance for sensitive identifier fields

searchDocs.title: How to access detailed guidance​
searchDocs.content: Each category links to its respective pattern page within the design system, where you'll find specific content considerations, examples, and implementation guidance for that particular form field type.

searchDocs.title: Additional resources​
searchDocs.content: The form labels documentation is part of the broader VA.gov Design System content style guide, which covers error messages, plain language standards, and other content guidelines for federal government forms.

searchDocs.title: First mention​
searchDocs.content: Lead with the form name, followed by the form number in parentheses using "VA Form" prefix:  "Use the Health Benefits Update form (VA Form 10-10EZR) to update your personal, financial, and insurance information."  This approach prioritizes clarity since VA form names tend to be very long and are difficult for readers to scan quickly.

searchDocs.title: Subsequent references​
searchDocs.content: After initial mention, refer to forms by "VA Form" plus the number alone:  "Send the completed VA Form 10-10EZR and any supporting documents to us."  Alternatively, use generic references when context is clear: "Send the completed form and any supporting documents to us."

searchDocs.title: CTA links, headers, and UI elements​
searchDocs.content: In interactive elements, use the form number rather than full name. Ensure the complete form name appears nearby for clarity.  Example:  CTA link text: "Download VA Form 21P-530 (PDF)"Supporting context: "Application for Burial Benefits (VA Form 21P-530)"

searchDocs.title: Exception: Common names​
searchDocs.content: Some forms are known by casual names Veterans recognize. Reference these by the familiar term rather than official designation:  "Find out how to request your military records, including your DD214, through milConnect."  Common exceptions include DD214 (instead of formal title) and DD149/DD293.

searchDocs.title: Key principle​
searchDocs.content: Prioritize Veteran comprehension over strict form nomenclature when balancing formal accuracy with accessibility.

searchDocs.title: Plain language for medical terms​
searchDocs.content: Replace medical jargon with everyday language or explain clinical terms in context.  Do this "high blood pressure" instead of "hypertension""cancer-causing" instead of "carcinogenic"  When Veterans need specific medical terminology their providers use, include the term with a plain language explanation:  Example A traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a sudden jolt to your head that changes the way your brain works.

searchDocs.title: Person-first language​
searchDocs.content: Put the person before their condition to avoid defining individuals by illness or status.  Do this "Veteran with cancer" not "cancer patient""Veteran with diabetes" not "diabetic Veteran""Veteran with higher body weight" not "obese Veteran"  Not this "cancer patient""diabetic Veteran""obese Veteran"

searchDocs.title: Identity-first language exception​
searchDocs.content: Some communities prefer identity-first language (for example, "Deaf Veterans" or "blind Veterans"). Use both approaches to respect individual and community preferences.

searchDocs.title: Destigmatizing language​
searchDocs.content: For detailed guidance on specific health topics, see:  Destigmatizing language for weightDestigmatizing language in substance use

searchDocs.title: Destigmatization and hope​
searchDocs.content: Health content should:  Acknowledge conditions are treatable and manageableUse encouraging languageInclude quotes or stories from people with lived experience when appropriateLink to support communities and advocacy groups  Example Depression is serious but highly treatable. Talk with your health care provider about treatment options.

searchDocs.title: Focus on small, achievable steps​
searchDocs.content: Provide specific, actionable instructionsUse everyday examples and relatable comparisonsExplain benefits of actions clearly  Example Don't lift anything heavier than 10 pounds for the first 2 weeks after surgery. This helps wounds heal faster and reduces bleeding risk. A vacuum cleaner or large garbage bag weighs about 10 pounds.

searchDocs.title: Be realistic​
searchDocs.content: Acknowledge practical barriers like budget constraints rather than assuming behavior change is easy.

searchDocs.title: Simplify numbers​
searchDocs.content: Use comparative language ("1 in 10" vs. "10%")Keep denominators consistent when comparing risksFocus on absolute risk rather than relative risk  Example Studies show eating 50 grams of processed meat daily can increase lifetime colorectal cancer risk from about 5 in 100 to about 6 in 100.

searchDocs.title: Pair risk with action​
searchDocs.content: Always follow risk information with action steps that Veterans can take to reduce risk or protect their health.

searchDocs.title: VA-specific resources​
searchDocs.content: When discussing behavior change, emphasize VA-specific support and programs rather than generic health advice. Brief mentions of VA expertise are appropriate, but keep focus on Veteran needs and available resources.  Example We can help you quit tobacco. Ask your VA health care team about support options or call our tobacco quitline at 855-QUIT-VET (855-784-8838).

searchDocs.title: Related resources​
searchDocs.content: CDC's Everyday Words for Public Health CommunicationNIH Clear Communication GuidelinesHealth.gov's Health Literacy Online Guide

searchDocs.title: Title length​
searchDocs.content: Keep error and alert message titles to approximately 50 characters (including spaces). Titles should align with general page and section title guidelines.

searchDocs.title: Message categories​
searchDocs.content: The VA.gov Design System organizes messages into four types:

searchDocs.title: System messages​
searchDocs.content: Alert users to important system-related issues or statuses initiated by the system rather than user actions.  View system message guidelines

searchDocs.title: Engagement messages​
searchDocs.content: Recommend that users enter or update data. These can be initiated by either the system or another person.  View engagement message guidelines

searchDocs.title: Access messages​
searchDocs.content: Appear when users attempt to access unavailable items such as deleted records or content requiring specific permissions.  View access message guidelines

searchDocs.title: Feedback messages​
searchDocs.content: Respond to user actions, particularly for create, read, update, and delete (CRUD) operations.  View feedback message guidelines

searchDocs.title: Context​
searchDocs.content: These messages primarily appear in interactive experiences including tools, forms, and applications. The visual design and formatting affect how content is presented.  For implementation guidance, see the Help users to recover from errors pattern.  note Message categories are adapted from Salesforce Lightning Design System standards.

searchDocs.content: Use	AvoidMedication for opioid use disorder (MOUD)	Medication-assisted treatment Unsuccessful treatment	Treatment failure Recurrence of use	Relapse Person chose not to complete treatment	Non-compliance

searchDocs.content: Recovery Research Institute's AddictionaryNational Institute on Drug Abuse terminology guide

searchDocs.title: Continuing saved applications​
searchDocs.content: Use when a user has a saved application that's approaching expiration.  Component: Alert box (Informational state)  Example Still want to apply for [BENEFIT NAME]? Your saved application will expire on [DATE]. If you don't submit your application by that date, you'll need to start over. [Continue your application] [Start over]

searchDocs.title: Two-factor authentication setup​
searchDocs.content: Encourage users to set up additional security.  Component: Alert box (Informational state)  Example Want to make your VA.gov account more secure? You can add an optional extra layer of security to your account. This helps make sure that only you can access your account—even if someone gets your password.

searchDocs.title: Work-in-progress for unauthenticated users​
searchDocs.content: Display on form introduction pages to encourage sign-in.  Component: Alert box (Informational state)Location: Form Introduction page  Example Sign in now to save time and save your work in progress When you're signed in to your VA.gov account: We can prefill some of your information to save you timeYou can save your work in progress and come back later to finish filling out your formAfter you submit, you can track the status of your application

searchDocs.title: Prefill notifications for authenticated users​
searchDocs.content: Let signed-in users know their information has been auto-populated.  Component: Alert box (Informational state)  Example We've prefilled some of your information We've prefilled some of your information from your account. If you need to correct anything, you can edit the pre-filled information. When you submit this form, we'll update your information in your account.

searchDocs.title: Autosave confirmation​
searchDocs.content: Display after a form saves successfully.  Component: Alert with background-only styling and iconState: SuccessLocation: After form step button pair  Example Your application has been saved. Your application ID number is [ID NUMBER]. It was last saved on [DATE] at [TIME].

searchDocs.title: Design components​
searchDocs.content: These messages typically use:  Alert boxes in various states (Informational, Success)Progress bars to show completion statusButton pairs for action choicesClear placement within form step pages

searchDocs.title: Form save in progress​
searchDocs.content: State: Success  Example We've saved your information We've saved the information you've entered so far.

searchDocs.title: Form save on exit​
searchDocs.content: State: Success  Example We've saved your in-progress application Your application ID number is [ID NUMBER]. You can continue your application at any time.

searchDocs.title: File upload​
searchDocs.content: State: Success  Example Your file has been uploaded [FILENAME] was successfully uploaded.

searchDocs.title: Form submission​
searchDocs.content: State: Success  Example We've received your application Thank you for submitting your application. We'll review your information and contact you if we need anything else. Your confirmation number is [NUMBER].

searchDocs.title: Deletion​
searchDocs.content: State: Success  Example We've deleted your file [FILENAME] has been removed.

searchDocs.title: Form save failed​
searchDocs.content: State: Error  Example Your form didn't save We're sorry. We couldn't save your form. Please try saving again.

searchDocs.title: General form error​
searchDocs.content: State: Error  Example We need you to start over with this application We're sorry. Something went wrong when you tried to submit your application. You'll need to start over.

searchDocs.title: Submission failure (saveable forms)​
searchDocs.content: State: Error  Example We couldn't submit your application We're sorry. Something went wrong when you tried to submit your application. Please save your application and try again.

searchDocs.title: Submission failure (non-saveable forms)​
searchDocs.content: State: Error  Example We couldn't submit your application We're sorry. Something went wrong when you tried to submit your application. Please start over with this application.

searchDocs.title: File upload failure​
searchDocs.content: State: Error  Example We couldn't upload your file We're sorry. Something went wrong and we couldn't upload your file. Please try again.

searchDocs.title: File download failure​
searchDocs.content: State: Error  Example We couldn't download your file We're sorry. Something went wrong and we couldn't download your file. Please try again.

searchDocs.title: File creation failure​
searchDocs.content: State: Error  Example We couldn't create your file We're sorry. Something went wrong and we couldn't create your file. Please try again.

searchDocs.title: File update failure​
searchDocs.content: State: Error  Example We couldn't update your file We're sorry. Something went wrong and we couldn't update your file. Please try again.

searchDocs.title: File deletion failure​
searchDocs.content: State: Error  Example We couldn't delete your file We're sorry. Something went wrong and we couldn't delete your file. Please try again.

searchDocs.title: Technical specifications​
searchDocs.content: Each message should include:  Element	DescriptionMessage title	Primary text that summarizes the status Message content	Supporting text with additional context Actions	Associated buttons or links for next steps Component type	Usually an Alert box Alert state	Success or Error Location	Where the message appears on the page

searchDocs.title: Related guidance​
searchDocs.content: For guidance on help desk contact information and next-step calls to action, see the Help users to recover from errors pattern.

searchDocs.title: Key principles​
searchDocs.content: Person-first language that doesn't define individuals by conditionsScientific understanding of obesity rather than framing it as a personal failureEmpathetic language that conveys support without judgment

searchDocs.title: Describing people​
searchDocs.content: Use "Person with higher weight""Person with a larger body"  Avoid ObeseMorbidly obeseOverweightChubbyFatHeavy

searchDocs.title: Describing conditions​
searchDocs.content: Use WeightHigher weightUnhealthy weight  Avoid ObesityMorbid obesityFat  note Some communities prefer "fat" as a neutral descriptor. When possible, ask individuals their preferences.

searchDocs.title: Describing people​
searchDocs.content: Use "Person with overweight""Person with obesity""Person with higher weight"

searchDocs.title: Describing conditions​
searchDocs.content: Use WeightHigher weightUnhealthy weightOverweightObesity"Class 3 obesity"  Avoid Fat"Morbid obesity"

searchDocs.title: Example​
searchDocs.content: Do this Overweight and obesity affect 80% of Veterans.  Not this 80% of Veterans are obese.

searchDocs.title: Body mass index (BMI) guidance​
searchDocs.content: Present BMI as one assessment tool, not a standalone health indicator.  Do this Body mass index is one tool providers may use to assess risk.  Not this If you have higher BMI, you're at higher risk.

searchDocs.title: Behavioral language​
searchDocs.content: Use	AvoidConsistent choices forming healthy habits	Discipline, willpower Challenges blocking goals	Excuses Slips or difficult situations	Cheating Triggers or feelings prompting eating	Temptations Progress toward goals	Success Emotional eating responses	Cravings Eating more than planned	Overeating Low-nutrient foods	Junk food, bad food High-nutrient foods	Good food, guilt-free food

searchDocs.title: Avoid images that​
searchDocs.content: Emphasize body parts or show people without facesDepict stereotypical unhealthy behaviorsPresent foods negatively

searchDocs.title: Choose images that​
searchDocs.content: Show diverse activities, roles, and careersFeature diverse backgrounds (gender, age, race/ethnicity)Display people in well-fitted clothing

searchDocs.title: Image selection questions​
searchDocs.content: Before using an image, ask:  Does it reinforce negative stereotypes?Does it maintain the person's dignity?Who might find it offensive and why?Are there better alternatives?

searchDocs.title: Resources​
searchDocs.content: Rudd Center for Food Policy and Health

searchDocs.title: Effective approaches​
searchDocs.content: Use natural, descriptive language that describes both purpose and destinationKeep text concise while highlighting relevant informationInclude "(opens in a new tab)" notation when the link opens in a new window

searchDocs.title: Patterns to avoid​
searchDocs.content: Don't use "Click here" - excludes non-pointing input methodsGeneric phrases like "Learn more" or "Read more" used aloneAbility-assuming words like "See," "Hear," or "Watch"  Example Do this: "File for a VA disability compensation increase" Not this: "Click here to learn more"

searchDocs.title: Formatting standards​
searchDocs.content: Remove punctuation from link text (except question marks and colons if integral to the meaning)Space links adequately for touch-screen usabilityPlace links on separate lines for visual clarity and scannabilityAvoid linking multiple list items to identical destinations

searchDocs.title: URL best practices​
searchDocs.content: Use canonical URLs (the version appearing in search results)For form flows, link to base URL excluding specific page referencesInclude trailing slashes when present in live URLsThis prevents broken links when flows change and improves search indexing

searchDocs.title: File-based links​
searchDocs.content: Minimize PDF links when possibleAdd relevant icons (calendar, video, XLS) from the Design System components when linking to files

searchDocs.title: External site links​
searchDocs.content: Use descriptive text that indicates the destination:  Example Check COVID-19 symptoms on the CDC website  Consider using aria-labels for screen reader-specific context when specialized circumstances require different text for visual and assistive technology users.

searchDocs.title: Privacy requirements​
searchDocs.content: When creating links, you must protect Personally Identifiable Information (PII) and Protected Health Information (PHI):  Avoid PII/PHI in link text (click events cannot be tracked for such links)Cannot pass PII/PHI in URL parameters or destination URLsFile downloads can include only the user's name and download dateGenerate non-PII identifiers for parameters  These restrictions protect user information from analytics tracking and logs.

searchDocs.title: Don't create new brands​
searchDocs.content: Creating branded names causes problems:  Imposes internal terminology on users - Veterans shouldn't need to learn VA's internal vocabularyCreates confusing sub-brands - Multiple branded names fragment the VA experienceRequires expensive marketing - Educating audiences about branded terms takes significant resources

searchDocs.title: Use plain language instead​
searchDocs.content: Rather than inventing branded names, call it what it is using everyday vocabulary that audiences already understand. This approach aligns with content principles and improves discoverability.  Do this "VA combined disability rating calculator""View your electricity bill"  Not this "The Combinator""Pepco Green Button"

searchDocs.title: Avoid acronym branding​
searchDocs.content: Don't create new acronyms in Veteran-facing content that aren't commonly used and understood by them already. Internal shorthand shouldn't appear in customer-facing materials as branded terminology.

searchDocs.title: Related guidance​
searchDocs.content: Check the word list for approved capitalizationsReview content principles for additional context on writing standards

searchDocs.title: Pronoun usage​
searchDocs.content: Use "they" and "their" instead of gendered alternatives like "he or she" or "his or her."  Do this "Learn about how a Veteran can transfer their unused Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits to you.""If your provider has filled out the form electronically, they must print it out to sign it."  Not this "Learn about how a Veteran can transfer his or her unused Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits to you."

searchDocs.title: Family relationships​
searchDocs.content: Use inclusive terms rather than gender-specific ones:  Use	Instead ofSpouse or partner	Husband/wife Child or dependent child	Son/daughter Stepchild	Stepson/stepdaughter Parent	Mother/father  note Backend form fields may require alignment with specific terms based on system requirements.

searchDocs.title: Avoid sensory-based verbs​
searchDocs.content: Don't use "view," "see," "hear," or "listen" since users access content differently.  Use	Instead ofGo to	See Review	View Check	Look at Read	See Play	Listen to

searchDocs.title: Replace interaction-specific terms​
searchDocs.content: Instead of "click," "press," or "tap," use "select" across all platforms.  Example Select Submit Not: "Tap the button" or "Click Submit"

searchDocs.title: Eliminate directional language​
searchDocs.content: Avoid references to screen position (top right, below) because responsive design and accessibility tools affect layout differently for each user.

searchDocs.title: Remove color references​
searchDocs.content: Don't instruct users to select "the blue button." Use the label name instead.

searchDocs.title: Use first-person references​
searchDocs.content: Describe VA as "we/us" rather than naming internal offices (VBA, VHA, NCA). This minimizes jargon unfamiliar to Veterans.

searchDocs.title: Minimize branded program names​
searchDocs.content: Describe the benefit or program rather than its official branded name.

searchDocs.title: Avoid specific staff titles​
searchDocs.content: Unless Veterans need a specific role name to contact the right person, use "We'll review" instead of naming job titles.

searchDocs.title: Use numerals for all numbers​
searchDocs.content: VA.gov differs from AP Style by using numerals for all numbers, including 1-10. Numerals are easier to scan on a screen and help readers with lower literacy levels and non-native English speakers.  Examples "You must meet at least 1 of these eligibility requirements""Get help completing your application, including one-on-one consultation"

searchDocs.title: Exceptions​
searchDocs.content: Spell out "one" in expressions like one-on-one, one-time, and "one of the reasons"Use the numeral "1" in all other instancesSpell out ordinals first through tenth unless in a series or rangeUse 11th, 12th, etc. after tenth  Example All runners-up from 5th to 11th place will receive an honorable mention.

searchDocs.title: Ampersand (&)​
searchDocs.content: Avoid ampersands in headers and body copy. Spell out "and" instead.  Exception: Use ampersands in proper nouns like program names (VR&E program).

searchDocs.title: Dollar sign ($)​
searchDocs.content: Use the dollar sign instead of spelling out "dollars." In tables, add "$" so screen readers interpret it as currency.  Example We'll pay the tuition and mandatory fees up to $27,120.05

searchDocs.title: Degree symbol​
searchDocs.content: Use with specific numbers. No space between the number and symbol or between the symbol and F/C.  Example The temperature was 10°C Not: "10 °C"

searchDocs.title: Percent sign (%)​
searchDocs.content: Use numerals with the % symbol. No space between the number and symbol. This follows scientific and technical writing standards.  Example a disability rating of 10% to 100%

searchDocs.title: Primary functions​
searchDocs.content: Page titles serve two critical purposes:  Clearly and quickly tell people the main purpose of the page - what they can do or what information they can getOptimize the page for search - so the information is findable through Google and other search engines

searchDocs.title: Character limits​
searchDocs.content: Content type	Character limitStandard pages	52 characters (including spaces) Resources and support articles	70 characters News releases, blog titles, community stories, local events	No limit

searchDocs.title: Best practices​
searchDocs.content: Include the primary SEO keyword in the page titleUse H1 tag for page titles on VA.govKeep titles focused on the single main purpose of the page

searchDocs.title: Best practices​
searchDocs.content: Structure with H2s for sections and H3s for subsections, maintaining natural hierarchyFor multiple contact or application options, use "Option [X]:" in the headerKeep section titles under 70 characters (including spaces)Eliminate unnecessary details from titles; address nuance in body copy

searchDocs.title: Example structure​
searchDocs.content: H1: How to apply for college H2: Documents you need before you start your college application H2: Ways to apply to colleges H3: Option 1: Online H3: Option 2: By mail   Headers provide clear guideposts and bring people deeper into the content.

searchDocs.title: Privacy guidance​
searchDocs.content: Page titles (H1s) can include Personally Identifiable Information (PII) or Protected Health Information (PHI), but this information can't be populated or tracked anywhere else.  When including PII/PHI in page titles:  Exclude such information from URLs, parameters, and anchor tagsGenericize corresponding breadcrumb segmentsGenericize title tags to prevent analytics tracking  note This creates an accessibility trade-off. The VA 508 office has approved this approach.

searchDocs.title: 1. Use short sentences​
searchDocs.content: Limit each sentence to one subject and verb when possible.  Do this Apply online for VA health care. You can also apply by mail or in person.  Not this There are several ways you can apply for VA health care, including online, by mail, or in person at a VA medical center.

searchDocs.title: 2. Use simple words and terms​
searchDocs.content: Choose familiar language suited to Veterans and their families.  Do this "get" instead of "obtain""help" instead of "assistance""about" instead of "approximately"

searchDocs.title: 3. Use active voice​
searchDocs.content: Connect actions directly to subjects. Avoid passive constructions lacking clear responsibility.  Do this We'll review your application and send you a decision letter.  Not this Your application will be reviewed and a decision letter will be sent.

searchDocs.title: 4. Define complex terms​
searchDocs.content: When necessary, provide plain language definitions in parentheses or separate sentences immediately following technical terms.  Example You may be eligible for Aid and Attendance benefits. This is an increased monthly pension amount for Veterans who need help with daily activities.

searchDocs.title: 5. Use conversational language​
searchDocs.content: Address the Veteran individually using "you" and "your." Refer to VA as "we" and "our."  Do this We'll send you a letter with our decision.  Not this The Veteran will receive notification of the determination.

searchDocs.title: 6. Use contractions​
searchDocs.content: Employ contractions like "don't" instead of "do not" for a more conversational tone.  Do this "don't" instead of "do not""can't" instead of "cannot""we'll" instead of "we will""you're" instead of "you are"

searchDocs.title: 7. Don't use jargon​
searchDocs.content: Avoid bureaucratic and legal language, and minimize unnecessary acronyms or initialisms.  Do this Your monthly payment  Not this Your monthly monetary allowance disbursement

searchDocs.title: 8. Don't use idioms​
searchDocs.content: Exclude idiomatic expressions that may confuse non-native English speakers.  Do this This will take a long time.  Not this This isn't going to happen overnight.

searchDocs.title: 9. Avoid branded names​
searchDocs.content: Minimize program-specific branding. Describe benefits instead.  Do this educational and career counseling  Not this Chapter 36 Educational and Vocational Counseling

searchDocs.title: 10. Structure your content​
searchDocs.content: Organize information using:  Hierarchical headings (H2s, H3s)Bulleted listsProcess listsAccordions  Avoid dense paragraphs that are difficult to scan.

searchDocs.title: Why plain language matters​
searchDocs.content: Clear communication helps people:  Understand their benefits and eligibilityComplete applications correctly the first timeComply with requirements through clearer instructionsMake informed decisions about their health care and benefits

searchDocs.title: Related standards​
searchDocs.content: Content principlesAbbreviations and acronyms

searchDocs.title: Apostrophes​
searchDocs.content: Use curly apostrophes (don't) instead of straight ones (don't).

searchDocs.title: Commas​
searchDocs.content: Apply the Oxford comma before conjunctions in series of 3 or more items to prevent misreading.  Example We provide health care, education, and housing benefits.

searchDocs.title: Contractions​
searchDocs.content: VA.gov embraces contractions for conversational tone, except in certain legal contexts. Avoid non-standard forms like "would've" or "could've."  Use don'tcan'twe'llyou're

searchDocs.title: Em dashes​
searchDocs.content: Use without spaces on either side to set off important clauses.  Example You may be eligible if you have an illness or injury caused—or made worse—by your time in service.

searchDocs.title: En dashes​
searchDocs.content: Avoid them since screen readers don't announce them consistently.

searchDocs.title: Hyphens​
searchDocs.content: Connect modifying words and names without spacing.  Examples active-duty service memberVA-related claim

searchDocs.title: Exclamation points​
searchDocs.content: Never use in body copy, headers, labels, or CTAs. This aligns with VA.gov's conversational, straightforward voice without hyperbole.

searchDocs.title: Quotation marks​
searchDocs.content: Use curly marks around free-text form submissionsPlace periods and commas inside quotation marksOther punctuation goes outside unless it's part of the quoteDon't quote buttons or headers—use bold instead

searchDocs.title: Form field punctuation​
searchDocs.content: Hint text: Add periods for complete sentences; omit for fragmentsError messages: Skip periods unless 2 or more sentences exist

searchDocs.title: Notes​
searchDocs.content: Place on separate lines after relevant textCapitalize and bold "Note:"For list items, position directly after the specific item with soft returns, maintaining list indentation  Example Note: This requirement applies only to applications submitted after January 1, 2024.

searchDocs.title: Error messages​
searchDocs.content: Use sentence case and bold formattingStart with action verbs ("Select," "Enter")Quote specific form elementsOmit periods unless multiple sentences are present

searchDocs.title: How we develop this guidance​
searchDocs.content: The guidance in this section draws from:  VA content and plain language standardsSearch and analytics research findingsInput from VA subject matter expertsFeedback from Veterans and service members through usability research and surveys

searchDocs.title: What each entry includes​
searchDocs.content: Each topic entry provides:  Considerations for writing about the topicRelated terminology and proper usageObsolete terms and recommended alternativesResources including published examples and research data

searchDocs.title: Key principle​
searchDocs.content: In reusable content that appears in many types of applications, requests, and static pages (like an alert), use the general term "form" instead of "claim," "application," or "request" to avoid confusion.

searchDocs.title: Application / Apply​
searchDocs.content: Used when someone submits an initial request for non-disability benefits. Veterans "apply" for pensions, DIC, and similar benefits.  Example Apply for VA health care benefits.

searchDocs.title: Claim / File a claim​
searchDocs.content: Primarily used for disability filings. Also applies to reimbursement claims and life insurance. Reflects the Veteran's right to compensation.  Example File a claim for disability compensation.

searchDocs.title: Claimant / Applicant​
searchDocs.content: Refers to the person with the claim or the person applying for benefits.  Define as "person with the claim""person applying for this benefit"  Plain language alternatives are preferred when possible. For example, use "Veteran's spouse" instead of "claimant" when referring to a spouse.

searchDocs.title: Claim exam​
searchDocs.content: Determines service-connected disability status and assigns ratings.  First mention VA claim exam (also known as a compensation and pension, or C&P, exam)

searchDocs.title: Document​
searchDocs.content: The digital or paper item submitted as evidence supporting a claim or application.

searchDocs.title: Evidence​
searchDocs.content: All documents and information submitted to support a claim or application.  Define as supporting documents or information

searchDocs.title: File (noun)​
searchDocs.content: The actual uploaded file from a user's device (.pdf, .jpg, .png, etc.). Upload buttons should read "Upload file."

searchDocs.title: Request​
searchDocs.content: A formal ask for action or an item—such as requesting a decision review or Presidential Memorial Certificate. Typically doesn't require explaining eligibility.  Example Request a decision review if you disagree with our decision.

searchDocs.title: Sponsor​
searchDocs.content: The Veteran whose earned benefits a family member accesses.  Define as the Veteran you're connected to (called your "sponsor")

searchDocs.title: When to use each term​
searchDocs.content: Term	Use forApply / Application	Non-disability benefits (health care, pension, education, DIC) Claim / File a claim	Disability compensation, reimbursement, life insurance Request	Decision reviews, certificates, records, specific items Form	Reusable content that appears across multiple benefit types

searchDocs.title: Implementation note​
searchDocs.content: Existing VA.gov content may not yet reflect these standards. Apply these guidelines when creating new content or updating existing content.

searchDocs.title: Key considerations​
searchDocs.content: Two principles guide all debt-related messaging:  Help availability: Communications should emphasize that support exists through repayment plans and relief optionsTimely action: Messaging should stress the 30-day window to avoid late fees and collection action

searchDocs.title: Balance​
searchDocs.content: The remaining amount owed on a debt or copay obligation. Primarily used within online debt portals.

searchDocs.title: Benefit overpayment​
searchDocs.content: When VA disburses excess funds for disability, education, or pension benefits. Use "benefit overpayment" on first mention; shorten to "overpayment" thereafter.  Example You have a benefit overpayment. This overpayment happened because...

searchDocs.title: Compromise offer​
searchDocs.content: A debt relief option allowing Veterans to propose a lump-sum settlement for less than the full amount owed.

searchDocs.title: Copay / Copayment​
searchDocs.content: A fixed amount you owe for a health care service. Define on first mention in general contexts.  Example A copay (or copayment) is the fixed amount you pay for a health care service.

searchDocs.title: Copay bill / Patient statement​
searchDocs.content: Documentation of health care charges. Define initially with plain language explanations.

searchDocs.title: Debt​
searchDocs.content: The overarching term for any funds owed to VA. Encompasses both overpayments and copays.

searchDocs.title: Debt relief​
searchDocs.content: VA assistance options including waivers, compromises, and repayment arrangements.

searchDocs.title: Monthly offset​
searchDocs.content: When VA retains benefit payments to reduce overpayment debt.

searchDocs.title: Outstanding debt​
searchDocs.content: Current unpaid obligations. Used in MyVA and mobile app headers.

searchDocs.title: Payment history​
searchDocs.content: Record of VA disbursements to Veterans.

searchDocs.title: Repay / Pay​
searchDocs.content: Use "repay" for overpayment obligationsUse "pay" for copay bills"Make a payment" works for both

searchDocs.title: Repayment plan​
searchDocs.content: A monthly payment arrangement option available for both overpayment and copay debt.

searchDocs.title: Waiver (debt forgiveness)​
searchDocs.content: A request to forgive full or partial debt obligations. Include the parenthetical "(debt forgiveness)" on first mention.  Example You can request a waiver (debt forgiveness) if you can't afford to pay your debt.

searchDocs.title: Write-off​
searchDocs.content: A cancellation request option for copay debt only. Not available for overpayments.

searchDocs.title: Retired terminology​
searchDocs.content: Don't use	Use insteadBenefit debt	Overpayment  "Benefit debt" was replaced with "overpayment" as less stigmatizing language.

searchDocs.title: Account provider emphasis​
searchDocs.content: The guidance prioritizes encouraging Login.gov accounts while supporting ID.me as alternatives. Both should be referred to as "account types" rather than separate tools.

searchDocs.title: Bolding convention​
searchDocs.content: Bold account type names when referencing them: Login.gov, ID.me, DS Logon, and My HealtheVet.  Example You can use your Login.gov account to access VA benefits and services.  Not this You can use Login.gov to access VA benefits and services.

searchDocs.title: Benefit-focused messaging​
searchDocs.content: Communications should emphasize Veteran advantages (fraud prevention, information protection) rather than VA's security obligations.

searchDocs.title: Account / Sign-in account​
searchDocs.content: Describes the authentication mechanism Veterans use to access VA services.  Don't use "VA.gov account""VA account""credential"

searchDocs.title: Account provider​
searchDocs.content: References Login.gov and ID.me as verification service suppliers.  Don't use "sign-in partner""service provider"

searchDocs.title: Identity verification​
searchDocs.content: Describes the one-time initial verification process.  First mention verify your identity for your account  Subsequent mentions verify  Don't apply to Routine sign-insMultifactor authenticationLOROTA processes

searchDocs.title: Identity-verified account​
searchDocs.content: Use on initial reference, then shorten to verified account thereafter.

searchDocs.title: Multifactor authentication​
searchDocs.content: The ongoing security process during sign-in. This is distinct from identity verification.

searchDocs.title: My HealtheVet​
searchDocs.content: Two words with a lowercase "e." The "e" is only italicized in the logo and print materials, not in digital body copy.

searchDocs.title: Security standards​
searchDocs.content: Use "meets modern security standards" when describing providers.

searchDocs.title: Sign in / Sign out​
searchDocs.content: The preferred terminology for authentication actions.  Don't use "log in" / "log out""sign on"

searchDocs.title: Retired terminology​
searchDocs.content: Don't use	Use instead2-factor authentication	multifactor authentication My HealtheVet basic/advanced/Premium	My HealtheVet account (with security level specification if needed) Sign-in partner / service provider	account provider

searchDocs.title: Related resources​
searchDocs.content: Signing in to VA.govCreating an account for VA.govVerifying your identity on VA.gov

searchDocs.title: Why we use they/their​
searchDocs.content: Using "they" and "their" eliminates unnecessary wordiness while remaining inclusive. This recommendation aligns with The New Fowler's Modern English Language (third edition) and Garner's Modern American Usage (third edition).

searchDocs.title: Examples​
searchDocs.content: Do this "Learn about how a Veteran can transfer their unused Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits to you.""If your provider has filled out the form electronically, they must print it out to sign it."  Not this "Learn about how a Veteran can transfer his or her unused Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits to you.""If your provider has filled out the form electronically, he or she must print it out to sign it."

searchDocs.title: Related guidance​
searchDocs.content: Neutral languageWe, us, you

searchDocs.title: Standard format​
searchDocs.content: Most pages: H1/Page Title | Veterans Affairs  Capitalization: Use initial caps (for example, "Find A Form" not "Find a form")

searchDocs.title: Character limits and truncation​
searchDocs.content: Benefit hub pages maintain a 70-character maximum (including spaces) to display fully in search results. When H1s exceed this, they're truncated in the meta title tag while preserving "| Veterans Affairs" at the end.  Other content types (news releases, resources) don't have character limits.

searchDocs.title: Exception 1: VA Medical Centers​
searchDocs.content: Format: H1 Page Title | VAMC Plain Language System Name | Veterans Affairs  Examples Psychology Internships And Fellowships | VA Pittsburgh Health Care | Veterans Affairs  No character limit appliedUses plain language VAMC system names

searchDocs.title: Exception 2: Forms and subtasks​
searchDocs.content: Title tags may differ from H1s for clarity when users have multiple forms open.  Examples "Income Limits | Veterans Affairs" (not "What's Your Address")"Apply For VA Health Care | Veterans Affairs" (not "Form 10-10ez")

searchDocs.title: Privacy requirements​
searchDocs.content: Title tags cannot include Personally Identifiable Information (PII) or Protected Health Information (PHI). Authenticated pages with specific personal data in H1s must use genericized title tags to prevent tracking sensitive information in analytics.  Example H1: Prednisone, 25mg Title tag: Medication detail - Medications | Veterans Affairs  The VA 508 office approved this approach despite creating non-unique title tags, since no meaningful differentiating data exists that wouldn't expose sensitive information.

searchDocs.title: First mention only​
searchDocs.content: Include the trademark symbol (®) in the first prominent mention, only once and only on the relevant section of the website.

searchDocs.title: Restricted placement​
searchDocs.content: Avoid using trademark symbols in:  LinksButtonsBreadcrumbsNavigation labels

searchDocs.title: Example: GI Bill​
searchDocs.content: The GI Bill® serves as an example. The trademark symbol appears on the Education and training hub landing page as the primary location.  If no suitable spot exists on a hub page, place it instead on the specific benefits page (such as "About the GI Bill benefits"), but not in both locations.  When mentioning the GI Bill on unrelated pages—disability, careers, pension sections—the symbol should be omitted.

searchDocs.title: Context​
searchDocs.content: There's no specific legal guidance for VA trademarks, but we follow this general practice on the web as a best practice rather than a legal requirement.

searchDocs.title: Related guidance​
searchDocs.content: Word list - for specific trademark styling

searchDocs.title: Recommended approach​
searchDocs.content: Example We offer a variety of health services and VA benefits to meet your needs. For additional contact information, view our phone directory.  This demonstrates conversational tone by combining organizational perspective with direct audience address.

searchDocs.title: Identifying your audience​
searchDocs.content: When clarity requires it, identify the specific audience before or alongside using second-person language:  Example If you're a dependent family member of a Veteran or service member, you can get career and educational counseling through VR&E.  This maintains direct address while specifying which group the content targets.

searchDocs.title: What to avoid​
searchDocs.content: Don't do this Third-person references to audiences: "Veterans may also view..."Organizational references that create distance: "VA encourages Veterans to..."  These patterns undermine the conversational, person-centered communication style.

searchDocs.title: Core principle​
searchDocs.content: Direct, inclusive language strengthens connection with users by treating them as conversation partners rather than subjects being discussed.

searchDocs.title: Related guidance​
searchDocs.content: They, theirNeutral languageContent principles

searchDocs.title: A​
searchDocs.content: Accredited representative: Define as "a trained professional trusted to help with VA-related claims" on first mention.  Active duty: Use lowercase. Hyphenate when modifying nouns (active-duty service member).  Agent Orange: Define as "a toxic chemical used to clear trees and plants during the war" on first mention.  And/or: Avoid this construction. Restructure to list all options separately.  Appeal option: Use this term on Board Appeal forms. Avoid using "lane."  Apply vs. file: Use "apply" for non-disability benefits (apply for health care). Use "file" for disability claims.  Armed Forces: Capitalize. Consists of 6 service branches.  Asbestos: Define as "toxic fibers, once used in many buildings and products" on first mention.

searchDocs.title: B​
searchDocs.content: Beneficiary: In life insurance contexts, define as "the person you choose to receive your insurance proceeds."  Benefit office: Use "regional office" instead.  Board of Veterans' Appeals: Note the plural possessive "Veterans'" styling.

searchDocs.title: C​
searchDocs.content: Can vs. may: Use "can" for ability. Use "may" for permission.  Caregiver: Preferred over "caretaker." Avoid labeling family members solely as caregivers.  Claim exam: Use "VA claim exam (also known as a compensation and pension, or C&P, exam)" on first mention.  Compensation: Pair terms as "disability compensation (pay)" to balance plain language with SEO value.  Condition vs. disability: Veterans have service-connected "conditions" until receiving a rating, then they become "disabilities."  Continuous: Define as "all at once, without a break in service" when discussing eligibility.

searchDocs.title: D​
searchDocs.content: Decision notice: Interchangeable with "decision letter" depending on business line usage.  Defense Department (DOD): Capitalize "D" in Department. Use "Defense Department" on first mention, then DOD.  Delete: Use instead of "remove" for file management actions.  Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (DIC): Capitalize. Note "Dependency" is singular.  Disability rating: Define as "a rating that measures how severe a disability is."  Disease: Use "illness" instead unless part of a proper disease name.

searchDocs.title: E​
searchDocs.content: Education: Use as a noun generally (education benefits, not educational benefits).  Educational: Use in specific phrases like "educational assistance," "educational institution," and "educational program."  Email: One word without hyphenation (not e-mail).  Employment handicap: Include definition explaining it limits ability to prepare for and maintain employment.  Evidence: Define as "supporting documents, like a doctor's report or medical test results."  Expedite/expedited: Replace with plain language like "faster," "quicker," or "speed up."

searchDocs.title: F​
searchDocs.content: Family member: Use instead of "beneficiary" whenever possible for more human-centered language.  File a claim: Use for disability compensation. Use "apply" for other benefits.  Financial hardship: Define as "having trouble paying for basic needs, like food and housing."

searchDocs.title: G​
searchDocs.content: Gender diverse: No hyphenation required.  GI: No periods (not G.I.).  GI Bill®: Include trademark symbol in first prominent mention.  GI Bill Comparison Tool: Treat complete name as proper noun. Use lowercase "tool" when referencing generically.  Gravesite: Style as one word.  Guarantee vs. guaranty: Use "guarantee" as verb. Use "guaranty" as noun in legal contexts.  Guard member: Gender-neutral preferred term over Guardsman/Guardsmen.  Gulf War illness: Capitalize "Illness." Reference former term "Gulf War Syndrome" for clarity when needed.

searchDocs.title: H​
searchDocs.content: Health care: Two words, never hyphenated as compound adjective.  Higher-Level Review decision: Lowercase "decision." Veterans "request" rather than "apply for."  Home loan: No hyphen even as adjective (home loan benefits).  Housebound allowance: Lowercase "allowance."

searchDocs.title: I​
searchDocs.content: Illegal: Avoid. Use "not allowed by law" instead. Never use to describe a person.  Illness: Preferred term over "disease" except in proper disease names.  Individual Unemployability: Capitalize as VA term. Define related "individually unemployable" (lowercase).  Intent to file: Lowercase in most cases. Avoid phrase "file your intent to file."

searchDocs.title: K​
searchDocs.content: Korean Demilitarized Zone (DMZ): Proper styling for this geographic reference.

searchDocs.title: L​
searchDocs.content: LGBTQ+: Include the plus sign in all instances.  Life insurance: Don't hyphenate in compound adjective form (life insurance coverage).  Loan guaranty agent/Loan technician: Lowercase these titles.  Log in/Log out: Use "sign in/sign out" or "username and password" instead.

searchDocs.title: M​
searchDocs.content: Manufacturing: Use "making" for plain language alternative.  Military occupation code (MOC): Proper styling for this acronym.  MISSION Act: Use "VA MISSION Act." Avoid full legislative title.  Mobile phone: Preferred term over "cell phone."  Montgomery GI Bill: Includes Active Duty (MGIB-AD) and Selected Reserve (MGIB-SR) variants.  Multifactor authentication (MFA): One word, no hyphen. Preferred over "2-factor authentication."  My HealtheVet: Don't italicize the "e" in body copy. Italicize only in logo.

searchDocs.title: N​
searchDocs.content: National Guard: Can also use shortened "Guard."  Native American Direct Loan (NADL): Lowercase "direct loan."  Note/Exception: Bold these callout terms with colon following. Never use all caps.  Number: Spell out. Don't abbreviate to "No." or "#."

searchDocs.title: O​
searchDocs.content: Original claim: Define as "your first claim for disability compensation."

searchDocs.title: P​
searchDocs.content: PACT Act: Use alone. Full title references SFC Heath Robinson HONORING our Promise to Address Comprehensive Toxics Act.  Patient: Use "person living with [condition]" instead.  Percent: Use symbol (%) rather than spelling out for scannability.  Period of honorable service: Don't use "honorable period of service."  Permanent disability: Define as "a disability that's not expected to improve."  Please: Move away from default usage. Employ only when specifically needed.  PO Box: No periods required.  Post-9/11: Hyphenate. Use slash for date (not hyphen).  Power of attorney (POA): Capitalized. Consult subject matter experts before using.  PTSD: Full term "posttraumatic stress disorder" (no hyphen) with acronym in parentheses on first mention. Use acronym alone after.

searchDocs.title: R​
searchDocs.content: Regional office: Use instead of "regional benefit office."  Required by law/Not allowed by law: Preferred terms for legal requirements.  Retroactive: Provide contextual definition when used.  Review option: Veterans select from Supplemental Claim, Board Appeal, or Higher-Level Review.

searchDocs.title: S​
searchDocs.content: Secondary service-connected claim: Define as "a claim for a new disability linked to existing service-connected disability."  Service connected: Hyphenate when modifying noun. No hyphen otherwise.  Service-connected condition: Define as "illness or injury caused—or made worse by—active-duty service."  Service member: Two words, lowercase (except in branded program names like Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance).  Sign in/Sign out: Use instead of "log in/log out" or "sign on."  Smartphone: Use when specifically referencing internet-capable mobile phone.  Social Security number: Lowercase "number."  Sponsor: Define as "the Veteran you're connected to."  Statement of the Case: Capitalize.  Substantially gainful employment: Define as "steady job that supports you financially."  Suicide: Ask "Are you thinking of hurting yourself or others?" rather than asking about suicide directly.  Supplemental Claim: Veterans "file" (not "request") this claim type.  Survivors Pension: Capitalize. No apostrophe in "Survivors."

searchDocs.title: T​
searchDocs.content: Terminal illness: Define as "a condition that can't be treated" when used in eligibility context.  Total disability: Define as "rated as 100% disabling."  Trauma: Define as "an injury or deeply disturbing experience."

searchDocs.title: U​
searchDocs.content: Uniformed Services: Refers to Armed Forces plus NOAA and Public Health Service.  Upload: Use instead of "add" for file management.  User: Avoid term. Use "Veterans" or "people" instead.

searchDocs.title: V​
searchDocs.content: VA: Don't precede with "the" when used as noun. Use with article when functioning as adjective.  VA.gov: Brand name. Always capitalize "VA." Don't use "www.va.gov."  VA medical center: Don't shorten to "VA center."  VA regional office: Use instead of "regional benefits office."  Veteran: Capitalize even as common noun. Use second-person perspective when possible.  Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC): Note singular "Veteran."  Veteran ID Card (VIC): Capitalize when referring to official discount card.  Veteran Readiness and Employment (VR&E): Full program name. Formerly "Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment" or "voc rehab."  Veterans Affairs: No apostrophe in "Veterans."  Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA): Note "Benefits" is plural.  Veterans Crisis Line (VCL): No apostrophe in "Veterans."  Veterans Employment Center™ (VEC): Include trademark symbol.  Veterans' Group Life Insurance (VGLI): Plural possessive apostrophe.  Veterans Health Administration (VHA): Standard acronym usage.  Veterans Job Bank: Plural "Veterans."  Veterans Law Judge: Capitalize. Can use lowercase "judge" after first mention.  Veterans Pension: No apostrophe. Use lowercase "pension" when written as "VA pension."  Veterans Service Organization (VSO): Plural. Use "VSO representative" for individual.  Vietnam era: Capitalize "Era." Use lowercase "era" when paired with "War" (Vietnam War era).

searchDocs.title: W​
searchDocs.content: Washington, DC: Default styling for location and facilities. "District of Columbia" acceptable in government contexts.  Website: One word, lowercase.  Work study: Two words, not hyphenated as noun. Hyphenate as adjective.

searchDocs.title: Y​
searchDocs.content: Yellow Ribbon Scholarship/Program: Capitalize "Program."

searchDocs.title: Z​
searchDocs.content: Zip code: Lowercase, two words per Merriam-Webster.

searchDocs.title: Content strategy​
searchDocs.content: Address actual user search queries with unique, relevant informationPlace primary keywords in the H1 (page title), H2 (section headers), and introductory textLimit pages to one H1; reserve it for the page title onlyIntegrate primary and secondary keywords naturally throughout body copy and headers without "keyword stuffing"

searchDocs.title: Content structure​
searchDocs.content: Use H2s and H3s consistently to structure content hierarchy for scannable organizationInclude primary keywords in URLs when possibleAvoid thin pages lacking sufficient depth; instead create comprehensive pages on a topicIncorporate personalized, conversational Q&A matching actual user search queries

searchDocs.title: User experience​
searchDocs.content: Write scannable, easily understood navigation and contentUse active voice and conversational language

searchDocs.title: Title tags and meta descriptions​
searchDocs.content: Create unique titles and descriptions for every pageAvoid duplicate tags across pages (damages SEO and confuses users)These help users identify page content in search results and reinforce VA's brand authority

searchDocs.title: Meta description guidelines​
searchDocs.content: Guideline	DetailsCharacter limit	Under 300 characters (including spaces) Primary keyword placement	Within first 155 characters Secondary keywords	Incorporate naturally Calls to action	Include when space permits Voice	Active voice and plain language
