searchDocs.content: Page titles and section titlesTitle tags

searchDocs.title: Core Principles​
searchDocs.content: Write in plain language that Veterans and their families can understandUse conversational tone that addresses users directlyFollow web best practices for scannable, accessible contentMaintain consistency across all VA administrations

searchDocs.title: Writing Fundamentals​
searchDocs.content: Plain Language - Guidelines for clear, simple writingError Messages - How to write helpful error and alert messagesLinks - Writing effective, accessible link textButton Labels - Action-oriented button text guidelines

searchDocs.title: Style & Grammar​
searchDocs.content: For comprehensive style and grammar guidance, see the Content Style Guide, which covers:  Abbreviations and acronymsCapitalization rulesPunctuation guidelinesNumbers and dates formattingWord list and terminology

searchDocs.title: Use Sentence Case​
searchDocs.content: Capitalize only the first word and proper nouns.  Correct:  Create an account  Incorrect:  Create An Account

searchDocs.title: Keep Labels Brief​
searchDocs.content: Aim for 35 characters maximum (including spaces). Shorter is better.  Too long	BetterSubmit your application for review	Submit application Continue to the next step	Continue Go back to the previous page	Back

searchDocs.title: Use Action Words​
searchDocs.content: Start with a verb that clearly signals what will happen.  Good examples:  Create an accountSubmit applicationDownload formSign inContinueBack  Avoid:  Get started (vague)Complaint filing (noun-based)Click here (unhelpful)

searchDocs.title: Navigation​
searchDocs.content: Action	LabelMove forward	Continue Move backward	Back Finish a process	Submit Leave without saving	Cancel

searchDocs.title: Account Actions​
searchDocs.content: Action	LabelCreate new account	Create an account Access existing account	Sign in Leave account	Sign out

searchDocs.title: Form Actions​
searchDocs.content: Action	LabelSend form	Submit Store progress	Save Save and exit	Save and continue later Add item to list	Add another [item] Remove item	Remove

searchDocs.title: File Actions​
searchDocs.content: Action	LabelGet a file	Download Send a file	Upload View a document	View [document name]

searchDocs.title: Button vs. Link​
searchDocs.content: Use buttons for:  Primary actions (Submit, Save, Continue)Actions that change dataForm submissionsImportant calls to action  Use links for:  Navigation between pagesSecondary actionsExternal resourcesActions that don't change data

searchDocs.title: Unique Labels​
searchDocs.content: Each button on a page should have a unique, descriptive label. If you have multiple "Submit" buttons, use aria-labels to differentiate:  <button type="submit" aria-label="Submit health care application"> Submit </button>

searchDocs.title: Descriptive Text​
searchDocs.content: Button text should describe the action, not just say "Submit" or "Continue."  When context is unclear:  Submit application  When context is clear:  Submit

searchDocs.title: Disabled Buttons​
searchDocs.content: When a button is disabled, explain why:  <button disabled aria-describedby="submit-help">Submit</button> <p id="submit-help">Complete all required fields to submit.</p>

searchDocs.title: Privacy Considerations​
searchDocs.content: Button text should avoid Personally Identifiable Information (PII) or Protected Health Information (PHI) whenever possible. If PII/PHI is unavoidable, click tracking becomes impossible for analytics compliance.  Avoid:  Submit John Smith's application  Use:  Submit your application

searchDocs.title: Do​
searchDocs.content: Start with an action verbKeep labels short and scannableUse sentence caseMake the action clear and specificTest with users to ensure clarity

searchDocs.title: Don't​
searchDocs.content: Use vague labels like "Go" or "Click here"Use noun-based phrasesInclude punctuationUse all capsMake buttons look like links or vice versa

searchDocs.title: System Messages​
searchDocs.content: Alert users of important system-related issues or statuses initiated by the system itself, not user actions.  Examples:  Scheduled maintenance notificationsSystem outagesService disruptions

searchDocs.title: Engagement Messages​
searchDocs.content: Recommend that the user enter or update data. Can originate from either the system or another person.  Examples:  Profile completion promptsInformation update remindersAction recommendations

searchDocs.title: Access Messages​
searchDocs.content: Appear when users attempt to access unavailable items, such as deleted records or restricted information.  Examples:  Page not found (404)Permission deniedContent no longer available

searchDocs.title: Feedback Messages​
searchDocs.content: Appear as a response to a user's actions, covering create, read, update, and delete operations.  Examples:  Form submission confirmationSave successfulDelete confirmation

searchDocs.title: Step 1: Explain the Problem​
searchDocs.content: Use an alert component with a clear header. Keep titles to 50 characters maximum (including spaces).  If VA caused the error:  We're sorry. We can't process your request right now.  If the user caused the error:Don't say "we're sorry," but don't blame the user either.  We couldn't find that page.

searchDocs.title: Step 2: Provide Recovery Steps​
searchDocs.content: Make recovery steps clear, specific, and actionable.  Vague (avoid):  An error occurred. Please try again.  Specific (prefer):  We couldn't save your form. Check your internet connection and try saving again.

searchDocs.title: Error Message Structure​
searchDocs.content: [Alert heading - what went wrong] [Body text - what they can do about it] [Action button or link - how to proceed]

searchDocs.title: Example​
searchDocs.content: <va-alert status="error"> <h2 slot="headline">We can't load your saved application</h2> <p> We're having trouble loading your information. Please try again in a few minutes. </p> <p> If this problem continues, call us at <va-telephone contact="8006982411"></va-telephone>. We're here 24/7. </p> </va-alert>

searchDocs.title: Common Contact Information​
searchDocs.content: Include appropriate contact options as secondary recovery steps:  Type	Contact	HoursTechnical support	MyVA411: 800-698-2411	24/7 Benefits questions	800-827-1000	M-F, 8am-9pm ET Education benefits	GI Bill hotline: 888-442-4551	M-F, 8am-7pm ET Health benefits	877-222-8387	M-F, 8am-8pm ET

searchDocs.title: Do​
searchDocs.content: Keep alert titles to approximately 50 charactersUse neutral, non-blaming languageProvide specific, actionable recovery stepsInclude contact options when appropriateTest error messages with users

searchDocs.title: Don't​
searchDocs.content: Blame the user for errorsUse technical jargon or error codes aloneLeave users without a next stepUse vague messages like "Invalid input"Show raw system errors

searchDocs.title: Form Validation Error​
searchDocs.content: Instead of:  Invalid file type  Write:  We can't accept this file type. Upload a PDF, JPG, or PNG file.

searchDocs.title: System Error​
searchDocs.content: Instead of:  Error 500: Internal Server Error  Write:  We're sorry. Something went wrong on our end. Please try again in a few minutes. If this keeps happening, call us at 800-698-2411.

searchDocs.title: Access Error​
searchDocs.content: Instead of:  403 Forbidden  Write:  You don't have access to this page. If you think this is a mistake, call us at 800-698-2411.

searchDocs.title: Coordinating with Support​
searchDocs.content: When creating new error messages with contact options, coordinate with the Veteran Support team. Document:  What triggers the errorRecovery steps for usersTroubleshooting guidance for support staff

searchDocs.title: Use Natural, Descriptive Language​
searchDocs.content: Link text should clearly communicate the purpose and destination.  Instead of:  Click here to learn more.  Write:  Learn more about VA health care benefits.

searchDocs.title: Avoid Generic Phrases​
searchDocs.content: Don't use vague link text that requires surrounding context to understand.  Avoid	Use insteadClick here	[Specific action or destination] Learn more	Learn more about [topic] Read more	Read more about [topic] Here	[Descriptive text]

searchDocs.title: Avoid Ability-Assumptive Words​
searchDocs.content: Not all users interact with links the same way. Avoid words that assume physical abilities.  Avoid	Use insteadSee our guide	Read our guide View the form	Get the form Watch the video	Video: [title] Hear the announcement	Listen to the announcement

searchDocs.title: Contextual Links​
searchDocs.content: Instead of:  For information about burial flags, [learn more].  Write:  [Learn more about burial flags].

searchDocs.title: Action Links​
searchDocs.content: Instead of:  [Click here] to apply for benefits.  Write:  [Apply for VA health care benefits].

searchDocs.title: Document Links​
searchDocs.content: Instead of:  Download the form [here].  Write:  [Download VA Form 10-10EZ (PDF)].

searchDocs.title: Screen Reader Users​
searchDocs.content: Screen reader users often navigate by jumping between links. Each link should make sense out of context.  Test: Read only the link text. Does it tell you where you'll go and why?

searchDocs.title: External Links​
searchDocs.content: Indicate when links leave VA.gov:  <a href="https://external-site.gov"> External resource name (opens in a new tab) </a>

searchDocs.title: Aria Labels​
searchDocs.content: Use aria-labels when visual context is clear but programmatic context is not:  <a href="/apply" aria-label="Apply for health care benefits"> Apply now </a>

searchDocs.title: Link Spacing​
searchDocs.content: Avoid clustering links together—this makes selection difficult on touch devicesPlace links on separate lines when listing multiple optionsMaintain adequate spacing for users with motor impairments

searchDocs.title: Punctuation​
searchDocs.content: Don't punctuate link text (except question marks or colons if integral to the text)Place punctuation outside the link  Correct:  Learn about [VA health care].  Incorrect:  Learn about [VA health care.]

searchDocs.title: Link Placement​
searchDocs.content: Position links on individual lines for scannabilityIn paragraphs, place links at the end of sentences when possibleUse link lists for multiple related links

searchDocs.title: Avoid PII in Links​
searchDocs.content: Link text must not contain Personally Identifiable Information (PII) or Protected Health Information (PHI).  Avoid:  View claim for [John Smith].  Use:  View your claim.

searchDocs.title: URL Parameters​
searchDocs.content: URLs cannot pass PII/PHI as parameters. Generate generic identifiers instead:  Avoid:  /claims?name=john-smith&ssn=123-45-6789  Use:  /claims?id=abc123

searchDocs.title: Do​
searchDocs.content: Write descriptive link text that makes sense out of contextUse consistent link text for the same destinationsIndicate external links and new tabsKeep link text concise but meaningful

searchDocs.title: Don't​
searchDocs.content: Use "click here" or "learn more" aloneInclude PII in link textPunctuate link text unnecessarilyCluster multiple links together without spacing

searchDocs.title: 1. Use Short Sentences​
searchDocs.content: Limit each sentence to one subject and verb when possible. Break complex ideas into multiple sentences.  Instead of:  Veterans who have served on active duty and have been discharged under conditions other than dishonorable may be eligible for VA health care benefits if they meet certain requirements.  Write:  You may qualify for VA health care if you served on active duty. You must have been discharged under conditions other than dishonorable.

searchDocs.title: 2. Use Simple Words​
searchDocs.content: Choose words familiar to Veterans and their families. Avoid complex terminology.  Instead of	Useutilize	use obtain	get commence	start terminate	end facilitate	help in the event that	if at this point in time	now in order to	to

searchDocs.title: 3. Use Active Voice​
searchDocs.content: Connect actions to subjects. Make it clear who is responsible for the action.  Passive (avoid)	Active (prefer)Benefits will be paid	We'll pay your benefits Your application was received	We received your application The form must be completed	Complete the form

searchDocs.title: 4. Define Complex Terms​
searchDocs.content: Add plain language definitions in parentheses immediately after unfamiliar terms.  You may qualify for Aid and Attendance (a monthly payment added to your pension).

searchDocs.title: 5. Use Conversational Language​
searchDocs.content: Address Veterans as individuals using "you" and "your." Refer to VA as "we" and "our."  Instead of:  The Veteran must submit required documentation.  Write:  You'll need to submit your documents.

searchDocs.title: 6. Use Contractions​
searchDocs.content: Employ contractions like "don't," "we'll," and "you're" for a natural, accessible tone.  Formal	Conversationaldo not	don't we will	we'll you are	you're cannot	can't

searchDocs.title: 7. Avoid Jargon​
searchDocs.content: Eliminate bureaucratic, legal, and unnecessary acronymic language.  Jargon	Plain languageadjudicate	decide promulgate	issue effectuate	carry out pursuant to	under

searchDocs.title: 8. Avoid Idioms​
searchDocs.content: Don't use expressions that may confuse non-native English speakers.  Idiom (avoid)	Clear alternativeball is in your court	you need to take action touch base	contact circle back	follow up hit the ground running	start quickly

searchDocs.title: 9. Minimize Branded Names​
searchDocs.content: Describe benefits instead of using program acronyms. Veterans care about what they can get, not what VA calls it internally.  Instead of:  Apply for PCPG benefits.  Write:  Apply for educational and career counseling.

searchDocs.title: 10. Structure Content for Scanning​
searchDocs.content: Use headings, bulleted lists, and accordions instead of dense paragraphs.  Instead of:  To apply, you'll need to provide your DD214, Social Security number, current address, and contact information. You may also need to provide medical records if you're applying for disability benefits.  Write:  You'll need to provide: DD214 (discharge papers)Social Security numberCurrent address and phone numberMedical records (for disability claims only)

searchDocs.title: Testing Your Content​
searchDocs.content: Read content aloud—if it sounds unnatural, simplify itAsk someone unfamiliar with VA to read and explain it backUse readability tools to check grade level (aim for 6th-8th grade)Review with Veterans during usability testing

searchDocs.title: Mobile-First Approach​
searchDocs.content: Write styles for mobile by default, then use breakpoints to add styles for larger screens:  .my-component { // Mobile styles (default) padding: 16px; @include media($tablet) { // Tablet and up padding: 24px; } @include media($desktop) { // Desktop and up padding: 32px; } }

searchDocs.title: Sass Mixin Usage​
searchDocs.content: Use the @media mixin to apply styles at specific breakpoints:  @include media($medium-screen) { // Styles for medium screens and larger }

searchDocs.title: Nesting Options​
searchDocs.content: You can place mixins within selectors:  .my-element { width: 100%; @include media($tablet) { width: 50%; } }   Or selectors within mixins:  @include media($tablet) { .my-element { width: 50%; } .another-element { display: flex; } }

searchDocs.title: Responsive Utility Classes​
searchDocs.content: Most utility classes support responsive prefixes:  <!-- Full width on mobile, half width on tablet, third on desktop --> <div class="vads-u-width--full tablet:vads-u-width--half desktop:vads-u-width--third"> Responsive content </div>

searchDocs.title: Do​
searchDocs.content: Start with mobile styles and progressively enhance for larger screensUse the predefined breakpoints for consistencyTest layouts at each breakpoint to ensure smooth transitions

searchDocs.title: Don't​
searchDocs.content: Write desktop-first styles that override down to mobileCreate custom breakpoints unless design elements encounter genuine stress points that cannot be resolved through design modificationsAssume specific devices match specific breakpoints

searchDocs.title: What Are Design Tokens?​
searchDocs.content: Design tokens are named entities that store visual design attributes. Instead of hardcoding values like #005ea2 throughout your code, you use tokens like vads-color-primary. This approach:  Ensures consistency across applicationsMakes updates easier (change the token, update everywhere)Documents design decisionsEnables theming and dark mode support

searchDocs.title: Token Taxonomy​
searchDocs.content: The VA Design System organizes tokens using a structured naming convention:

searchDocs.title: Namespace​
searchDocs.content: Identifies the token origin:  Prefix	Sourceuswds-	U.S. Web Design System vads-	VA Design System vacds-	VA Component Design System

searchDocs.title: Object Levels​
searchDocs.content: Tokens can be scoped to different levels:  Group - Families of components (forms, navigation)Component - Specific component nameElement - Parts within components

searchDocs.title: Base Categories​

searchDocs.title: 1. Primitive Tokens​
searchDocs.content: Base-level building blocks from USWDS. These are raw values that other tokens reference:  uswds-system-color-blue-60v → #005ea2 uswds-system-spacing-3 → 24px

searchDocs.title: 2. Semantic Tokens​
searchDocs.content: Communicate how primitives are used contextually:  vads-color-primary → references uswds-system-color-blue-60v vads-color-error → references uswds-system-color-red-warm-50v vads-spacing-3 → references uswds-system-spacing-3

searchDocs.title: 3. Component Tokens​
searchDocs.content: Scoped to specific components with component-specific decisions:  vads-button-color-background-primary-on-light → #005ea2 vads-alert-color-border-error-on-light → #d54309 vads-input-border-color-on-light → #565c65

searchDocs.title: In CSS​
searchDocs.content: .my-component { color: var(--vads-color-primary); background-color: var(--vads-color-base-lightest); padding: var(--vads-spacing-2); border-radius: var(--vads-shape-border-radius-md); }

searchDocs.title: Do​
searchDocs.content: Use semantic tokens over primitive tokens when availableUse component tokens for component-specific stylingReference tokens by their full name for clarityCheck for existing tokens before creating custom values

searchDocs.title: Don't​
searchDocs.content: Hardcode color, spacing, or typography valuesCreate custom tokens without approvalOverride token values in component stylesMix token systems (USWDS and VADS) inconsistently

searchDocs.title: Token Updates​
searchDocs.content: When design tokens are updated:  Primitive tokens may change at the USWDS levelSemantic tokens are updated to reference new primitivesComponent tokens may be added or deprecatedApplications receive updates through package updates  Always check the changelog when updating the design system package.

searchDocs.content: .image-container { aspect-ratio: 3 / 2; overflow: hidden; } .image-container img { width: 100%; height: 100%; object-fit: cover; }

searchDocs.title: Responsive Images​
searchDocs.content: <picture> <source media="(min-width: 1024px)" srcset="hero-desktop.jpg"> <source media="(min-width: 640px)" srcset="hero-tablet.jpg"> <img src="hero-mobile.jpg" alt="Description of image" loading="lazy"> </picture>

searchDocs.title: Do​
searchDocs.content: Use the standard aspect ratios for consistencyOptimize images for web (compress, use appropriate format)Provide meaningful alt text for all imagesUse loading="lazy" for images below the foldEnsure adequate contrast for any text overlaid on images

searchDocs.title: Don't​
searchDocs.content: Use arbitrary aspect ratios that don't match the standardsUpload images larger than necessaryUse images without alt textRely on images alone to convey critical information

searchDocs.title: Alt Text​
searchDocs.content: All images must have descriptive alt text:  <!-- Good: Descriptive --> <img src="veteran-counselor.jpg" alt="A veteran meeting with a counselor at a VA facility"> <!-- Bad: Non-descriptive --> <img src="veteran-counselor.jpg" alt="Image"> <!-- Decorative images: Empty alt --> <img src="decorative-pattern.jpg" alt="" role="presentation">

searchDocs.title: Image Performance​
searchDocs.content: Use appropriate file formats (WebP with fallbacks)Implement responsive images with srcsetSet explicit width and height to prevent layout shiftUse lazy loading for non-critical images

searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: The VA.gov Design System uses a flexbox-based grid that delivers more design flexibility and options for responsive design compared to traditional float-based grids.

searchDocs.title: Flexbox Grid​
searchDocs.content: A 12-column responsive grid system built on CSS flexbox. The grid provides:  Responsive column widthsAutomatic equal-width columnsNested grid supportGutters via padding utilities  Learn more about the Flexbox Grid →

searchDocs.title: Page Layouts​
searchDocs.content: Pre-built page layout templates for common VA.gov page types:  Two columns with content on rightTwo columns with content on leftFull-width layouts  Learn more about Page Layouts →

searchDocs.title: Related Resources​
searchDocs.content: Spacing Units - Consistent margins and paddingBreakpoints - Responsive design breakpointsTypography - Text styling for layouts

searchDocs.title: Standard Container​
searchDocs.content: Centers content with a max-width of 1000px:  <div class="vads-l-grid-container"> <!-- Content --> </div>

searchDocs.title: Full-Width Container​
searchDocs.content: Uses the full page width:  <div class="vads-l-grid-container--full"> <!-- Content --> </div>

searchDocs.title: Basic Row and Columns​
searchDocs.content: <div class="vads-l-grid-container"> <div class="vads-l-row"> <div class="vads-l-col">Column 1</div> <div class="vads-l-col">Column 2</div> <div class="vads-l-col">Column 3</div> </div> </div>   When no width is specified, columns distribute equally and automatically wrap when space is insufficient.

searchDocs.title: Column Widths​
searchDocs.content: Use vads-l-col--[number] where the number represents columns out of a 12-column grid:  <div class="vads-l-row"> <div class="vads-l-col--3">3 columns (25%)</div> <div class="vads-l-col--9">9 columns (75%)</div> </div>

searchDocs.title: Available Widths​
searchDocs.content: Class	Widthvads-l-col--1	8.33% vads-l-col--2	16.67% vads-l-col--3	25% vads-l-col--4	33.33% vads-l-col--5	41.67% vads-l-col--6	50% vads-l-col--7	58.33% vads-l-col--8	66.67% vads-l-col--9	75% vads-l-col--10	83.33% vads-l-col--11	91.67% vads-l-col--12	100%  note The row's total columns should equal 12 to prevent wrapping.

searchDocs.title: Responsive Columns​
searchDocs.content: Columns can adapt across breakpoints using responsive prefixes:  Prefix	Breakpointmobile-lg:	481px tablet:	640px desktop:	1024px desktop-lg:	1201px

searchDocs.title: Example​
searchDocs.content: <div class="vads-l-row"> <div class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--6 desktop:vads-l-col--4"> Full width on mobile, half on tablet, third on desktop </div> <div class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--6 desktop:vads-l-col--4"> Full width on mobile, half on tablet, third on desktop </div> <div class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--12 desktop:vads-l-col--4"> Full width on mobile and tablet, third on desktop </div> </div>

searchDocs.title: Column Spacing​
searchDocs.content: The grid requires padding and/or margin utilities to provide column spacing. This offers greater design flexibility than traditional grids with built-in gutters.  <div class="vads-l-row"> <div class="vads-l-col--6 vads-u-padding-right--2"> Left column with right padding </div> <div class="vads-l-col--6 vads-u-padding-left--2"> Right column with left padding </div> </div>

searchDocs.title: Nested Grids​
searchDocs.content: Grids can be nested. Use matching negative margin values to offset parent padding:  <div class="vads-l-grid-container"> <div class="vads-l-row"> <div class="vads-l-col--8 vads-u-padding--2"> <div class="vads-l-row vads-u-margin-x--neg2"> <div class="vads-l-col--6 vads-u-padding--2">Nested column</div> <div class="vads-l-col--6 vads-u-padding--2">Nested column</div> </div> </div> <div class="vads-l-col--4"> Sidebar </div> </div> </div>

searchDocs.title: Two-Column Layout​
searchDocs.content: <div class="vads-l-grid-container"> <div class="vads-l-row"> <div class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--8"> Main content </div> <div class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--4"> Sidebar </div> </div> </div>

searchDocs.title: Three-Column Layout​
searchDocs.content: <div class="vads-l-grid-container"> <div class="vads-l-row"> <div class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--4">Column 1</div> <div class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--4">Column 2</div> <div class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--4">Column 3</div> </div> </div>

searchDocs.title: Card Grid​
searchDocs.content: <div class="vads-l-grid-container"> <div class="vads-l-row"> <div class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--6 desktop:vads-l-col--3 vads-u-padding--2"> <div class="vads-u-background-color--gray-lightest vads-u-padding--2"> Card 1 </div> </div> <div class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--6 desktop:vads-l-col--3 vads-u-padding--2"> <div class="vads-u-background-color--gray-lightest vads-u-padding--2"> Card 2 </div> </div> <!-- More cards... --> </div> </div>

searchDocs.title: Do​
searchDocs.content: Use the 12-column grid for consistent layoutsApply responsive prefixes for mobile-first designUse padding utilities for column spacing

searchDocs.title: Don't​
searchDocs.content: Nest grids more than 2 levels deepMix grid systems (stick to flexbox grid)Forget to account for spacing when calculating column widths

searchDocs.title: Two Columns, Content on Right​
searchDocs.content: This layout positions navigation or secondary content on the left sidebar with main content occupying the right column.

searchDocs.title: Desktop View​
searchDocs.content: Left sidebar: 4 columns (3 on desktop-lg)Main content: 8 columns (9 on desktop-lg)

searchDocs.title: Mobile View​
searchDocs.content: On mobile devices, the sidebar converts to a flyout menu and appears above the main content.

searchDocs.title: Example​
searchDocs.content: <div class="vads-l-grid-container"> <div class="vads-l-row"> <!-- Sidebar --> <div class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--4 desktop-lg:vads-l-col--3"> <nav aria-label="Secondary navigation"> <!-- Navigation items --> </nav> </div> <!-- Main content --> <main class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--8 desktop-lg:vads-l-col--9"> <h1>Page Title</h1> <!-- Page content --> </main> </div> </div>

searchDocs.title: Two Columns, Content on Left​
searchDocs.content: This layout places primary content on the left and promotional or supplementary content on the right.

searchDocs.title: Desktop View​
searchDocs.content: Main content: 8 columnsRight sidebar: 4 columns

searchDocs.title: Mobile View​
searchDocs.content: On mobile, the right column moves below the main content.

searchDocs.title: Example​
searchDocs.content: <div class="vads-l-grid-container"> <div class="vads-l-row"> <!-- Main content --> <main class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--8"> <h1>Page Title</h1> <!-- Page content --> </main> <!-- Sidebar --> <aside class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--4"> <!-- Promotional content, related links, etc. --> </aside> </div> </div>

searchDocs.title: Full-Width Layout​
searchDocs.content: For pages that need maximum content width:  <div class="vads-l-grid-container--full"> <main> <h1>Page Title</h1> <!-- Full-width content --> </main> </div>

searchDocs.title: Technical Structure​
searchDocs.content: Both two-column layouts use:  Flexbox grid container with appropriate margin utilities for consistent spacingResponsive breakpoints (mobile, tablet, desktop-lg)Padding utilities using standardized spacing units<main> semantic tag wrapping core page content

searchDocs.title: Semantic Structure​
searchDocs.content: The main content of the page should always be wrapped in <main>:  <main> <!-- Primary page content --> </main>

searchDocs.title: Source Order​
searchDocs.content: Maintain visual-to-DOM order consistency across all screen sizes. Avoid CSS-based source reordering that could confuse screen reader users.  <!-- Good: DOM order matches visual order --> <div class="vads-l-row"> <div class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--4">Sidebar (appears first on mobile)</div> <main class="vads-l-col--12 tablet:vads-l-col--8">Content</main> </div>

searchDocs.title: Landmarks​
searchDocs.content: Use appropriate ARIA landmarks:  <nav aria-label="Primary navigation">...</nav> <main>...</main> <aside aria-label="Related content">...</aside> <footer>...</footer>

searchDocs.title: Do​
searchDocs.content: Use semantic HTML elements (<main>, <nav>, <aside>, <footer>)Ensure content is accessible in all viewport sizesTest layouts at each breakpointMaintain consistent spacing using utility classes

searchDocs.title: Don't​
searchDocs.content: Reorder content visually in ways that differ from DOM orderNest main content areasUse layout classes for non-layout purposesOverride grid behavior with conflicting CSS

searchDocs.title: Key Principle: "Branded House" Approach​
searchDocs.content: VA has adopted a unified visual strategy rather than multiple sub-brands. This approach recognizes that:  Veterans think of VA as a single entityMultiple brands are confusing and complicatedA consolidated brand supports better navigation and trust

searchDocs.title: Logo Restrictions​
searchDocs.content: Custom logos for VA departments, offices, teams, programs, or initiatives are not supported on VA.gov.  This policy aligns with:  VA Graphic StandardsWeb Governance requirementsDigital Modernization initiative

searchDocs.title: Unsupported Use Cases​
searchDocs.content: Logos cannot be used for:  Program or benefits listing pagesBenefit detail pagesSoftware applications (forms, tools)Search result listings for VA departments or officesTeam or initiative brandingEvent branding on VA.gov

searchDocs.title: Recommended Alternative​
searchDocs.content: Instead of graphical logos, use the name of the department, office, team, program, initiative, or event in text form.

searchDocs.title: Example​
searchDocs.content: <!-- Don't: Custom program logo --> <img src="program-logo.png" alt="My VA Program"> <!-- Do: Text name with standard styling --> <h1>My VA Program</h1>

searchDocs.title: Official VA Logo​
searchDocs.content: The official VA logo is available for specific, approved uses:  VA.gov headerOfficial communicationsApproved print materials

searchDocs.title: Logo Resources​
searchDocs.content: VA Graphic Standards (pages 9, 46-49) specify proper logo executionOfficial logos are available in the VADS Component Library for designersContact the VA Design System team for logo access and approval

searchDocs.title: Why This Matters​
searchDocs.content: This policy supports VA's Digital Modernization initiative by:  Reducing confusion - Veterans don't need to learn multiple brand identitiesBuilding trust - Consistent branding reinforces that all services come from VASimplifying navigation - Fewer visual elements means clearer wayfindingEnsuring accessibility - Text is more accessible than images

searchDocs.title: Exceptions​
searchDocs.content: If you believe your use case requires a logo exception:  Review the VA Graphic StandardsConsult with the VA Design System CouncilDocument the business justificationObtain written approval before implementation  Most exceptions are not granted. The default should always be text-based identification.

searchDocs.title: Source Sans Pro (Primary)​
searchDocs.content: .vads-u-font-family--sans   Source Sans Pro is the primary sans-serif typeface, designed for UI legibility. It's open-source with excellent rendering across devices and browsers, supporting multiple languages including Western European, Vietnamese, Pinyin, and Navajo.

searchDocs.title: Bitter (Serif)​
searchDocs.content: .vads-u-font-family--serif   Bitter is a slab serif designed specifically for screen reading. It features large x-heights and manual spacing with minimal kerning pairs, maintaining consistent stroke weight for comfortable paragraph reading.

searchDocs.title: Roboto Mono (Monospace)​
searchDocs.content: .vads-u-font-family--mono   Roboto Mono is used for code and technical content. It clearly distinguishes similar characters (0/O, 1/l/I) for clarity.  Use sparingly. Avoid using monospace for:  Phone numbersZIP codesDates

searchDocs.content: Regular (400) - Standard weight for body textBold (700) - Emphasis and heading hierarchy

searchDocs.title: Do​
searchDocs.content: Use semantic HTML headings in proper nesting order (H1 → H2 → H3)Apply font-size utility classes to adjust appearance without breaking structureUse headings as organizational elements to structure content

searchDocs.title: Don't​
searchDocs.content: Skip heading levels (e.g., H1 directly to H3)Use improper nesting purely for visual stylingTurn headings into links in normal page content  note Links in headers are acceptable only in Card components where space constraints justify combining elements.

searchDocs.title: Intro Paragraphs​
searchDocs.content: Use the va-introtext class for introductory paragraphs at the top of pages.  <p class="va-introtext"> This introductory text helps Veterans understand what they'll find on this page. </p>

searchDocs.title: Line Length​
searchDocs.content: Maximum line length should be 72ex (vads-size-line-length-5) for optimal readability.

searchDocs.title: Accessibility​
searchDocs.content: Always use semantic headings, logically nested in the proper orderProper heading hierarchy supports screen readers and assistive technologiesAvoid using headers as links, as this creates dual functionality that can confuse users and presents keyboard navigation challengesEnsure sufficient color contrast for all text (4.5:1 for normal text, 3:1 for large text)

searchDocs.title: For components​
searchDocs.content: Utility classes increase modularity in design system components without requiring additional markup or modifier classes. They're particularly useful for components with unpredictable internal layouts.

searchDocs.title: Overriding defaults​
searchDocs.content: Utility classes help adjust spacing between components when visual distraction occurs from default spacing.

searchDocs.title: Design consistency​
searchDocs.content: Utilities like margin and padding maintain consistent horizontal and vertical rhythm by using design tokens and Sass variables rather than hard-coded pixel values.

searchDocs.title: IA Principles​
searchDocs.content: The VA.gov platform and VA Health and Benefits mobile app follow seven core principles:

searchDocs.title: 1. User-Centered Design​
searchDocs.content: Research how people categorize and search for information to inform organizational decisions.

searchDocs.title: 2. Sense of Place​
searchDocs.content: Always provide a sense of place by using design components and content to show visitors where they are within the experience and where they can go next.

searchDocs.title: 3. Consistency​
searchDocs.content: Apply uniform organizational structure and labels across digital and physical touchpoints.

searchDocs.title: 4. Prioritization​
searchDocs.content: Limit and prioritize information to enhance discoverability, reduce cognitive load, and allow self-paced exploration.

searchDocs.title: 5. Findability​
searchDocs.content: Present information aligned with user mental models and offer multiple discovery pathways.

searchDocs.title: 6. Focused Navigation​
searchDocs.content: Use clear menus and labeling with distinct calls-to-action to reduce friction and cognitive burden.

searchDocs.title: 7. Scalability​
searchDocs.content: Design flexible systems allowing content and information to evolve over time.

searchDocs.title: When to Consider IA​
searchDocs.content: Apply IA thinking when:  Launching new features or contentAdding categories to the mobile appCreating subdomains or subdirectoriesRedesigning or restructuring pagesImproving content discoverabilityRemoving features or contentModifying global navigation elements

searchDocs.title: Resources​
searchDocs.content: Domain Structure - Guidelines for using subdomains vs. subdirectoriesURL Standards - Requirements for creating and managing URLsVA Health and Benefits App - App-specific IA guidance  Contact: #content-ia-centralized-team on Slack for VA.gov IA questions

searchDocs.title: Principles for Domain Structuring​
searchDocs.content: Create single sources of truth: Avoid duplicating information or functionality across subdirectories or subdomainsKeep similar information together: Related content for the same audience must occupy the same spaceCreate relationships where important: Subdirectories establish connections between similar information; subdomains create separationPreserve seamless experience: Maintain continuity for user journeys to prevent disorienting shifts in branding, navigation, or layout

searchDocs.title: Subdirectory​
searchDocs.content: Subdirectories organize content into sections within the main website. They appear after the domain in URLs (e.g., www.va.gov/health-care/).  Characteristics:  Keeps content within the main websiteAccommodates most VA content and toolsMust follow URL standardsCan be nested into multiple levels  Examples:  https://www.va.gov/education/ - Veterans access education benefits informationhttps://www.va.gov/my-health/ - Veterans manage VA health care functionality

searchDocs.title: Subdomain​
searchDocs.content: Subdomains operate as separate sites extending the va.gov domain name, appearing to the left (e.g., design.va.gov).  Characteristics:  Functions as a distinct, separate siteUsed sparingly and only for approved casesCan include subdirectories for organization (e.g., design.va.gov/components)Development environments may include staging subdomainsMust follow URL standards  Examples:  https://design.va.gov - Design standards for VA employees and contractorshttps://developer.va.gov - API access for developers building VA tools

searchDocs.title: Criteria for Subdirectory Use​
searchDocs.content: Subdirectories are appropriate for:  Information and tools Veterans, family members, and supporters need to discover, learn about, apply, track, and manage VA benefits, healthcare, programs, and servicesInformation about VA facilities and offices managing benefits and services

searchDocs.title: Criteria for Subdomain Use​
searchDocs.content: Subdomains may be appropriate for:

searchDocs.title: Mission-Related Experiences​
searchDocs.content: Distinct needs separate from va.gov's primary mission serving broad audiences (e.g., news.va.gov, research.va.gov, data.va.gov)Information and tools for VA employees and contractors working remotely (e.g., design.va.gov, developer.va.gov)Partner-focused experiences for claims submission or care provision (e.g., representatives.va.gov)

searchDocs.title: Technical Constraints​
searchDocs.content: Experiences with platform or infrastructure limitations preventing va.gov hostingRequirements for domain-level isolation meeting ATO, FISMA, or FedRAMP standardsSeparate lifecycle, team, or delivery models creating integration burdens

searchDocs.title: Exception​
searchDocs.content: In rare cases, separate top-level domains may be created (e.g., www.veteranscrisisline.net).

searchDocs.title: Requesting Changes​
searchDocs.content: Contact the IA team via #content-ia-centralized-team on Slack for subdirectory or subdomain requests.

searchDocs.title: Purpose​
searchDocs.content: User Protection: Prevents 404 (page not found) errors by routing visitors to valid destinationsSearch Engine Optimization: Informs search engines of page relocation, updating their indexes and transferring search value

searchDocs.title: When to Implement Redirects​
searchDocs.content: Redirects are appropriate when changes affect page availability at specific URLs:  Page removal or discontinuationMerging multiple pages into consolidated contentURL changes due to keyword or contextual modificationsMoving pages within site architectureParent page changes that cascade to child pages

searchDocs.title: When NOT to Use Redirects​
searchDocs.content: Temporary situations: Use temporary redirects instead of permanent (301) redirects for anticipated returns or repurposingInvalid URL variations: Cannot claim every possible URL spelling or variation accessing a pageNon-VA.gov domains: Cannot redirect pages outside va.gov domain structureForms Library pages: Use migrations instead of redirects per Forms Library specifications

searchDocs.title: Implementation Timing​
searchDocs.content: Deploy redirects simultaneously with URL changes, no later than 24 hours after new URL goes live.

searchDocs.title: Destination Selection​
searchDocs.content: Choose landing pages with similar context, purpose, and detail level. Avoid redirecting to homepage as it frustrates users seeking specific information.

searchDocs.title: Avoid Common Issues​
searchDocs.content: Redirect chains: A→B→C sequences that slow page loading and dilute SEO valueRedirect loops: Circular routing that prevents pages from loadingImproper child page handling: Forgetting to redirect child pages when parent URLs changeCasing variation oversights: URLs with different capitalization should redirect to the canonical lowercase version

searchDocs.title: Internal Updates​
searchDocs.content: Modify all VA.gov links reflecting new destinations rather than relying solely on redirects.

searchDocs.title: Multi-page Tools​
searchDocs.content: Always link to canonical URLs for flows, tools, and forms.

searchDocs.title: Request Process​
searchDocs.content: Redirect requests must be submitted to VA.gov Information Architecture for vetting before implementation, ensuring accuracy and triggering processes to update internal links across environments.  Contact #content-ia-centralized-team on Slack to submit a redirect request.

searchDocs.title: Example​
searchDocs.content: www.va.gov/trust directs users to https://www.va.gov/initiatives/veteran-trust-in-va/

searchDocs.title: Distinction from Shortened URLs​
searchDocs.content: A shortened URL uses randomized characters rather than meaningful words. VA does not offer URL-shortener services and discourages external services (like bitly.com) due to blocking and trustworthiness concerns.

searchDocs.title: Key Characteristics​
searchDocs.content: Begin with www.va.gov exclusivelyNo subdomains (e.g., education.va.gov)No custom top-level domains (e.g., www.va.apply)The vanity segment must be brief, typeable, and memorableUser's browser displays the final canonical URL after redirect

searchDocs.title: Appropriate Use Cases​
searchDocs.content: Implement vanity URLs for campaigns that:  Target Veterans, family members, or caregiversHave national (not local) scopeDirect to a dedicated campaign landing page

searchDocs.title: Inappropriate Applications​
searchDocs.content: Vanity URLs should NOT be used for:  External content beyond VA.govFile or document downloads (PDFs)General benefit information or toolsResources and support contentUnfinished URL reservations

searchDocs.title: Selection Criteria​
searchDocs.content: Prioritize pronounceability and ease of entry for print, video, and audio campaignsConsider assistive technology compatibilityUse contextually relevant keywordsAvoid sensitive or alarming terminologyMaintain consistency with general URL standards

searchDocs.title: Request Process​
searchDocs.content: Submit vanity URL requests to VA.gov Information Architecture for validation, approval, and implementation.  Contact #content-ia-centralized-team on Slack to submit a vanity URL request.

searchDocs.title: Four Top-Level Categories​
searchDocs.content: The app organizes content into four primary sections:  1. Home​  The default screen displaying personalized Veteran information and tasks across VA, plus general resources and lesser-used features like Profile and Settings.  Includes Profile subcategory for infrequently updated personal data  2. Health​  All health-related features and statuses.  Current features:  AppointmentsPrescriptionsVA vaccine recordsMessaging  Future: Medical records  3. Benefits​  Benefit-related features excluding health.  Current features:  Disability ratingClaimsVA Letters  Future: Education  4. Payments​  Unified financial management section.  Current features:  VA payment historyDirect deposit information  Future: Medical copays, Bills, Travel reimbursements

searchDocs.title: Key IA Principles​
searchDocs.content: When adding new features to the app's architecture:  Prioritize existing categories before proposing new top-level categoriesMaintain flat hierarchies within categoriesGroup features when a category exceeds six itemsEnsure primary placements - all features must have a primary location within the taxonomyApply user research (card sorting) when content outgrows current structure

searchDocs.title: Documentation Resources​
searchDocs.content: The detailed sitemap/flow diagram in Figma serves as the source of truth and includes:  System display logicKey actionsNative mobile integration points

searchDocs.title: Development Background​
searchDocs.content: The current IA resulted from three research phases:  Two card-sorting roundsNavigation model explorationEvaluative testing with Veterans

searchDocs.title: Uniqueness & Differentiation​
searchDocs.content: Each URL must be completely unique within a domainURLs must be specific enough to clearly distinguish each page

searchDocs.title: Formatting Requirements​
searchDocs.content: All alphabetic characters must be lowercaseWords separated by hyphens (no underscores or spaces)No special characters except hyphensMaximum 2000 characters to ensure browser compatibility

searchDocs.title: Structural Accuracy​
searchDocs.content: URLs must accurately represent content placement and hierarchyAvoid invalid or empty sub-directoriesEmpty directories should redirect to appropriate locations

searchDocs.title: Readability & Plain Language​
searchDocs.content: Users and search engines must easily understand content purposeKeywords should derive from the page's H1 headingContent should match the VA content style guide standardsNo spelling or grammatical errors permitted

searchDocs.title: Clarity & Conciseness​
searchDocs.content: Avoid overly broad terms or excessive abbreviationDo not repeat keywords unnecessarilyExclude stop words ("a," "the," "and") unless clarity requires them

searchDocs.title: Privacy Protection​
searchDocs.content: No Personally Identifiable Information (PII) or Protected Health Information (PHI)This applies to parameters and anchor tags as well

searchDocs.title: Changing URLs & Retiring Content​
searchDocs.content: Always implement redirects when:  Pages are removedURLs change  This prevents 404 errors and preserves SEO value.

searchDocs.title: Core Standards Apply​
searchDocs.content: All form flow URLs must follow the core standards listed above.

searchDocs.title: Linking Strategy​
searchDocs.content: Link to the core form URL, not specific pages, to reduce broken links if pages are reorganized.  Incorrect: www.va.gov/health-care/apply-for-health-care-form-10-10ez/introduction  Correct: www.va.gov/health-care/apply-for-health-care-form-10-10ez/

searchDocs.title: Standardized Form Pages​
searchDocs.content: /introduction/ - typically the first page/review-and-submit/ - allows users to review before submission/confirmation/ - displayed after form submission

searchDocs.title: Flat Structure Required​
searchDocs.content: Form flows should be linear with all pages at the same hierarchy level.  Incorrect: form-url/page1/page2/page3/  Correct: form-url/page1/, form-url/page2/, form-url/page3/  Exception: Different audience paths may be nested:  /form-url/veteran/page1//form-url/family/page1/

searchDocs.title: Multiple Response Numbering​
searchDocs.content: For list-and-loop questions, numbering starts at 1 and increments upward.  Embedded example:  /form-url/dependent-1//form-url/dependent-2/  Parameter example:  /form-url/dependent/?name=1/form-url/dependent/?name=2

searchDocs.title: Chapter Names​
searchDocs.content: Avoid incorporating chapter names in URLs to prevent problems when chapters are renamed or reorganized.

searchDocs.title: Related Steps Strategy​
searchDocs.content: Use the same initial term for related pages in a flow:  List and loop follow-ups:  /dependent-1-contact/dependent-1-address/dependent-2-contact/dependent-2-address  Follow-up questions:  /form-url/home-ownership//form-url/home-value/  Topic-related series:  /form-url/military-branch//form-url/military-service-period//form-url/military-other-names/

searchDocs.title: Anchor Tag Guidelines​
searchDocs.content: When using jump links or anchored links:  Treat anchor tag IDs as part of the URLFollow standard URL guidelines when possibleUse plain language keywords from associated headings for static content  Example: www.va.gov/health-care/#manage-your-health-and-benefits  For lengthy or changeable headings, using content IDs works well for accordions with frequently asked questions.

searchDocs.title: URL Parameters (Query Strings) Guidelines​
searchDocs.content: Parameters filter or organize page information and are commonly used for:  PaginationAnchoringFiltering or sorting dataLanguage indicationSearching  Example: https://www.va.gov/search/?page=1&query=disability+compensation&t=true

searchDocs.title: Parameter Best Practices​
searchDocs.content: No PII/PHI: Never include names, contact information, or unique identifiers (IP addresses, ICN, EDIPI)Canonical tags: Use rel=canonical when parameter-based URLs contain similar content to establish the primary version for search enginesParameter naming: Keys should be single words that clearly define the parameter; avoid generic terms like "parm" or "key"No empty parameters: Do not expose null or empty value parametersMulti-select values: Combine into single parameter: color=blue,red,white instead of repeating the keyAvoid parameter links: Link to static or canonical URLs when possibleConsistent ordering: When using multiple parameters, establish priority and list them consistently

searchDocs.title: Ask users for...
searchDocs.content: Ask users for... Patterns for collecting user information through forms and applications. These patterns provide consistent, accessible approaches for gathering: Personal information (names, dates of birth)Contact details (addresses, phone numbers, email)Preferences and responsesFiles and documents Browse the patterns in this section to find guidance for your specific data collection needs.

searchDocs.title: Addresses
searchDocs.content: Addresses Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern when you need to collect a mailing or home address, including military base addresses. Usage When to use this pattern Collecting mailing addresses. When you need a user's mailing location for correspondence.Collecting home addresses. When you need a user's residential address.Collecting military base addresses. When users may be located at military installations. Design principles Validate against USPS data. Compare entries against postal service databases and warn users of discrepancies.Adapt fields by country. State field converts from text input to select menu for US, Canada, and Mexico.Use prefill when available. Populate from VA.gov profile and notify users with the prefill component.Clarify profile updates. Specify whether changes affect the user's broader VA.gov profile. Examples Mailing address Standard form for collecting a mailing address with street, city, state, and postal code fields. Military base address Form variant including military installation checkbox and APO/FPO options. Address confirmation Alert component warning of unmatched USPS data with correction options. How to design and build The address pattern uses a structured workflow for both single and multiple address scenarios. How this pattern works Header identifying address type (mailing or home address).Contextual information block explaining why the address is needed.Military address checkbox with explanation (conditional).Country selector dropdown.Three-line street address fields.City input field.State/Province/Region field (adapts based on country).Postal code input with country-specific validation.For home address: 'Same as mailing address' radio option. Components used in this pattern CheckboxSelectText inputAlert Code usage Usage The `addressPattern` is available as a web-component pattern in the VA Forms library. ```jsx import { addressPattern } from '@department-of-veterans-affairs/platform-forms-system/patterns'; ``` See the [vets-website repository](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/vets-website) for implementation details. Content considerations Field	Hint text	Error messageCountry	—	Select a country Street address	—	Enter a street address City	—	Enter a city State (US)	—	Select a state Province (Canada)	—	Enter a valid province Postal code (US)	—	Enter a valid 5-digit zip code Postal code (International)	—	Enter a postal code meeting your country's requirements Military post office	—	Select a military post office (APO, FPO, or DPO) Accessibility considerations Follow the addresses section in the VA.gov content style guide for displaying addresses.Error messages should vary based on country selection and validation type.Military address abbreviations (AA, AE, AP) require specific validation messaging. Provide feedback Share your feedback, report issues, or suggest improvements for the Addresses component. Your input helps us make the design system better for everyone. searchDocs.title: Contact preferences
searchDocs.content: Contact preferences Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern when you want to ask a user how they'd like to be contacted, allowing them to select a preferred communication method. Usage When to use this pattern Capturing preferred contact method. When your form requires knowing how the user prefers to be contacted.Form-specific requirements. Different forms may have varying contact method options based on stakeholder needs. Design principles Give users one choice. Allow users to pick one method of contact using radio buttons.Vary options by form. The available contact methods may differ depending on form requirements.Work with stakeholders. Determine what contact information is necessary for each form. Examples Method of contact Radio button list allowing users to select their preferred contact method. How to design and build The contact preferences pattern uses radio buttons for single selection. How this pattern works Present contact methods as a radio button list.Common options include: Phone, Email, Mail, or Text message.Ensure options align with what the form/service can actually support.Collect the corresponding contact information based on the selection. Components used in this pattern Radio button Accessibility considerations Radio buttons must be properly grouped with a fieldset and legend.Each option must have a visible label.Ensure keyboard navigation works correctly between options. Provide feedback Share your feedback, report issues, or suggest improvements for the Contact preferences component. Your input helps us make the design system better for everyone. Slack supportGet immediate support in #platform-design-system All feedback channelsExplore all ways to share feedback

searchDocs.title: A single response
searchDocs.content: A single response Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Asking for one logical thing at a time allows users to focus on what you are asking from them. While a page may contain multiple form fields, the "one thing" refers to the information being gathered conceptually. Usage When to use this pattern Collecting related responses. When collecting one or a few related responses from users.Reducing complexity. When dividing long forms into logical sections.Focused information gathering. When situations require clear, focused questions. Design principles One thing per page. This encompasses: one piece of information, one decision, or one question.Limit conditional reveals. When using conditional reveals, limit to one per page.Make revealed questions clear. Conditionally revealed questions should be self-explanatory.Create distinct error messages. Each field should have its own error message. When not to use this pattern Multiple similar items. When collecting the same data about multiple items, use the Multiple Responses pattern.Unknown quantity. When gathering an unknown quantity of responses, use the Multiple Responses pattern. Examples Single question page Page with one focused question and clear call to action. Related fields grouped Multiple fields that together represent one logical concept (e.g., full address). How to design and build Design forms using the "one thing per page" principle. How this pattern works Brainstorm concepts using sticky notes to identify individual 'things'.Assume each concept belongs on separate pages initially.Conduct card sorting exercises with teams to group related items.Research how concepts link in existing solutions.Reorganize into related groupings where appropriate.Map user flow and test with actual users.Iterate based on feedback. Components used in this pattern CheckboxMemorable dateRadio buttonSelectText inputTextarea Code usage Usage The single response pattern reduces cognitive load, simplifies error handling, improves mobile experiences, and enhances screen reader compatibility. **Production examples:** - VA Form 21-0972 (Alternate Signer) - VA Form 21-10210 (Lay/Witness Statement) - VA Form 20-0995 (Supplemental Claim) - VA Form 20-10206 (FOIA/Privacy Act Request) Content considerations Focus each page on one logical concept, even if it contains multiple form fields.Use clear, concise questions that don't require additional context.Provide helpful hint text only when necessary. Accessibility considerations The W3C notes that keeping content to a small number of important points reduces clutter and aids understanding.This benefits users with cognitive disabilities who may struggle with focus and information retention.Ensure keyboard accessibility for conditionally revealed fields.Provide clear focus management when revealing additional fields. Provide feedback Share your feedback, report issues, or suggest improvements for the A single response component. Your input helps us make the design system better for everyone. Slack supportGet immediate support in #platform-design-system All feedback channelsExplore all ways to share feedback

searchDocs.title: Feedback
searchDocs.content: Feedback Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... VA asks users of VA.gov for feedback via a feedback button and form provided by Medallia, enabling sentiment feedback collection across modernized pages. Usage When to use this pattern Every modernized VA.gov page. Consistently offer feedback capability on every modernized page.Page bottom placement. Position the feedback button at the bottom of the page, alongside other footer-area elements. Design principles Consistent placement. The feedback button should appear in the same location on every page.Coordinate with other elements. Maintain consistent spacing with back-to-top button and last-updated date when present.Return focus after submission. After displaying confirmation, return focus to the button. Examples Desktop feedback button Feedback button at the bottom of content on full-width and search results pages. Mobile feedback button Feedback button accessible on mobile viewports. Modal form Three-question survey that appears when users click the button. How to design and build The feedback pattern uses Medallia to collect user sentiment. How this pattern works Position the Medallia feedback button at the bottom of main content.Coordinate placement with back-to-top button and last-updated date when present.Maintain consistent spacing regardless of which elements are present.Trigger modal form on button click.Display confirmation screen post-submission and return focus to button. Components used in this pattern ButtonBack to top Code usage Usage The feedback pattern is powered by Medallia integration. **Research findings:** - Moving button from sidebar to main content increased submissions 84-1,280% across tested pages - 54-60% of participants looked in footer first when searching for feedback options See the Medallia integration documentation for implementation details. Accessibility considerations Previous sticky sidebar placement created 508 compliance issues; relocation to main content resolved accessibility barriers.The button must be keyboard accessible.Focus must return to the button after the modal is closed.Screen magnification users may miss bottom-placed buttons, but research showed this is still the preferred location. Provide feedback Share your feedback, report issues, or suggest improvements for the Feedback component. Your input helps us make the design system better for everyone. searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: The VA Design System metrics dashboard displays usage and health metrics for the design system. The data flows through multiple repositories and processes to create a comprehensive view of system adoption and performance.

searchDocs.title: Architecture​
searchDocs.content: ┌─────────────────────┐ ┌──────────────────────┐ ┌────────────────────────┐ │ component-library │ │ vets-design-system- │ │ design.va.gov │ │ repo │───▶│ documentation │───▶│ (metrics dashboard) │ │ │ │ repo │ │ │ └─────────────────────┘ └──────────────────────┘ └────────────────────────┘ │ │ │ ▼ ▼ ▼ ds-components-*.csv JSON metrics files HTML + Charts (component usage) (processed data) (final dashboard)

searchDocs.title: 1. Component Usage Data (CSV → JSON)​
searchDocs.content: Source Repository: component-libraryLocation: packages/design-system-dashboard-cli/output/ds-components-*.csvWhat it contains: Usage counts for each VA design system component across all VA applications  Data Flow:​  Generation: CSV files are generated in the component-library repo using their dashboard CLITransfer: GitHub Actions workflow fetches the latest CSV from component-library repoProcessing: scripts/process-ds-components.js converts CSV to JSONOutput: Creates component-usage.json in both locations: /src/assets/data/metrics/ (for JavaScript charts)/src/_data/metrics/ (for Jekyll Liquid templates)  CSV Structure:​  date,component_name,uswds,static_content_templates,yellow_ribbon_schools,...[123 VA applications] 2025-09-04,VaAlert,0,2,0,5,12,... 2025-09-04,VaButton,0,8,2,15,25,...   JSON Output:​  { "top_components_overall": [ { "name": "VaModal", "usage_count": 316, "totalUsage": 316, "applicationBreakdown": { "appointments": 5, "travel_pay": 0, ... } } ], "summary_stats": { "total_components": 50, "total_usages": 2404, "most_used": "VaModal", "applications_tracked": 123 }, "data_source": "component-library/ds-components", "report_date": "2025-09-04" }

searchDocs.title: Direct deposit
searchDocs.content: Direct deposit Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern when collecting banking information so Veterans can receive electronic payments through direct deposit. Usage When to use this pattern Collecting banking details. When Veterans need to receive electronic payments for benefits.Reviewing or updating accounts. When Veterans need to modify previously entered bank account details. Design principles Include a check image. Provide a visual reference guide showing where to find account and routing numbers.Show masked data for review. Display only the last 4 digits of account numbers when showing existing information.Clarify scope of changes. Some benefits are affected by updates while others maintain separate account information.Offer alternatives. Include expandable section addressing 'What if I don't have a bank account?' Examples New direct deposit information Form for collecting banking information with check image reference guide. Review existing information Card displaying masked account data with edit button to make changes. How to design and build The direct deposit pattern collects and displays banking information securely. How this pattern works Fieldset legend: 'Direct Deposit' with explanatory text about requirements.Include a check image showing where to locate account and routing numbers.Account type: Radio button group for Checking or Savings options.Bank routing number: Required 9-digit text input.Bank account number: Required text input.Additional info component for common questions.For review: Display bank name, masked account number (last 4 digits), and edit button. Components used in this pattern Text inputRadio buttonAdditional info Code usage Usage The direct deposit pattern is implemented in various VA.gov forms. **Production examples:** - VA Form 22-10203 (Rogers STEM Scholarship application) - VA.gov Profile direct deposit section See the [vets-website repository](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/vets-website) for implementation details. Content considerations Field	Hint text	Error messageBank routing number	—	Enter a valid nine digit routing number Bank routing number (missing)	—	Enter a routing number Bank account number	—	Enter a bank account number Accessibility considerations Ensure form fields have visible, associated labels.The check image should have descriptive alt text explaining how to find routing and account numbers.Error messages should be associated with fields using aria-describedby.Masked account numbers should be announced properly to screen readers. searchDocs.title: Email address
searchDocs.content: Email address Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern when collecting an email address, which is required for online forms that need user follow-up. Usage When to use this pattern Online form submissions. As of October 2024, email collection is mandatory for digital submissions requiring user follow-up.Contact information. When you need to communicate with users about their application or request. Design principles Collect for both parties when applicable. Capture email for both the Veteran and form completer if they are different individuals.Leverage existing data. Pre-populate email address from VA Profile API whenever possible.Skip confirmation fields. Avoid 'confirm email' fields as they provide minimal error-catching benefit when users copy/paste.Validate in real-time. Validate formatting upon entry to catch mistakes immediately.Be transparent about data use. Tell people why you want their email address to build trust.Pair with phone number. Email typically appears alongside phone number collection on the same form step.Use prefill notification. Use the prefill component to inform users when profile data populates fields. Examples Email address field Standard email input with validation and helpful error messaging. Email with context Email field with explanation of how the address will be used. How to design and build The email pattern uses a text input with email-specific validation. How this pattern works Use a single text input field with type='email' for browser validation.Include context about why the email is needed and how it will be used.Validate format on entry and provide immediate feedback.Pre-populate from VA Profile when available. Components used in this pattern Text input Code usage Usage The `emailPattern` is available as a web-component pattern in the VA Forms library. ```jsx import { emailPattern } from '@department-of-veterans-affairs/platform-forms-system/patterns'; ``` See the [vets-website repository](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/vets-website) for implementation details. Content considerations Include context explaining why email is needed: 'We may use your contact information to contact you if we have questions about your application.'Don't use jargon or technical terms when describing email requirements. Field	Hint text	Error messageEmail address	—	Enter a valid email address without spaces using this format: email@domain.com Email (invalid characters)	—	You entered a character we can't accept. Try removing the character. Accessibility considerations Ensure the email field has a visible, associated label.Use autocomplete='email' to help users fill in the field.Provide clear error messages that explain the expected format.Validate during entry and announce errors to screen readers. searchDocs.title: A mutually exclusive answer
searchDocs.content: A mutually exclusive answer Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma In some questions, either none of the options or all of them may apply to the user. This pattern addresses how to handle these situations. Usage When to use this pattern All or none scenarios. When users may need to select either none or all available options in response to a question. Design principles Checkboxes: Include 'select all that apply'. Add instructional text when using checkboxes.Avoid dedicated all/none checkboxes. Users can already select multiple or zero checkbox options.Radio buttons: Include all/none options last. When genuinely mutually exclusive, add 'all of these' or 'none of these' after other options.Consider alternatives. Reframe the question, break into separate questions with conditional logic, or explicitly state that selection is optional. Examples Checkboxes with select all that apply Checkbox group with instructional text allowing multiple or no selections. Radio buttons with none option Radio button list including a "None of these" option at the end. How to design and build Choose the appropriate form control based on the selection requirements. How this pattern works For checkboxes, include 'select all that apply' instructional text.Don't create dedicated 'all of these' checkboxes—users can already select all.Don't create dedicated 'none of these' checkboxes—users can already select none.For radio buttons, include 'all of these' or 'none of these' as the last options.For select boxes, follow radio button rules for all/none options. Components used in this pattern CheckboxRadio buttonSelect Accessibility considerations Ensure instructional text like 'select all that apply' is associated with the fieldset.Screen readers should announce the selection instructions.All options must be keyboard accessible. searchDocs.title: Dates
searchDocs.content: Dates Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern when collecting date information from users, including memorized dates, approximate dates, and date ranges. Usage When to use this pattern Memorized dates. Dates users know by heart like date of birth or anniversary dates.Approximate dates. Dates users may not remember exactly, like when they received a diploma (month/year only).Date ranges. Periods of time like service history or employment dates. Design principles Use clear labeling for ranges. Avoid 'From/To' labels; use specific descriptors like 'Start date' and 'End date'.Display full month names. Show complete month names in selected states to reduce confusion.Provide input validation. Give immediate feedback for incorrect date entries.Use a single field for birth dates. Reduces format confusion compared to separate fields.Pair with names. Date of birth collection typically appears alongside the full name pattern. Examples Date of birth Single memorable date field for collecting a user's birth date. Approximate date Month and year only fields for dates users may not remember exactly. Date range Start and end date fields for collecting a period of time. How to design and build Choose the appropriate date component based on the precision needed. How this pattern works For known dates (birth dates, specific events), use the memorable date component.For approximate dates, use the month/year date input variation.For place of birth, use a single text input to accommodate diverse birth locations.Include clear validation messages for invalid entries. Components used in this pattern Memorable dateDate inputText input Code usage Usage Date patterns are available as web-components in the VA Forms library. ```jsx import { datePatterns } from '@department-of-veterans-affairs/platform-forms-system/patterns'; ``` See the [vets-website repository](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/vets-website) for implementation details. Content considerations Field	Hint text	Error messageDate of birth	Select a month. Enter 1 or 2 digits for day and 4 digits for year.	Provide a date of birth Month	—	Select a month Day	—	Enter a day between 1 and 31 Year	—	Enter a year between 1900 and the current year Accessibility considerations Ensure date fields are properly labeled and associated with their inputs.Provide clear error messages that explain the expected format.Use ARIA attributes to announce validation errors to screen readers. searchDocs.title: Housing status
searchDocs.content: Housing status Use with cautionWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern to ask Veterans about their current housing situation, allowing them to accurately disclose their living circumstances including potential housing instability. Usage When to use this pattern Collecting housing information. When you need to gather information about a Veteran's housing or living situation.Assessing housing instability. When forms need to identify temporary living arrangements or housing risks. Design principles Use criteria-based self-identification. Rather than a simple yes/no homelessness question, use a series of criteria to help users self-identify their circumstances.Apply conditional logic. Route users to appropriate follow-up questions based on their housing situation.Consider point-of-contact. Optionally collect emergency contact information for housing-unstable Veterans. When not to use this pattern API limitations. When the backend API cannot accommodate the gathered information. Examples Housing criteria checklist Series of checkboxes allowing users to identify their housing circumstances. Conditional mailing address Mailing address collection that appears based on housing status selection. How to design and build The housing status pattern uses conditional logic to route users appropriately. How this pattern works Present housing criteria as checkboxes for self-identification.Affirmative responses to housing instability options direct users to mailing address question.'Other housing risks' responses route to a secondary form before mailing address.'None apply' responses proceed directly to the address pattern.Optionally collect point-of-contact information. Components used in this pattern CheckboxRadio buttonAdditional info Code usage Usage **Production example:** - Form 20-10207: Request priority processing for an existing claim See the [vets-website repository](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/vets-website) for implementation details. Accessibility considerations Ensure all form controls are keyboard accessible.Provide clear labels that don't stigmatize housing-unstable users.Use trauma-informed language throughout the pattern. searchDocs.title: Marital information
searchDocs.content: Marital information Use with cautionWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern to collect a user's marital status and details about current and previous marriages. Questions about marital status can bring up complex feelings, so this pattern takes a trauma-informed approach. Usage When to use this pattern Collecting marital status. When forms require knowing a Veteran's, spouse's, or dependent's marital status.Marriage history details. When forms need detailed information about current and previous marriages. Design principles Use trauma-informed approach. Explain why you're asking via Additional Info component, as these questions can evoke complex emotions.Collect only what's needed. Only request data your form actually requires.Adjust language by respondent. Shift from 'your marital status' to 'the Veteran's marital status' when appropriate. Examples Current marital status Radio button question asking about current marital status with options like Married, Divorced, Widowed, etc. Simplified marital question Simple yes/no question for forms needing less detail. How to design and build The marital information pattern uses conditional logic based on status selection. How this pattern works Primary question: 'What is your current marital status?' with options: Married, Divorced or annulled, Separated, Widowed, Never married.Simplified alternative: 'Are you currently married?' (Yes/No) for forms needing less detail.Spouse information (optional): Name, DOB, SSN, Veteran status, VA file number.Living arrangements (optional): Current/past 12-month cohabitation; reasons for separation.Marriage details (optional): Date, place, type of ceremony, termination method and date.Previous marriages: Use Multiple Responses pattern for marriage history. Components used in this pattern Radio buttonSelectAdditional info Code usage Usage The marital information pattern uses conditional navigation based on marital status selection. **Implementation features:** - Dynamic page titles referencing specific spouses - Route logic determining page sequence and visibility - Multiple Responses pattern for previous marriage history Content considerations Adjust language based on respondent role (Veteran vs. spouse vs. dependent).State file upload requirements on form introduction page when documentation is needed.Use Additional Info to explain why marital information is being collected. Accessibility considerations Ensure all form controls are keyboard accessible.Radio buttons must be properly grouped with fieldset and legend.Additional Info component must be accessible to screen readers.
