searchDocs.title: Files
searchDocs.content: Files Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern when users must upload files to provide required documentation for their application. Usage When to use this pattern Required documentation. When a user must upload a file to provide required documentation for their application. Design principles Use clear terminology. Use 'upload' and 'delete' rather than 'add', 'remove', or 'edit'.Prefer 'file' over 'document'. The term 'file' has broader applicability.Validate thoroughly. Check mime-type and file extension matching, verify UTF encoding.Handle encrypted PDFs. Detect encrypted PDFs and prompt for password when needed.Require confirmation for deletion. Use two-step confirmation before deleting uploaded files. When not to use this pattern Non-essential files. When files don't impact service delivery.Batch uploads. Avoid batch uploading scenarios which are mobile-unfriendly and create UX/technical issues. Examples Default file upload File input with instructions about accepted file types and size limits. Review uploaded file Card displaying filename with change and delete options. Delete confirmation Modal confirming the user wants to delete an uploaded file. How to design and build The file upload pattern guides users through uploading and managing documentation. How this pattern works Header clearly describing what file to upload.Instructions explaining file type requirements and why the file is needed.Bullet list of permitted file types and size limits.File input component for uploading.Review state: Card displaying filename with change/delete options.Delete state: Confirmation modal for destructive action. Components used in this pattern File inputModal Code usage Usage The file upload pattern uses the File input component with validation. **Validation requirements:** - Check mime-type and file extension matching - Verify UTF encoding for proper handling - Detect encrypted PDFs and prompt for password See the [vets-website repository](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/vets-website) for implementation details. Content considerations Use 'upload' and 'delete' rather than 'add', 'remove', or 'edit'.Prefer 'file' over 'document' for broader applicability.Provide explicit action language in instructions.Clearly list accepted file types and maximum file size. Accessibility considerations Avoid italicizing help text about file types and sizes.Require two-step confirmation before deleting files.Provide clear, actionable error messages explaining upload failures.Ensure support for screen reader and magnification users.The file input must have a visible, associated label. searchDocs.title: Multiple responses
searchDocs.content: Multiple responses Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern when collecting the same data in a series of questions, such as details about dependents, multiple addresses, or service periods. Usage When to use this pattern Collecting the same data repeatedly. When gathering the same information across multiple items.Unknown quantity of responses. When the number of items to collect is not predetermined.1 to n items. When forms need repeated similar information across one or more items. Design principles Use multi-page approach. The default approach allows flexible data collection following 'one thing per page'.Provide required and optional variants. Required variant needs at least one item; optional allows skipping entirely.Include summary page. Show all collected items with edit and delete capabilities.Use zero-based indexing. URL structure: /dependents/0/name for first item, /dependents/1/name for second. When not to use this pattern Single or limited responses. When collecting single or limited responses, use the Single Response pattern.Different questions per item. When questions differ for each item. Examples Multi-page flow Introduction page, questions flow, and summary page with edit/delete options. Add item variation List of existing items with "Add a new item" action link. Summary cards Cards showing collected information with edit and delete actions. How to design and build The multiple responses pattern has several variations to choose from. How this pattern works Multi-page (recommended): Introduction page → Questions flow → Summary page.Required variant: At least one item must be added before proceeding.Optional variant: Users may skip the section entirely.Add item variant: Displays existing items as list with 'Add a new item' link. Best when data already exists.Use URL structure: /<form-root>/<section>/<array-name>/<index>/<question-path>Provide edit and delete capabilities on summary page.Use modal for delete confirmation. Components used in this pattern AlertAction linkCardModal Code usage Usage The multiple responses pattern (also known as List & Loop) handles repeated data collection. **URL Structure:** ``` /<form-root>/<section>/<array-name>/<index>/<question-path> ``` **Examples:** - First dependent: `/form/dependents/0/name` - Second dependent: `/form/dependents/1/name` Use built-in error/validation messages and maintain consistent terminology throughout. Content considerations Use consistent terminology across pages (e.g., 'dependent' throughout, not 'family member' on some pages).Include hint text indicating required items or maximum limits.Pre-populate fields during edits. Accessibility considerations Edit links and delete buttons require accessible text so screen reader users understand what is being edited or deleted.Example: 'Edit John Smith' rather than just 'Edit'.Ensure summary cards are navigable by keyboard.Delete confirmation modal must trap focus appropriately. searchDocs.title: Signature
searchDocs.content: Signature Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern when forms require users to certify information through a statement of truth. An e-signature has the same legal weight as a handwritten signature under federal law. Usage When to use this pattern Forms requiring certification. When users must certify the accuracy of their submission through a statement of truth.Legal compliance. When forms must comply with electronic signature regulations (GPEA, UETA, ESIGN). Design principles Do not add a privacy policy checkbox. The signature pattern replaces the need for a separate privacy acknowledgment.Use Statement of truth component. Implement the dedicated component rather than alternatives.Include proper timestamps. All signatures must include UTC date and time stamps.Indicate authentication level. Watermarks must reflect whether the user was unauthenticated, IAL1, or IAL2. When not to use this pattern Not all forms need this. Only use for forms that specifically require certification or statement of truth. Examples Statement of truth Signature section with certification statement and text input for user's name. PDF with signature Generated PDF showing signature field, date signed, and authentication watermark. How to design and build The signature pattern captures electronic signatures that comply with federal regulations. How this pattern works Include instructions around signing the certification.Use a card container for the signature section.Implement the Statement of truth component.For PDFs, include: signature field (user's name), date signed (UTC), and authentication watermark.Watermark format varies by authentication level: unauthenticated, IAL1, or IAL2. Components used in this pattern Statement of truth Code usage Usage The signature pattern is implemented using the Statement of truth component. **PDF Requirements:** - Signature Field: Veteran's name from Statement of truth input - Date Signed: Current submission date (UTC) - Watermark: Bottom-right with authentication level and timestamp - VA DATE STAMP Box: Fill when form includes it (upper right corner) **Watermark formats by authentication level:** - Unauthenticated: "Signed electronically at [HH:MM] UTC [YYYY-MM-DD]. Signee not signed in." - IAL1: "...hasn't verified their identity." - IAL2: "...signed with an identity-verified account." Content considerations Use UTC timezone for all date/time stamps.Timestamps should reflect initial submission date, not PDF generation date.For signed-in users, use their authenticated name for the signature field. Accessibility considerations Ensure the signature input field has a clear, visible label.The statement of truth must be readable by screen readers.Provide clear instructions about what the user is certifying. Provide feedback Share your feedback, report issues, or suggest improvements for the Signature component. Your input helps us make the design system better for everyone. searchDocs.title: Social Security or VA file number
searchDocs.content: Social Security or VA file number Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern when collecting or displaying identifying numbers for Veterans and non-Veterans, including Social Security Numbers (9 digits), VA file numbers (8-9 digits), and Military Service numbers. Usage When to use this pattern Collecting identity information. When you need SSN or VA file number for application identification purposes.Displaying prefilled information. When showing existing identity information to authenticated users. Design principles Use single text input fields. Do not split SSN into 3 separate input fields.Avoid abbreviations. Use the full term 'Social Security number' rather than 'SSN'.Accept flexible formatting. Allow spaces, dashes, or no formatting in user input.Auto-mask input. Display with dashes upon blur for consistency.Prefill when possible. Use existing data from VA systems when available. When not to use this pattern Already on file for IAL2 users. When users are authenticated and identity-proofed with SSN already on file, use the prefilled information pattern instead. Examples Collect SSN or VA file number Form fields requesting both Social Security and VA file numbers. Display prefilled information Card showing last four digits of Social Security number for verification. How to design and build The pattern handles collection and display of sensitive identity numbers. How this pattern works Use single text input fields for SSN (not split into 3 parts).Offer both SSN and VA file number fields for unauthenticated users.For authenticated IAL2 users, SSN is uneditable when already on file.For non-Veteran applicants, request only the applicable person's SSN.Auto-mask input with dashes upon blur.Validate appropriately based on expected format. Components used in this pattern Text inputCard Code usage Usage The `ssnPattern` is available as a web-component pattern in the VA Forms library. ```jsx import { ssnPattern } from '@department-of-veterans-affairs/platform-forms-system/patterns'; ``` For screen reader accessibility, use the `formatNumberForScreenReader` utility: ```javascript import { formatNumberForScreenReader } from '@department-of-veterans-affairs/platform-forms-system/utilities'; const formattedNumber = formatNumberForScreenReader(123456789); ``` Content considerations Field	Hint text	Error messageSocial Security number	You must enter a Social Security number or VA file number	Enter a valid 9-digit Social Security number (dashes allowed) VA file number	—	Enter a valid VA file number Accessibility considerations Use the formatNumberForScreenReader utility for proper screen reader announcement of masked numbers.Ensure form fields have visible, associated labels.Provide clear error messages that explain the expected format.When displaying masked numbers, announce them in a screen reader friendly format. searchDocs.title: Gender identity
searchDocs.content: Gender identity DeprecatedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma This pattern guided design for collecting gender identity information from Veterans through VA.gov forms and profiles. The current policy recommends against using this pattern. Usage When to use this pattern Avoid redundancy. Don't ask a user to provide information that VA already has—only collect when VA lacks current data.Demonstrate user benefit. Only request gender identity data when it clearly explains how providing this information will benefit the user in their current task.Build trust. Clarify that data won't influence medical treatment or benefits determinations and enable users to manage preferences in their VA.gov profile. Design principles Opt-out option. Provide an option labeled 'Prefer not to answer'.Mark as optional. Mark questions as optional with clear communication.Brief content. Keep explanatory content brief and integrated into the task flow.Stay focused. Don't divert users from their primary objective. When not to use this pattern Policy recommendation. The current policy recommends against using this pattern.Paper form limitations. Many forms are based off of paper forms with limited fields for gender identity—collaborate with stakeholders to expand options. Examples VA.gov Profile Gender identity field in VA.gov Profile personal information section. What to know disclosure Additional info component explaining data usage. How to design and build This pattern is deprecated. Contact the Design System Council for current guidance. How this pattern works This pattern is deprecated and should not be used in new implementations.For existing implementations, contact the Design System Council for migration guidance. Components used in this pattern Additional info Accessibility considerations This pattern is deprecated due to policy recommendations. searchDocs.title: Names
searchDocs.content: Names Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern when you need to collect a person's name for contact information or an application. Usage When to use this pattern Collecting personal information. When you need a person's name for contact purposes, identification, or as part of an application process. Design principles Work with stakeholders to determine which fields are necessary. Not all applications require middle name, suffix, or maiden name.Don't restrict character input. Names can contain special characters, apostrophes, hyphens, and non-ASCII characters. When not to use this pattern Searching for records. Use a search pattern instead if you're looking up existing records by name. Examples Default name fields Standard name collection with first, middle, and last name fields. How to design and build The name pattern uses standard text input components with specific validation and labeling requirements. How this pattern works First name and last name are required fields. Middle name is optional.Suffix (Jr., Sr., III, etc.) uses a select dropdown and is optional.Mother's maiden name is optional and only included when specifically required for identity verification.Name fields should typically appear on the same page as date of birth for identification purposes. Components used in this pattern Text inputSelect Code usage Usage The `fullNamePattern` is available as a web-component pattern in the VA Forms library. ```jsx import { fullNamePattern } from '@department-of-veterans-affairs/platform-forms-system/patterns'; ``` See the [Forms library documentation](https://depo-platform-documentation.scrollhelp.site/developer-docs/va-forms-library-overview) for implementation details. Content considerations Use 'First or given name' and 'Last or family name' as labels to be inclusive of different naming conventions.Do not restrict the length of name fields unnecessarily. Some names can be quite long.Allow special characters including apostrophes, hyphens, and periods. Field	Hint text	Error messageFirst name	—	Enter a first or given name First name (invalid)	—	You entered a character we can't accept. Try removing the character or entering your name differently. Last name	—	Enter a last or family name Last name (invalid)	—	You entered a character we can't accept. Try removing the character or entering your name differently. Accessibility considerations Ensure each name field has a visible, associated label.Use autocomplete attributes: autocomplete='given-name' for first name, autocomplete='family-name' for last name.Error messages should be associated with the field using aria-describedby. searchDocs.title: Phone numbers
searchDocs.content: Phone numbers Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern when collecting phone numbers for contact purposes, supporting both domestic and international formats. Usage When to use this pattern Collecting contact phone numbers. When you need to reach users about their application or request.Gathering outreach information. When phone is a preferred or required contact method. Design principles Validate phone numbers. Users must provide a valid domestic or international phone number.Make phone required when primary. Phone fields are required when selected as the primary contact method.Require mobile for text opt-in. Mobile numbers are mandatory if the user opts into text message communications.Pair with email. Phone collection typically appears alongside email address on the same form step.Explain data usage. Tell users how their phone number will be used. Examples With country codes Phone number fields that include country code selection for international numbers. Without country codes Domestic-only phone number fields for US numbers. How to design and build The phone number pattern supports multiple formats and validation rules. How this pattern works Use the telephone input component for proper formatting and validation.Include country code selector for international number support when needed.Validate both domestic formats (703-123-4567, 7031234567) and international formats (+52 123 456-7890).Distinguish between home and mobile phone numbers. Components used in this pattern Telephone input Code usage Usage The `phonePattern` is available as a web-component pattern in the VA Forms library. ```jsx import { phonePattern } from '@department-of-veterans-affairs/platform-forms-system/patterns'; ``` **Acceptable US formats:** - 703-123-4567 - 7031234567 **Acceptable international formats:** - +52 123 456-7890 - 637031234567 Content considerations Use 'Home phone number' and 'Mobile phone number' rather than primary/secondary terminology.Display collected numbers per the VA.gov content style guidelines.Avoid jargon; maintain a plain language approach. searchDocs.title: Race and ethnicity

Ethnicity precedes race as a separate, single-response question.Multiple race selections. Race uses checkboxes to allow multiple selections.Include prefer not to answer. Clearly explain how providing this information helps the user.Stay in flow. Do not remove the user from the task at hand to communicate details about this data collection. searchDocs.title: Service history
searchDocs.content: Service history Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern when gathering information about a Veteran's periods of service in the military. Usage When to use this pattern Gathering service periods. When forms require documentation of Veteran's periods of military service.Multiple service periods. When Veterans need to add more than one service period.Reviewing prefilled data. When forms allow reviewing and updating prefilled service data. Design principles Use multiple response pattern. When forms allow Veterans to add more than one service period.Some forms only need recent service. Health care applications may only require the most recent branch of service.Clarify data scope. Clearly state that any changes made to service data within the form won't change the data that VA has on file.Minimize POW requests. Prisoner of War information should only be requested when absolutely necessary. When not to use this pattern Not required by form. When service information isn't required for the application. Examples Service periods Form collecting branch of service, start date, and end date. Service under another name Multiple response pattern for names used during service. How to design and build Service history collection is organized into logical sections. How this pattern works Service periods section: Branch of service (combo box), service start date, service end date.Service locations section: Place service started, place service ended (text inputs).Service details section: Service number, grade/rank/rating, character of discharge, type of service.Service under another name: Uses multiple responses pattern with summary review.Reserves and National Guard: Obligation start/end dates, unit name.POW status (when required): Period start/end dates with optional estimate hint text. Components used in this pattern Memorable dateText inputCombo box Code usage Usage Service history patterns use combinations of form components organized into logical sections. **Branch of service** uses a combo box with autocomplete functionality. See the [vets-website repository](https://github.com/department-of-veterans-affairs/vets-website) for implementation details. Content considerations Use the standard branch of service list maintained by VA.Provide hint text clarifying what information is required vs. optional.For POW dates, include hint text that estimates are acceptable. Accessibility considerations Ensure all date fields have proper labels and are keyboard accessible.Branch of service combo box must be screen reader friendly.Provide clear error messages for invalid date ranges. searchDocs.title: Know how their information is updated
searchDocs.content: Know how their information is updated DeprecatedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma This pattern guided design teams in helping users understand when and how their personal information will be updated in their profile when modifying information within an application. Usage When to use this pattern Prefilled profile data. When prefilled profile data is displayed and editable.Stored user data. When forms show stored user data that may change based on form input.Profile update clarity. When users need clarity about whether edits will update their VA.gov profile. Design principles System status visibility. Communicate current state so users feel in control.User autonomy. Give users control over their own information management. If changes only apply to the current application, use instead: 'Any updates you make here to your [type of contact information] will only apply to this application.'Unreliable data modification. Editable information Profile data with edit links, introduction explaining usage, and note confirming profile updates. Edit workflow Users edit information, save changes to profile, and see updated information reflected immediately. How to design and build The pattern demonstrates system status visibility and user autonomy principles. How this pattern works Display information on file—show users what data is stored.Note if information cannot be changed in the current application.For editable information, include introduction explaining how information will be used.Add note confirming updates will modify VA.gov profile.Use left blue border styling with header labels.Include edit links for each data section.Allow users to edit, save changes, and see updated information immediately. searchDocs.title: Wizard
searchDocs.content: Wizard DeprecatedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma The wizard pattern was designed to guide users through complex VA benefit eligibility pathways. It is deprecated due to difficult-to-solve accessibility issues. Use the "Complete a sub-task" pattern instead. Usage When to use this pattern Complex eligibility. Previously used to help users understand complex eligibility requirements for VA benefits.One question at a time. Presented one question at a time to avoid showing irrelevant content.Branching logic. Used branching logic to direct users to optimal pathways based on their circumstances. Design principles Deprecated. This pattern is deprecated due to accessibility issues.Use sub-task pattern. Replace with the 'Complete a sub-task' pattern. When not to use this pattern All new implementations. Do not use this pattern for any new implementations.Accessibility concerns. This pattern has difficult-to-solve accessibility issues that negatively impact screen reader users and keyboard navigation. Examples Eligibility wizard Series of plain-language questions with conditional logic determining next questions. How to design and build This pattern is deprecated. Use the "Complete a sub-task" pattern instead. How this pattern works This pattern is deprecated and should not be used in new implementations.Replace with the 'Complete a sub-task' pattern.Contact the Design System Council or CollabCycle team for implementation guidance. Components used in this pattern ButtonRadio button Content considerations For teams unable to immediately migrate, minimize accessibility issues by asking qualifying questions upfront in forms.Keep newly added content below triggering elements.Limit added content to one question or clarification.Avoid static content between interactive elements.Consult accessibility specialists for complex branching scenarios. Accessibility considerations Screen reader issues. New content added via conditional logic wasn't properly announced to screen readers.No clear endpoint. No clear endpoint for the wizard experience.Tab navigation. Users could accidentally tab out of the wizard flow.Nested fieldsets. Nested fieldsets created confusion as screen readers don't announce fieldset endings.Dynamic content. Dynamic show/hide behavior for results was unreliable for assistive technology. searchDocs.content: Help users to... Patterns for guiding users through complex tasks and processes. These patterns help users: Check eligibility for benefitsNavigate multi-step applicationsReview and verify their informationRecover from errorsManage their benefits and tools Browse the patterns in this section to find guidance for supporting your users through their journey.

searchDocs.title: Know when their information is prefilled
searchDocs.content: Know when their information is prefilled Use with cautionWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern to help users understand when their information will be automatically populated, where that data originates, and how they can modify it. Usage When to use this pattern Prefilling user data. When you prefill a user's data into an application or form.Editable prefilled data. When users have the ability to update the prefilled data.Authenticated users only. This pattern applies only to signed-in users. Design principles Visibility of system status. Communicate current state so users feel in control.User control and freedom. Allow users authority over their own information.Clarify save location. Indicate whether changes update VA Profile, the form only, or let users choose. When not to use this pattern Unauthenticated users. Don't show prefilled personal information to users who aren't signed in. Examples Non-editable prefilled information Cards without edit links for legal name, DOB, SSN with instructions for offline updates. Editable prefilled information Cards with edit links for contact details and addresses. Save location alert Alert indicating where changes will be saved. How to design and build The pattern operates across three key scenarios for prefilled data. How this pattern works Non-editable information: Remove edit links from cards for legal name, DOB, SSN.Include a bolded 'Note:' explaining how to update this information offline.Editable information: Display data in cards with edit links.Save location clarity: Display alerts indicating where changes are saved.Options: update VA Profile, update form only, or let users choose via radio buttons. Components used in this pattern AlertCardRadio buttonAdditional info Content considerations Unauthenticated alert heading: 'Sign in with a verified account'Authenticated alert heading: 'We've prefilled some of your information'Clearly distinguish between editable and non-editable fields. Accessibility considerations Use semantic HTML (description lists, unordered lists) for uneditable information.Edit links must be clearly labeled for screen readers.Success alerts should confirm where changes were saved. searchDocs.title: Check eligibility
searchDocs.content: Check eligibility Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern to help users check their eligibility for a benefit or service, providing early feedback that can reduce application rejection rates. Usage When to use this pattern Potential ineligibility. When users may not qualify for a requested benefit or service.Early feedback. When early feedback on eligibility can reduce application rejection rates.User control. When presenting eligibility status gives users control to exit lengthy processes or correct mistakes. Design principles Useful friction. Introduce useful friction by anticipating possible errors that lead to rejected applications.Give users control. Give users freedom to exit or correct information early in the process. When not to use this pattern Not a substitute for clear criteria. Don't use as a substitute for clear, plain-language eligibility criteria.Brief requirements. When eligibility requirements are brief enough for the introduction page.Searchable content. When eligibility info is concise enough to be easily searchable. Examples Eligibility check flow Two-step process showing eligibility feedback with options to exit, save, or continue. How this pattern works Alert users if they don't meet requirements using an Alert component.Offer options: exit, save-for-later, or continue anyway.Provide clear summary showing met and unmet eligibility requirements.Enable users to adjust their answers if they believe they made a mistake. searchDocs.title: Complete a sub task
searchDocs.content: Complete a sub task Use with cautionWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern to help users complete a shorter task before or within a larger process. This pattern replaces the deprecated Wizard pattern and applies the "One thing per page" principle. Usage When to use this pattern Multiple eligibility pathways. When tasks require users to navigate multiple eligibility pathways.Shorter tasks in larger processes. When completing shorter tasks within larger processes spanning multiple touchpoints.Branching eligibility. When branching eligibility choices guide users toward optimal pathways. Design principles One thing per page. Limit questions to two or three maximum per screen.Reduce cognitive load. Keep decisions simple and focused.No dead ends. Always provide next steps at completion or transition points.Use alerts for clarity. When exiting the sub-task, use alerts to communicate status. When not to use this pattern Standard form flows. Don't use as a replacement for standard form flows.Simple eligibility. When eligibility information fits concisely on an introduction page.Standalone forms. Forms without progress indicators and button pairs. Examples Supplemental Claim sub-task Determines if service suits user needs through single-question branching. Pre-Check-in Experience Verifies current information accuracy before facility visits. VAOS Vaccine screening Screens vaccination status within broader scheduling process. How to design and build Start with content design creating simple, plain-language questions on distinct pages. How this pattern works Structure logic trees gathering information in minimal questions.Avoid showing irrelevant content.Always provide next steps—no dead ends.Clearly mark completion or transition points.Use alerts for clarity when exiting the sub-task.Order essential required questions before optional ones. Components used in this pattern AccordionAlertButton pairAction link Content considerations Use plain language exclusively.Order essential required questions before optional ones.Avoid nested questions within single prompts.Group related questions by topic.Use research and card sorting for question sequencing.Use clear button labels. searchDocs.title: Navigate benefit applications
searchDocs.content: Navigate benefit applications Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern to help Veterans navigate complex benefit applications through four structured phases - Eligibility, How to apply, Apply now, and After you apply. Usage When to use this pattern Complex benefit applications. When policies and regulations around benefits are complex and users need guidance.Eligibility assessment. When users need help determining if they're eligible.Application guidance. When users need to understand what to provide and what to expect. Design principles Four-phase structure. Organize into Eligibility, How to apply, Apply now, and After you apply.Present common scenarios. Present the most common scenario using featured content.Scale complexity. Build from simple to complex information.Set expectations. Clearly communicate processing timeframes. Examples Eligibility page Page helping users understand if they qualify for a benefit. How to apply page Page explaining preparation and application methods. Apply now page Entry point to the application with process map. After you apply page Page explaining what to expect after submission. How to design and build Structure benefit applications into four distinct phases. searchDocs.title: Navigate a long list
searchDocs.content: Navigate a long list Use with cautionWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern to allow users to navigate and process a long list of items by progressively displaying additional items as needed. Usage When to use this pattern Focus attention on top results. Display only the most relevant or initial options to reduce cognitive load while letting users access additional choices progressively.Paired with sorting. Best implemented alongside default sorting or personalization tools that demonstrate results have been customized for the user. Design principles Progressive disclosure. Initially displays 5 options from a longer list.Incremental reveal. Button trigger reveals 5 additional options at a time.Auto-hide trigger. Button automatically hides when all options are visible.No unnecessary UI. Button never appears if 5 or fewer options exist total. When not to use this pattern Static content disclosure. Avoid this approach for revealing supplementary information unrelated to list items. Use the Additional info component instead for non-list supplementary content. Examples VA Online Scheduling (VAOS) Pattern used for facility and provider selection in the scheduling flow. VA Claim Status tool Pattern implemented for navigating claim-related list items. How to design and build The pattern progressively reveals list items with a button trigger. How this pattern works Initially display 5 options from the longer list.Include a 'Show more' button that reveals 5 additional options at a time.Button text format: 'Show [name of option] (#)' - e.g., 'Show past updates (3)'.Automatically hide the button when all options are visible.Once expanded, options remain visible (no collapse mechanism).Never show the button if 5 or fewer options exist total. searchDocs.content: Stay informed of their form submission status Use with cautionWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern to notify users about form submission progress, receipt confirmation, and error states at critical touchpoints in the submission lifecycle. Examples Email notifications Five email templates via VA Notify for different submission states. My VA status cards Cards showing submission states (in progress, received, action needed). Form confirmation page Success message with what to expect next. How to design and build The pattern addresses three key notification moments in the submission lifecycle. How this pattern works Email notifications: Use VA Notify templates reviewed by Privacy Officers.Protect PII/PHI: Exclude personal information and obscure filenames.Implement fallbacks: Try secondary email, then SMS, then veteran support handoff.Form confirmation pages: Differentiate between 'submitted' (sync) and 'in progress' (async).What to expect section: Explain next expected communications.My VA status cards: Show Submission in progress, Received, or Action needed. searchDocs.title: Navigate multiple related forms
searchDocs.content: Navigate multiple related forms Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern to help Veterans understand which forms come next, which are optional, and how to move through multiple forms without confusion. Usage When to use this pattern Follow-up forms. When a Veteran's primary form submission leads to follow-up forms by identifying required vs. optional forms.Supporting documents. When additional evidence or documentation must be submitted alongside the main form.Multi-form processes. Guide users through multi-form processes with clear priorities. Design principles Distinguish requirements clearly. Use explicit language differentiating 'must complete' from optional submissions rather than relying solely on visual treatment.Prioritize online over PDFs. Default linking to online form experiences with PDFs as secondary options.Set realistic expectations. Provide specific timing information and explain consequences of missing deadlines.Group logically. Organize forms by priority, timing, or purpose with consistent labeling. When not to use this pattern Unrelated forms. Don't use for unrelated forms serving different purposes or benefits.Unclear timing. When follow-up timing is unclear or speculative. Examples Introduction page mentioning related forms Lists evidence needed on introduction pages before starting the form. Mid-form flow Requires additional form downloads/uploads during the form process. Confirmation pages with required follow-ups Shows required follow-up forms after submission. Confirmation pages with optional forms Lists optional forms available after submission. How to design and build The pattern provides guidance on form placement and expectations. How this pattern works Use introduction pages when Veterans need documents before starting, multiple forms comprise one application, or scope understanding aids decision-making.Use mid-form placement when user responses trigger additional form requirements.Open required forms in new tabs to preserve progress.Remind users on confirmation pages about any mid-form downloads.Use confirmation pages when forms become available post-processing, specific deadlines apply, or forms are optional.Provide in-form submission methods for supporting documents.Allow form submission without all documents, with guidance for later submission. Components used in this pattern Process listLinkAdditional infoAlert Content considerations Structure forms consistently. Use parallel language and formatting across form listings.Be specific. Avoid vague language; clearly state what's required versus optional.Link descriptively. Use meaningful link text explaining what users will find.Explain context. Provide reasoning and timing for additional form submissions. Accessibility considerations Implement hierarchical heading structure.Ensure screen readers understand form relationships from link text.Use proper HTML list markup.Test with assistive technology. searchDocs.title: Recover from errors
searchDocs.content: Recover from errors Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern to structure error messages that help users understand what went wrong and how to resolve the issue. This applies to system-level errors, not inline form field validation. Usage When to use this pattern System-level errors. When users encounter errors that prevent them from completing a task.Clear recovery path. When you need to explain the problem and provide actionable recovery steps. Design principles Two-step structure. Step 1: Explain the problem. Step 2: Provide recovery steps.Keep titles short. Keep alert titles to 50 characters maximum.Use neutral tone. If user caused error, use neutral tone without blame.Be specific and actionable. Make recovery steps clear, specific, and actionable.Coordinate with support. Coordinate new error messages with Veteran Support team. Examples VA system error Alert explaining a VA system problem with recovery steps. User action error Neutral alert explaining what went wrong with steps to fix. How to design and build Error messages follow a two-step structure for clarity. How this pattern works Step 1 - Explain the problem: Use alert component with explanation in header.If VA caused error: 'We're sorry. There's a problem with our system...'If user caused error: Use neutral tone without blame.Step 2 - Provide recovery steps: Make steps clear, specific, and actionable.Provide contact option as secondary step if needed.Include links or buttons when necessary. Components used in this pattern Alert Code usage Usage **Standard contact information for error messages:** | Issue Type | Contact | Phone | |------------|---------|-------| | Technical help | MyVA411 | 800-698-2411 | | Benefits questions | VA Benefits | 800-827-1000 | | Education benefits | GI Bill Hotline | 888-442-4551 | | Health benefits | VA Health | 877-222-8387 | | My HealtheVet | MHV Help | 877-327-0022 | Content considerations Explain what went wrong clearly and specifically.Tell users how to fix the issue with actionable steps.Use specific, actionable language throughout.Coordinate new error messages with Veteran Support team. Accessibility considerations Alert components must be announced to screen readers immediately.Links and buttons within error messages must be keyboard accessible.Contact phone numbers should be formatted for click-to-call on mobile. searchDocs.title: Sign in
searchDocs.content: Sign in Use with cautionWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern for products requiring or allowing sign-in to VA.gov or VA online services, with tailored alerts for verified vs. unverified access scenarios. Usage When to use this pattern Products requiring sign-in. When your product requires users to sign in to VA.gov or VA online services.Verified account access. When services need verified account authentication. Design principles Use standard alerts. Select one of two blue alert variations (required vs. optional sign-in).Handle unverified accounts. Implement all three yellow verification alerts for unverified accounts.Conditional display. Alerts display conditionally based on user sign-in status and account type.Collaborate on custom implementations. Work with CAIA and identity teams for custom implementations. When not to use this pattern Unverified accounts accepted. Products that accept unverified accounts may need adjustments.No prefill capability. Products that allow sign-in without prefill capability.Alternative incentives. Products with alternative sign-in incentives (e.g., Intent to File generation).My HealtheVet specific. Products requiring My HealtheVet registration specifically. Examples Required sign-in (verified) Blue alert indicating sign-in is required for verified accounts. Optional sign-in (verified) Blue alert indicating sign-in is optional but recommended. Verify account alerts Yellow alerts prompting users to verify with ID.me or Login.gov. How to design and build The sign-in pattern uses alert variations based on sign-in requirements and account status. How this pattern works Select the appropriate blue alert: required sign-in or optional sign-in.Implement all three yellow verification alerts for unverified accounts.Display alerts conditionally based on user sign-in status.Support account types: Login.gov, ID.me, My HealtheVet.Request identity team review of pull requests.Obtain CAIA content review for any content changes. Components used in this pattern Alert - sign-in Content considerations Do not modify alert content without CAIA approval.These alerts typically serve as the sole sign-in messaging.Reference the style guide section on sign-in and identity verification for additional content needs. Accessibility considerations Follow VA.gov accessibility standards for all alert components.Ensure sign-in buttons and links are keyboard accessible.Alert content must be announced to screen readers. searchDocs.title: Update prefilled information
searchDocs.content: Update prefilled information Use with cautionWeb GitHub Issues...FigmaResearch... Use this pattern to help users understand how to modify information that has been automatically filled into forms, including what can be edited online versus what requires other methods. Usage When to use this pattern Prefilled forms. When information is prefilled into forms or tools.Clarity on updates. When users need clarity on updating sensitive data they cannot modify online.Save location communication. When you need to communicate where changes will be stored. Design principles System status visibility. Keep users informed about what data they can modify.User control. Provide control over personal information.Clear save behavior. Explain whether changes affect just the form or their VA profile. When not to use this pattern No prefilled information. When no information is prefilled in the form.Unauthenticated users. When users are not signed in.Forms without sign-in. When forms don't require sign-in. Examples Non-editable information cards Display without edit links, includes phone/contact instructions. Editable information cards Include edit links for updatable fields like addresses. User-controlled saving Radio buttons let users decide if changes update their profile. Success confirmations Alerts confirm where changes were saved. How to design and build The pattern addresses both editable and non-editable prefilled data. How this pattern works Omit edit links for non-editable prefilled data.Include 'Note:' sections with phone numbers for updating restricted information.Display informational alerts before changes confirming sync behavior.Use radio buttons for optional profile updates.Show success alerts after changes are saved.Implement error states if required data is missing. searchDocs.title: Email
searchDocs.content: Email Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma The email template serves as a design resource for communicating with Veterans through email. It's primarily used for transactional messages like submission confirmations, status updates, and account modifications, though it can also serve informational purposes. Usage When to use this template Transactional messages. Submission confirmations, status changes, and account updates.Informational purposes. General communications to Veterans.Mockup preparation. Preparatory tool for mockups in Figma before implementation through VA Notify. Usability guidance System fonts. Limited email client support for custom fonts means typography uses system fonts.VA Notify. Emails deploy through VA Notify's Self Service Portal using markdown formatting. Structure The email template includes consistent header and footer sections with customizable body content. Anatomy Header — Contains VA logo with appropriate alt text. Responsive design with 600px breakpoint - centered seal on smaller screens, left-aligned on larger ones.Heading — Required H1 conveying email purpose. Should match or expand upon the subject line. Limited to one per email.Salutation — Personalizes message using 'Dear ((first_name)),'. Avoids including last name due to PII concerns.Body Content — Supports paragraph, bold, italic text, bulleted lists, headings (H2-H4), blockquotes (max one), action links (max one), links (max three), and dividers.Contact Section — Includes 'Have questions?' heading. Default content: 'Visit https://va.gov or call 800-827-1000 (TTY: 711)'. Removable if redundant.Footer — Explains email reason and requests no replies. Preceded by divider. Text customizable per message type. Content guidelines Refer to the Email Content and Style Guide for detailed writing standards.Do not close emails with 'VA.gov' or 'VA' signatures.Limit to one blockquote per email.Maximum of one action link and three regular links.Organizations must onboard via the VA Notify GitHub repository. Accessibility considerations Include appropriate alt text for VA logo in header.Use semantic heading structure (H1-H4).Ensure links are descriptive and accessible.Follow email accessibility best practices for all content. searchDocs.title: Forms overview
searchDocs.content: Forms overview Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma This section provides guidance for building benefit applications, multi-step processes, and data collection experiences that serve Veterans and their families. Usage When to use this template Benefit applications. Forms suited for benefit applications requiring personal information collection.Multi-step processes. Processes requiring progress-saving and validation.Data collection. Experiences needing validation and error handling.Authenticated experiences. Where users review and update their information. Structure The complete form journey consists of five key pages that guide users from discovery to confirmation. Anatomy How to Apply — Drupal landing page outlining eligibility and application details.Introduction — Sets expectations and provides preparation steps before starting the form.Step Pages — Core information collection following established patterns.Review — Allows users to verify and edit their responses before submission.Confirmation — Explains next steps after successful submission. Content guidelines One thing per page. Reduce cognitive load by focusing on single tasks.Progressive disclosure. Show only necessary content at each step.Clear progress indicators. Help users understand where they are in the process.Automatic progress-saving. Preserve user work for authenticated sessions.Plain language. Use clear, simple communication throughout. Accessibility considerations Follow VA.gov form accessibility guidelines for all form implementations.Use the VA Forms Library for standardized, accessible functionality.Refer to the Content style guide for appropriate language.See the Guide to Digitizing VA Forms for comprehensive project planning. searchDocs.content: Form step Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma Use the form step template to create all pages of a form except for the introduction, review, and confirmation pages. This template handles data entry, selections, and document uploads. Usage When to use this template Interior form pages. Creating interior pages of online forms collecting user information.Data entry. Pages requiring data entry, selections, or document uploads.Standard form flow. Any form step besides introduction, review, or confirmation. Usability guidance Form steps limit. Design recommends limiting forms to 13 total steps.Single component rule. In Figma, replace the placeholder with only one component (may be custom local components).Breadcrumb consistency. Remains static across all form step pages.Title consistency. Use identical H1 form title and subtitle across all form pages.Pronouns matter. Specify 'your' only when referring to the form submitter to clarify whose information is requested. Structure The template has authenticated and unauthenticated variations. Anatomy Breadcrumb navigation — Static navigation across all form step pages.Form title and subtitle — Consistent H1 title and form number subtitle.Progress bar - segmented — Shows current step with step header.Saved as message — Authenticated only - displays application ID.Prefill alert — Authenticated only - appears on pages with prefilled data.Form step content — Page title and form fields for this step.Finish this application later — Authenticated only - link to save and exit.Button pair — Back/Continue navigation buttons.Autosave alert — Authenticated only - success alert showing last saved timestamp.Need help? component — Contact information for assistance. Components used in this template BreadcrumbsProgress bar - segmentedAdditional infoNeed helpAlert — Prefill and autosave variationsButton pair Content guidelines Step headers vs page titles. Step headers identify general information categories ('Your personal information'), while page titles specify details ('Your name and date of birth').Body text. Aim for fewer than fifty words in the body text. Use for clarifying needed information or data usage.Hint text. Provide context helping users select correct responses. Example: 'We'll use your email address to confirm when we receive your form.'Additional information. Reserve for details important to some users but not essential for everyone. Accessibility considerations Each page's H1 must be unique and descriptive.Authenticated version includes autosave messaging for screen readers.Unauthenticated version has simplified structure without autosave alerts.Follow VA.gov form accessibility guidelines. searchDocs.title: Accessibility guidelines for forms
searchDocs.content: Accessibility guidelines for forms Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma This template provides detailed accessibility requirements and implementation guidance for forms on VA.gov, ensuring Veterans with disabilities can access and complete essential services. Approximately 1 in 4 Veterans live with service-connected disabilities. Usage When to use this template All form implementations. These guidelines apply to all forms on VA.gov.Section 508 compliance. Forms must comply with Section 508 and Americans with Disabilities Act requirements.Universal usability. Addresses technical accessibility, cognitive accessibility, and universal usability principles. Structure The guidelines cover focus management, form labeling, validation, cognitive accessibility, and testing requirements. Anatomy Managing Focus in Form Flows — Single-page applications must manually set focus when users move between pages since focus doesn't reset automatically.Where to Move Focus — If page has unique heading (H1 or H3), set focus there. Without unique heading, set focus on step indicator header (H2).Form Labeling and Structure — Each form step needs unique H3 describing current step. Use consistent fieldset/legend patterns across all steps.Input Validation and Error Handling — Validate required fields when users attempt to continue. Move focus to first field with error. Preserve all user data when validation errors occur.Cognitive Accessibility — Present one question per page, show clear progress indication, use consistent terminology, include review pages for important submissions.Comprehensive Accessibility Testing — Keyboard navigation, screen reader testing, error message association, proper labeling, color contrast verification. Content guidelines Focus testing checklist. Does focus land on unique heading after clicking Continue? Is focused item visible? Does screen reader immediately announce step/page name?Error messages. Provide specific, actionable error messages in plain language. Example: 'Enter a valid 9-digit Social Security number' rather than 'Invalid input'.Cognitive design. Present one question per page, show clear progress, use consistent terminology, provide format examples. Accessibility considerations WCAG 2.4.3 Focus Order. Focus moves in a logical sequence that preserves meaning and operability.WCAG 2.4.7 Focus Visible. Keyboard focus indicator must be visible.WCAG 3.3.2 Labels/Instructions. Labels or instructions are provided when content requires user input.WCAG 3.3.3 Error Suggestion. Correction suggestions provided for detected errors.WCAG 4.1.3 Status Messages. Form validation changes must be programmatically determinable.Required testing areas. Keyboard navigation, screen reader testing (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver), error message association, proper labeling, color contrast.Multi-step specific testing. Screen reader announcements for step changes, progress bar updates, focus movement after error correction, session persistence.Foundational testing before launch. Color and contrast evaluation, automated testing with aXe DevTools, content zoom and reflow, keyboard navigation.Support available. The Accessibility Digital Experience (ADE) team provides early guidance during planning phases. searchDocs.title: Confirmation
searchDocs.content: Confirmation Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma The form confirmation page provides users with essential information following their submission of an online application, including what to expect next, a benefit summary, confirmation number, and submission date. Usage When to use this template Successful submission. After users successfully submit an online form or application.Confirm receipt. To confirm receipt and provide next steps.Record keeping. To help users retain records of their submission. Structure The confirmation page provides essential post-submission information and record-keeping options. Anatomy Page Title (H1) — Carries over from the original form.Keep Records Pattern — Enables users to save/print submission records.Success Alert — Confirms successful submission with relevant details including date and confirmation number.Download Link — Allows downloading form copies.Data Accordion — Displays submitted information in collapsible sections.Print Button — Primary action for printing confirmation.Additional Content — Benefit-specific information and next steps.Back to VA.gov Link — Secondary action link for navigation.Need Help Footer — Support contact information. Components used in this template Alert — Success variantAccordionButton — Primary for print actionAction link — Secondary actionNeed helpProcess list — For extended tracking information Examples Request for personal records (Form 20-10206) Confirmation page for personal records request. Authorize release of non-VA medical information (Form 21-4142) Confirmation page for medical information release authorization. Lay or witness statement submission (Form 21-10210) Confirmation page for statement submissions. Content guidelines Success alert example. 'Form submission started on [date]. Your submission is in progress. It can take up to 30 days for us to receive your form.'Address key questions. What happens after submission? Processing timeline? Required actions while waiting? How to get help? Will VA request more information?Research shows 30.55% print page for records, 27.35% download form copy, 27.03% check status on My VA.A 2024 study found that a majority of Veterans indicated they would download a copy of their form submission. Accessibility considerations Remove breadcrumbs when printed.Ensure content fills 100% of print width.Follow form accessibility guidelines for all content.Success alerts should be announced to screen readers. searchDocs.title: Form step - Minimal
searchDocs.content: Form step - Minimal Use with cautionWeb GitHub Issues...Figma This template is for all internal pages of a digitized form that asks Veterans to enter information, select an option, or upload supporting documents. It uses a simplified header/footer to reduce cognitive load. Usage When to use this template All new forms. All new forms should use this template per current guidance.Multi-page form flows. Creating multi-page form flows (excluding introduction, review, confirmation pages).Authenticated or unauthenticated. Forms requiring either authenticated or unauthenticated user experiences. Usability guidance Request prerequisite information. Gather information before it's needed in the flow.Front-load easier questions. Start with easier questions for user comfort.Group related information. Organize logically by topic. When to consider something else Introduction pages. Use the Introduction template instead.Review pages. Use the Review template instead.Confirmation pages. Use the Confirmation template instead.Existing forms. Unless migration investment is justified. Structure The template has authenticated and unauthenticated variations with minimal chrome. Anatomy Minimal header — Simplified header with form title and subtitle.Back link — Navigation to previous step.Segmented progress bar — Shows current step with step label.Autosave message — Authenticated only - shows save status.Page header (H1) — Unique heading describing requested information.Form question content — The actual form fields for this step.Finish later link — Authenticated only - save and exit option.Continue button — Primary action to proceed.Autosave alert — Authenticated only - confirmation of saved progress.Need help component — Contact information for assistance.Feedback pattern — User feedback collection.Minimal footer — Simplified footer with essential links only. Components used in this template Minimal headerBack linkProgress bar - segmentedAdditional infoAlert — Autosave alertNeed helpMinimal footer Examples Request personal records (VA Form 20-10206) Example of minimal form step template in production. View live example Content guidelines Unique H1 per page. Each question page requires a unique H1 that describes the requested information.H1 can be input label. The H1 can be a text input label, form field group legend, or standalone text coded as H1.Fieldset/legend structure. Associate helper text with the legend for proper screen reader announcement.Keep hint text brief. Single short sentences; avoid line breaks and links. Accessibility considerations Unique H1 prevents disorientation. Repetitive H1s confuse sighted and screen reader users.Proper fieldset/legend associations. Essential for screen reader users.Focus management. Consistent navigation for keyboard users.Research found sighted users confused by repetitive H1s and step headings.Screen reader users reported disorientation from redundant H1s.Mobile magnification users may have content hidden below fold. searchDocs.title: Homepage
searchDocs.content: Homepage Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma The homepage serves as VA.gov's primary landing page, providing an overview of VA offerings for Veterans, service members, family members, and caregivers. It facilitates navigation to key features and enables visitors to explore benefits, access services, and sign in for personalized experiences. Usage When to use this template VA.gov homepage only. Only for www.va.gov's single, unique homepage.All site visitors. Serves visitors seeking to re-orient themselves or explore VA offerings. Usability guidance Single messages only. No rotating content.Clear, accessible language. For all Veterans and family members.Follow section-specific guidance. Refer to component documentation for each area. When to consider something else Subsection landing pages. Not intended for subsections, sub-directories, or subdomains of VA.gov.Other landing pages. Using this template elsewhere creates confusion about site location and navigation. Structure The template includes 11 sections in a specific order. Anatomy Header — Standard header component.Page Title — H1 'Welcome to VA.gov' (permanent fixture).Main Promo — Single message with H2 heading (max 35 characters), text (max 125 characters), and one action link.Create Account — H2 introduction, one sign-in button, one support link.Search Tools — H2 title, global search input, 2-4 links to VA search tools.Top Pages — H2 title, 8-10 links displayed across 2 columns.Featured News — H2 'VA NEWS' title, photo (large screens only), article title, teaser text (max 160 characters), two links.Benefit Hubs — H2 'Explore VA benefits and health care,' icons, hub names, teaser text (max 500 characters).Feedback Survey — Implements standard feedback pattern.Email Sign-up — H2 'Sign up to get the latest VA updates,' text input with submit CTA.Footer — Standard footer component. Examples VA.gov Homepage Live implementation of the homepage template. View live example Content guidelines Single messages only - no rotating content.Clear, accessible language for all Veterans and family members.Character limits: Main promo heading max 35 characters, text max 125 characters.News teaser text max 160 characters.Benefit hub teaser text max 500 characters.Ownership: OPIA manages promo and news; OCTO governs search, pages, hubs, feedback, and email sections. Accessibility considerations Design emphasizes clarity and accessibility across all audience segments.No rotating or multiple simultaneous messages to prevent confusion.Proper heading hierarchy throughout all sections.Follow component-specific accessibility guidance. searchDocs.title: Search results
searchDocs.content: Search results Use with cautionWeb GitHub Issues...Figma A template for displaying pages containing links to content that matched a user's search query, with optional filtering and sorting capabilities. Usage When to use this template Site search results. Displaying results from site-wide search.Resource and support pages. Listing filtered resources.Facility or provider listings. Location-based searches.Data set displays. Structured data presentations.Medication, appointment, or claims lists. User-specific data.Knowledge base searches. Documentation and help content. Usability guidance Sorting. Add only when reordering provides user value. Triggers inline without additional buttons.Filtering. Occurs inline on current page. Preserves selected filter visibility after updates.Layout. Use persistent left sidebar when search is the primary feature. Employ filter chips when displaying 3+ facets. Structure The search results page may include these components (not all required). Anatomy Page title — H1 describing the search subject.Search input — Entry field for search queries.Active filters — Chips showing currently applied filter values.Filters — Search Filter component with checkboxes/radio buttons.Sort — Select component for reordering results.Results description — Text stating quantity (e.g., 'Showing 1-10 of results').Apply filters button — Primary button triggering filter application.Clear all filters button — Secondary button removing all filters.Pagination — Navigation between result pages.Search results — Individual result entries with title link, description, and URL. Components used in this template Search inputSearch filterCheckboxRadio buttonSelectButton — Primary and secondary variantsPaginationTag — Filter chips Content guidelines Results description format: 'Showing 1-10 of results for "[query]"'.Results must update when filters change to reflect current output.Title link should match the destination page's H1.Description should be meta description with bolded matching search terms.Distinguish clearly between sort and filter functionality. searchDocs.title: Introduction
searchDocs.content: Introduction Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma The form introduction page introduces the process veterans and beneficiaries will follow to apply for benefits or complete supporting forms. It sets clear expectations, helps users prepare, and provides ways to get help. Usage When to use this template Process list version. For complicated processes, particularly initial claims or applications for VA benefits or decision review requests.No process list version. For supporting forms, reimbursement claims, and non-application forms. Usability guidance Set expectations. Clearly communicate what the process involves.Help users prepare. Guide users to gather required information and documents before starting.Provide help options. Include ways to get help and find more information about the related benefit. Structure The intro page accomplishes three key objectives for users. Anatomy Title & Subtitle — Plain language action-oriented H1 (52 characters or fewer). Official form name with form number in parentheses as subtitle. Brief introductory paragraph (1-3 sentences, max 25 words per sentence).Check your eligibility — First step in the process list for applications requiring eligibility verification.Gather your information — Lists required documents and information (5 bullets max).Start your application — Final step with sign-in or start options.What to know before you fill out this form — Alternative section for non-application forms with 2-5 key bullets. Components used in this template Process listAlert — Sign-in and prefill alertsOMB infoNeed helpAdditional info Examples File for disability compensation Introduction page for disability compensation claims. Apply for VA Education Benefits Introduction page for education benefits application. Apply for VA health care Introduction page for health care enrollment. Apply for Veterans Pension benefits Introduction page for pension benefits. Submit intent to file Introduction page for intent to file form. Content guidelines Use plain language and conversational tone.Reuse 'When to use' descriptions from form detail pages.Keep process list items brief with tailored, specific information.Include estimated time burden for completing the form.Explain post-submission timeline and next steps.Flag sensitive information requirements with explanatory components. Accessibility considerations Display sign-in alert and sign-in information for unauthenticated users.Display prefill alert and option to continue saved forms for authenticated users.Ensure proper heading hierarchy.Follow VA.gov form accessibility guidelines. searchDocs.title: Signed out vs. signed in
searchDocs.content: Signed out vs. signed in Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma This template addresses how VA.gov displays different content, features, and CTAs depending on user authentication status. When unsigned, minimal information is shown; upon sign-in and identity verification, personalized content appears. Usage When to use this template Pages with VA benefits or services. Any page offering VA benefits or services.Applications requiring authentication. Forms that need user identity.Conditional features. Pages with features based on login status.User-dependent options. When user information affects available options. Structure The template covers site header and contextual CTA variations based on authentication state. Anatomy Site Header - Large screens (signed out) — Standard Sign In button in header. Navigation without personalization.Site Header - Large screens (signed in) — User's first name replaces Sign In button. 'My VA' and 'My Health' added to top navigation.Site Header - Small screens (signed out) — Menu-based navigation. Standard Sign In link.Site Header - Small screens (signed in) — User's first name displayed. 'My VA' and 'My Health' options in expandable menu.CTA Required to Continue (Green Alert) — Signed out: 'Create account' messaging. Signed in: 'Verify identity' messaging.CTA Beneficial, Not Required (Blue Alert) — Encourages sign-in as primary action. Non-blocking, informational approach.Error State (Red Alert) — Blocks process continuation. Always provides resolution path. Components used in this template Alert — Green, blue, and red variantsHeaderButton Content guidelines Tailor messaging to authentication state.Provide clear next steps for each state.Distinguish between required and recommended actions.Always offer error resolution paths.Use appropriate alert colors: green for required, blue for beneficial, red for errors. Accessibility considerations Proper focus management in navigation state changes.Alert role semantics for status messages.Screen reader considerations for conditional content.Keyboard navigation support for all interactive elements. searchDocs.title: Review
searchDocs.content: Review Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma This template enables users to examine submitted information and make revisions as needed. It implements the "check answers" pattern at the conclusion of form workflows. Usage When to use this template Final review. Before users submit their form or application.Check answers pattern. Implementing the check answers pattern at workflow conclusion.Edit capability. When users need to modify entries before submission. Structure The Review page displays user-provided information organized by form chapter or step, with options to edit entries before final submission. Anatomy Page Title and Subtitle — H1 formatted as 'Review [Form name]' or 'Review application,' followed by form number.Progress Bar - Segmented — Shows review as the final step in the process.Review Steps/Chapters - Expanded — Bordered accordions containing form fields and user-entered values; each section includes an 'Edit' button when open.Review Steps/Chapters - Collapsed — All accordions launch in collapsed state for scannability.Penalty Notice — Required legal notice component for application finalization.Privacy Agreement — Standard component (replaced by signature pattern for forms requiring wet signatures).Button Group — Secondary 'Back' button and primary 'Submit application' button.Autosave — Displays last saved timestamp via success alert.Finish Application Later — Exit link preserving user progress.Need Help? — Contact information component. Components used in this template Accordion — Bordered variantProgress bar - segmentedPenalty noticePrivacy agreementButton groupAlert — Autosave success alertNeed help Content guidelines Organize information by form chapter or step for easy scanning.Each accordion section should include an 'Edit' button when expanded.Include the penalty notice before final submission.Show last saved timestamp for user confidence. Accessibility considerations Accordion sections must be navigable by keyboard.Edit buttons must have clear accessible labels indicating what they edit.Success alerts for autosave should be announced to screen readers.Follow VA.gov form accessibility guidelines. searchDocs.title: Hub
searchDocs.content: Hub Use: DeployedWeb GitHub Issues...Figma Hub pages serve as landing pages for specific benefit categories, providing overviews, navigation, and contact information for VA benefits and services. Usage When to use this template Benefit landing pages. Provide a parent page for a section offering specific benefits or services.Core audience benefits. Create landing pages listing all VA benefits available for Veterans, transitioning service members, or family members. Usability guidance Don't overwhelm visitors. Highlight the most important content rather than every child page.Avoid unnecessary content. Don't create content just to fill template sections.Stay within template. Don't add sections beyond the template design.Follow section guidance. Refer to component documentation for individual sections. When to consider something else Campaign landing pages. Use a Campaign Landing Page template instead.Custom benefit groupings. By health condition or audience segment - explore alternative templates. Structure The hub consists of intro, spokes (core content), and right rail sections. Anatomy Hub icon and page title — Consistent, benefit-specific icon with descriptive title.Intro text — High-level benefit overview with SEO-rich content, plus 'On this page' navigation.Critical alert (optional) — Limited to 2 specific alerts; max 1 per hub.'Get benefits' spoke — Application and eligibility content (max 10 links).'Manage benefits' spoke — Usage, tracking, and management content (max 10 links).'More resources' spoke — Related tools and benefit rate information (max 10 links).Related benefits — Links to other VA benefits outside this hub (max 5 links).Promo spot — Highlighted service or key information (right rail).'Ask questions' accordion — Contact information (right rail).'Not a Veteran?' accordion (optional) — Audience-specific links, max 3 (right rail).'Connect with us' accordion — Social media and administrative links (right rail). Components used in this template AlertAlert - ExpandableAccordionDividerIconLink — With teaser textOn this page Content guidelines Link labels should match destination page titles with descriptive additions when needed.Order links by frequency of use within manage and resources sections.Keep teaser text concise and descriptive.Use consistent benefit category naming.Maximum 10 links per spoke, 5 for related benefits. Accessibility considerations Follow VA.gov form accessibility guidelines.Implement proper heading hierarchy.Ensure 'On this page' navigation aids screen readers.Test with accessibility annotations for applications.
